This room was carpeted, and therein was a piano, a couch, a chiffonnière; above all, it contained a lofty window with a crimson curtain, which, being undrawn, afforded another glimpse of the garden through the large, clear panes, round which some leaves of ivy, some tendrils of vine were trained.

zh: “你是克里姆斯沃斯先生，是吗？”我身后传来问话声，我闻声不由地转过身来。由于我聚精会神地欣赏着这个漂亮小客厅，所以没有注意到有人进了这个大客厅。没错，那就是勒泰小姐。刚刚叫我的勒泰小姐就站在我的身后；我立即恢复沉着冷静，向她鞠躬致意——因为我不会轻易陷入窘境——然后便开始交谈起来，我评论着她这个小客厅的舒适之处，说她比珀莱先生多了一个花园，真是大有益处。
en: ‘Monsieur Creemsvort, n’est ce pas?’ said a voice behind me; and, starting involuntarily, I turned.I had been so taken up with the contemplation of the pretty little salon that I had not noticed the entrance of a person into the larger room.It was, however, Mdlle. Reuter who now addressed me, and stood close beside me; and when I had bowed with instantaneously recovered sang-froid—for I am not easily embarrassed—I commenced the conversation by remarking on the pleasant aspect of her little cabinet, and the advantage she had over M. Pelet in possessing a garden.

zh: “是的，”她说道，她也常这么想，又补充道，“正是因为这个花园，先生，我才一直住在这里，否则我或许早就搬到一个更大并且更宽敞的住所去了；但是你知道，我不可能随身带着我的花园，在这个镇上的其他地方很难再找到这样一个又大又舒适的花园了。”
en: ‘Yes,’ she said, she often thought so, and added, ‘It is my garden, monsieur, which makes me retain this house, otherwise I should probably have removed to larger and more commodious premises long since; but you see I could not take my garden with me, and I should scarcely find one so large and pleasant anywhere else in town.’

zh: 我对她的想法表示赞同。
en: I approved her judgment.

zh: “可是你还没看过我的花园呢，”她起身说道，“到窗户这边来，可以看得清楚些。”我跟着她走过去。她打开窗框，我探身向外望去，这个对我来说一直是个未知领域的花园，此时一览无遗。这是一片很长的耕地，并不开阔，中间有条小径，两边环绕着巨大的老果树。花园里有一块草坪，一个玫瑰花坛，一些由鲜花围成的边沿，远处是一片浓密的紫丁香、金链花和金合欢的小花丛。对我来说，它赏心悦目、美不胜收，因为我已经很久没有见过任何类型的花园了。但是我的目光并没有只停留在勒泰小姐的花园上；当我欣赏完那修剪整齐的花坛和正在发芽的小花丛后，我的目光转移到她本人身上，也没有匆忙收回。
en: ‘But you have not seen it yet,’ said she, rising; ‘come to the window and take a better view.’ I followed her.She opened the sash, and leaning out I saw in full the enclosed demesne which had hitherto been to me an unknown region.It was a long, not very broad strip of cultured ground, with an alley bordered by enormous old fruit-trees down the middle.There was a sort of lawn, a parterre of rose-trees, some flower-borders, and, on the far side, a thickly-planted copse of lilacs, laburnums, and acacias.It looked pleasant to me, very pleasant, so long a time had elapsed since I had seen a garden of any sort.But it was not only on Mdlle. Reuter’s garden that my eyes dwelt; when I had taken a view of her well-trimmed beds and budding shrubberies, I allowed my glance to come back to herself, nor did I hastily withdraw it.

zh: 我原以为我会看见一个身材瘦高，面色发黄的修女形象，身穿黑衣，头戴紧边白帽，帽带像修女的头饰一样绑在下巴下面；然而站在我面前的却是一个个头不高，颇为丰满的女人，也许实际上比我年龄大些，但是仍然年轻。我想，她不会超过二十七八岁。她像正统英国女人一样白皙。她没有戴帽子；头发是栗红色的，梳成一缕缕卷发；她的相貌并不算俊俏，也不算十分柔美，也不是非常端正，但是也绝不难看，而且我有理由认为她的五官表情丰富。她面容的首要特性是什么呢？是睿智？还是理智？是的，我想是这样的；但是我尚不能确定。然而我发现她的眼睛里带有某种宁静，面容里带有某种青春活力，看了令人极为喜悦。她脸颊红润，就像一个里外都熟透了的苹果。
en: I had thought to see a tall, meagre, yellow, conventual image in black, with a close white cap, bandaged under the chin like a nun’s head-gear; whereas there stood by me a little and roundly formed woman, who might indeed be older than I, but was still young.She could not, I thought, be more than six or seven and twenty.She was as fair as a fair Englishwoman.She had no cap; her hair was nut-brown, and she wore it in curls; pretty her features were not, nor very soft, nor very regular, but neither were they in any degree plain, and I already saw cause to deem them expressive.What was their predominant cast?Was it sagacity—sense?Yes, I thought so; but I could scarcely as yet be sure.I discovered, however that there was a certain serenity of eye and freshness of complexion most pleasing to behold.The colour on her cheek was like the bloom on a good apple, which is as sound at the core as it is red on the rind.

zh: 勒泰小姐和我开始谈及正事。她说她对自己即将采取的步骤是否明智不敢绝对肯定，因为我很年轻，家长们可能会反对我这样的教师去教他们的女儿。“但是根据自己的判断行事一般都是好的，”她说，“我们要牵着家长走，而不是由他们领导我们走。一个教师是否合格并不取决于年龄；从我的见闻观察来看，我宁愿信任你而不信任音乐老师勒德吕先生，他是一个近五十的已婚男人。”
en: Mdlle. Reuter and I entered upon business.She said she was not absolutely certain of the wisdom of the step she was about to take, because I was so young, and parents might possibly object to a professor like me for their daughters.‘But it is often well to act on one’s own judgment,’ said she, ‘and to lead parents, rather than be led by them.The fitness of a professor is not a matter of age; and, from what I have heard, and from what I observe myself, I would much rather trust you than M. Ledru, the music-master, who is a married man of near fifty.’

zh: 我说我希望她会发现我值得她的褒奖；如果我了解我自己的话，我是不会辜负她对我的信任的。“虽然如此，”她说，“我还是会对你严加监督的。”之后她接着谈及薪水问题。她很慎重，戒备心强。她完全没有讨价还价，而是小心翼翼地试探着我的期望；我守口如瓶，不说出一个确定的数字，她就反复地劝导我，用一种流利但又婉转曲折的说法，最终商定每年五百法郎——这并不算太多，但是我同意了。谈判还没有结束时，天色已微暗。我倒是不急不忙，因为我喜欢坐在那里听她说话。她所展现的那种商务才能让我愉悦。爱德华也不会比她更注重实效，他还更粗暴、急躁；而且她又列出很多理由，解释颇多；最终她成功地使我相信她是个公正无私而且很慷慨大方的人。最后她不再讲了，她没什么可讲了，因为我默许了所有的一切，她没有必要再多解释什么。我只得起身告辞。我倒情愿再多坐一会儿。我回到我那空荡荡的小房间干什么呢？而且我看着勒泰小姐便觉得开心。尤其是现在，暮色使她的面貌柔和了一些，在这似明又暗的薄暮中，我可以想象她的额头已经舒展开来，嘴角上既带着甜美的微笑，又有着理智的线条。我起身离开时，故意伸出手，尽管我知道这有悖于国外的习惯。她微笑着，然后说道——
en: I remarked that I hoped she would find me worthy of her good opinion; that if I knew myself, I was incapable of betraying any confidence reposed in me.‘Du reste,’ said she, ‘the surveillance will he strictly attended to.’ And then she proceeded to discuss the subject of terms.She was very cautious, quite on her guard.She did not absolutely bargain, but she warily sounded me to find out what my expectations might be; and when she could not get me to name a sum, she reasoned and reasoned with a fluent yet quiet circumlocution of speech, and at last nailed me down to five hundred francs per annum—not too much, but I agreed.Before the negotiation was completed, it began to grow a little dusk.I did not hasten it, for I liked well enough to sit and hear her talk.I was amused with the sort of business talent she displayed.Edward could not have shown himself more practical, though he might have evinced more coarseness and urgency; and then she had so many reasons, so many explanations; and, after all, she succeeded in proving herself quite disinterested and even liberal.At last she concluded she could say no more, because, as I acquiesced in all things, there was no further ground for the exercise of her parts of speech.I was obliged to rise.I would rather have sat a little longer.What had I to return to but my small empty room?And my eyes had a pleasure in looking at Mdlle.Reuter, especially now, when the twilight softened her features a little, and, in the doubtful dusk, I could fancy her forehead as open as it was really elevated, her mouth touched with turns of sweetness as well as defined in lines of sense.When I rose to go, I held out my hand, on purpose, though I knew it was contrary to the etiquette of foreign habits.She smiled, and said,—

zh: “啊！还真是典型的英国人呢，”她还是很友好地递过来她的手。
en: ‘Ah!c’est comme tous les Anglais,’ but gave me her hand very kindly.

zh: “这是我们国家的特权，小姐，”我说，“并且请您记住，我将会一直这么做。”
en: ‘It is the privilege of my country, mademoiselle,’ said I ‘and, remember, I shall always claim it.’

zh: 她笑了笑，十分温和，而且带着那种她一举一动都会表现出来的宁静——这种宁静格外地使我平静、满足，至少那天晚上我是这么想的。当我再次走上大街时，布鲁塞尔似乎成了一个让我非常愉快的地方，在那个完全一样的温和平静的四月之夜，前方似乎为我敞开了一条令人振奋、十分重要的光明前程。人是一种多么敏感的生物啊，至少在那段时间里我是这样。
en: She laughed a little, quite good-naturedly, and with the sort of tranquillity obvious in all she did—a tranquillity which soothed and suited me singularly, at least I thought so that evening.Brussels seemed a very pleasant place to me when I got out again into the street, and it appeared as if some cheerful, eventful, upward-tending career were even then opening to me, on that self-same mild, still April night.So impressionable a being is man, or at least such a man as I was in those days.

zh: 第八章
en: CHAPTER VIII

zh: 那么珀莱先生本人呢？我后来还喜欢他吗？噢，极其喜欢！没有什么比他对我的态度更温和、更有风度、甚至更友好了。在他手下，我既不需要忍受冷酷的忽视和恼人的干涉，也没见过他有过自命不凡的优越感。但是，我恐怕学校那两位努力工作的贫穷的比利时招待对他不会有我这样的看法；对于他们，校长的态度总是那么冷淡、严峻、冷若冰霜。我相信有一两次他也发觉了，我对他对待我跟那两个人的不同态度有些吃惊，便带着平静而嘲讽的微笑解释说：
en: And Pelet himself?How did I continue to like him?Oh, extremely well!Nothing could be more smooth, gentlemanlike, and even friendly than his demeanour to me.I had to endure from him neither cold neglect, irritating interference, nor pretentious assumption of superiority.I fear, however, two poor, hard-worked Belgian ushers in the establishment could not have said as much; to them the director’s manner was invariably dry, stem, and cool.I believe he perceived once or twice that I was a little shocked at the difference he made between them and me, and accounted for it by saying, with a quiet, sarcastic smile,—

zh: “只是两个佛兰芒人——无所谓！”
en: ‘Ce ne sont que des Flamands—allez!’

zh: 然后他便轻轻地拿掉嘴上的香烟，向我们所坐房间的油漆地板上吐了口口水。他们确实是佛兰芒人，并且两个都带有真正佛兰芒人的特征，他们智力低下，并显示在外形中，没有人会看错。他们仍然是人，基本上都是老实人；我不懂，为什么别人就因为他们是那块贫瘠荒凉的土地上的原住民，就有借口用无止尽的刻薄和蔑视来对待他们。珀莱对我温文尔雅、和蔼可亲，这本会让我对他大有好感，可这种不公平的思想让我对他的好感多少有点减弱。一天的工作结束之后发现自己的雇主是个聪明而开朗的同伴，这当然是件愉快的事；虽然有时他显得有点尖酸刻薄，有时又有点阿谀奉承；虽然我发现他只是表面上温文尔雅，而实际上并非如此——虽然我偶尔察觉他温和的外表下实际上有着冷酷无情的一面——但我们都不是完美的；而且我早已厌倦了长期生活在X镇，那种暴虐横行、傲慢无礼的氛围了；所以在一个风平浪静的海港拔锚驻扎后，我现在可不想马上去窥探那些被小心翼翼地隐藏起来，仔细掩饰着不想让我察觉的缺点。我倒情愿认为珀莱是表里如一的，相信他是个仁慈而友好的人，除非有什么出乎意料的情况来表明他并非如此。他未婚，不久后我又发现他对于婚姻和女人完全是法国人的、巴黎人的观念。我怀疑他的道德观有些放纵，每当他提及自己所称的美丽女性时，语气中总带有一种冷淡和厌恶；但是他彬彬有礼，凡是我没有提及的话题他都不会涉及的。因为他十分聪明并且真正地喜欢谈有知识性的话题，我们总是有聊不完的话，绝不会陷入没话题的困境。我讨厌他提及爱情的方式。我从内心里憎恨逢场作戏、放浪形骸。他也感觉到我们两个的不同观念，于是我们都不约而同地避开有争议的话题。
en: And then he took his cigar gently from his lips and spat on the painted floor of the room in which we were sitting.Flamands certainly they were, and both had the true Flamand physiognomy, where intellectual inferiority is marked in lines none can mistake.Still they were men, and, in the main, honest men; and I could not see why their being aboriginals of the flat, dull soil should serve as a pretext for treating them with perpetual severity and contempt.This idea of injustice somewhat poisoned the pleasure I might otherwise have derived from Pelet’s soft affable manner to myself. Certainly it was agreeable, when the day’s work was over, to find one’s employer an intelligent and cheerful companion; and if he was sometimes a little sarcastic and sometimes a little too insinuating, and if I did discover that his mildness was more a matter of appearance than of reality—if I did occasionally suspect the existence of flint or steel under an external covering of velvet—still we are none of us perfect; and weary as I was of the atmosphere of brutality and insolence in which I had constantly lived at X—, I had no inclination now, on casting anchor in calmer regions, to institute at once a prying search after defects that were scrupulously withdrawn and carefully veiled from my view.I was willing to take Pelet for what he seemed, to believe him benevolent and friendly until some untoward event should prove him otherwise.He was not married, and I soon perceived he had all a Frenchman’s, all a Parisian’s, notions about matrimony and women.I suspected a degree of laxity in his code of morals, there was something so cold and blasé in his tone whenever he alluded to what he called le beau sexe; but he was too gentlemanlike to intrude topics I did not invite, and as he was really intelligent and really fond of intellectual subjects of discourse, he and I always found enough to talk about, without seeking themes in the mire.I hated his fashion of mentioning love.I abhorred from my soul mere licentiousness.He felt the difference of our notions, and, by mutual consent, we kept off ground debatable.

zh: 珀莱的房屋和厨房都由他的母亲打理，她是一位真正的法国老太太。她曾经是个美貌的女人——至少她对我这样说过，我也尽力相信她的话；现在她却十分丑陋，丑陋到大陆的老妇人才会有的那么丑陋。不过也许是她的穿着方式使她看起来比实际上更丑陋。在室内时她会不带帽子到处走动，灰白的头发凌乱不堪；在家里时她很少穿长外衣——只穿一件破旧的棉背心。她也很少穿鞋，而是穿着一双大拖鞋，那鞋后脚跟都给踩烂了。可是，当她高兴出去逛逛时，比如星期天或者节日时，她就会穿上色彩艳丽、质地通常都很薄的衣服，戴上一顶装饰着花环的丝绸软帽，还披了一条很漂亮的披肩。总的来说，她并不是一个坏脾气的老妇人，而是一个啰嗦又爱随随便便说话的人。她主要是在厨房里外忙，似乎很想避开她那令人敬畏的儿子。的确，她对他显然有些畏惧。当他责骂她时，他的言辞既尖刻又严厉；但是他很少自找那种麻烦。
en: Pelet’s house was kept and his kitchen managed by his mother, a real old Frenchwoman.She had been handsome—at least she told me so, and I strove to believe her; she was now ugly, as only Continental old women can be. Perhaps, though, her style of dress made her look uglier than she really was.Indoors she would go about without cap, her gray hair strangely dishevelled; then, when at home, she seldom wore a gown—only a shabby cotton camisole.Shoes, too, were strangers to her feet, and in lieu of them she sported roomy slippers, trodden down at the heels.On the other hand, whenever it was her pleasure to appear abroad, as on Sundays and fête-days, she would put on some very brilliant-coloured dress, usually of thin teXture, a silk bonnet with a wreath of flowers, and a very fine shawl.She was not, in the main, an ill-natured old woman, but an incessant and most indiscreet talker.She kept chiefly in and about the kitchen, and seemed rather to avoid her son’s august presence.Of him, indeed, she evidently stood in awe. When he reproved her, his reproofs were bitter and unsparing; but he seldom gave himself that trouble.

zh: 珀莱夫人有她自己的社交圈，有她固定的来访者，不过她的那些客人我倒是很少见，因为她一般在她所谓的密室里接待他们，那是个连着厨房、下一两级台阶才能进去的小房间。顺便说一下，我常看到珀莱夫人坐在那些台阶上，膝盖上放个木盘，一边吃着饭，一边跟她喜欢的仆人、女佣聊天，还一边责骂她的冤家——厨师，三不耽误。她从来不跟儿子一起吃正餐，事实上她也很少跟儿子一起吃任何饭。至于她在学生们的餐桌上露面那更是不可能了。这些细节在英国人听来真是匪夷所思，但是比利时不是英国，他们的习惯跟我们的不同。
en: Madame Pelet had her own society, her own circle of chosen visitors, whom, however, I seldom saw, as she generally entertained them in what she called her cabinet, a small den of a place adjoining the kitchen, and descending into it by one or two steps.On these steps, by-the-bye, I have not unfrequently seen Madame Pelet seated with a trencher on her knee, engaged in the three-fold employment of eating her dinner, gossiping with her favourite servant, the housemaid, and scolding her antagonist, the cook.She never dined, and seldom indeed took any meal with her son, and as to showing her face at the boys’ table, that was quite out of the question.These details will sound very odd in English ears, but Belgium is not England, and its ways are not our ways.

zh: 考虑到珀莱夫人这样的生活习惯，有一天发生的一件事让我感到很吃惊，那是个星期四的晚上（星期四通常放半天假），当我一个人在房间里改大叠的英文和拉丁文练习时，一个佣人敲了敲门，门打开后，那个佣人向我转达了珀莱夫人的问候，并说如果我能去餐厅跟夫人吃茶点（在我们英国称之为“茶点”）的话，夫人将十分开心。
en: Madame Pelet’s habits of life, then, being taken into consideration, I was a good deal surprised when, one Thursday evening (Thursday was always a half-holiday), as I was sitting all alone in my apartment, correcting a huge pile of English and Latin exercises, a servant tapped at the door, and, on its being opened, presented Madame Pelet’s compliments, and she would be happy to see me to take my goûter (a meal which answers to our English ‘tea’) with her in the dining-room.

zh: “你说什么？”我说，因为我想我肯定是误解了，因为这个口信和邀请都太不同寻常了。佣人又重复了一遍同样的话。当然我接受了邀请；当我下楼时，我在想这个老太太葫芦里到底在卖什么药。她儿子出门了，到阿默尼大音乐厅或者别的某个他参加的俱乐部打发夜间时光去了。就在我的手刚抓住餐厅的门把时，一个奇怪的想法在我脑海中一闪而过。
en: ‘Plaît-il?’ said I, for I thought I must have misunderstood, the message and invitation were so unusual.The same words were repeated.I accepted, of course; and as I descended the stairs, I wondered what whim had entered the old lady’s brain.Her son was out, gone to pass the evening at the salle of the Grande Harmonie, or some other club of which he was a member.Just as I laid my hand on the handle of the dining-room door a queer idea glanced across my mind.

zh: “她肯定不会是向我求爱吧。”我想。我曾听说过法国老太太喜欢干那种类型的无稽之事；而那个茶点又是怎么回事呢！我相信，她们通常是通过吃喝来开始那种事情的。
en: ‘Surely she’s not going to make love to me,’ said I.‘I’ve heard of old Frenchwomen doing odd things in that line; and the goûter!They generally begin such affairs with eating and drinking, I believe.’

zh: 我这活跃的想象让我惊慌害怕起来，如果还有时间仔细考虑的话，我无疑会立即止步，奔回房间，将自己反锁在房间里；但是每当有一种危险或者恐惧被不确定性笼罩的话，大脑中的首要想法就是弄清楚真相，当可怕的预料成真时，便可以准备逃脱的应急手段了。我扭开门把手，马上跨过那致命的门槛，随手关上门，站在珀莱夫人的面前。
en: There was a fearful dismay in this suggestion of my excited imagination, and if I had allowed myself time to dwell upon it, I should no doubt have cut there and then, rushed back to my chamber, and bolted myself in; but whenever a danger or a horror is veiled with uncertainty, the primary wish of the mind is to ascertain first the naked truth, reserving the expedient of flight for the moment when its dread anticipation shall be realized.I turned the door-handle, and in an instant had crossed the fatal threshold, closed the door behind me and stood in the presence of Madame Pelet.

zh: 我的上帝啊！第一眼看到她便似乎证实了我最担心的事情。她坐在那里，身穿浅绿色的棉布长袍，头戴一顶绣着花边的便帽，褶皱里还装饰着朵朵盛开的红色玫瑰。她的桌子上已经精心摆好食品。有水果、蛋糕、咖啡，还有一瓶我说不上名字的东西。我的额头已经开始冒冷汗，我已经回头瞟了一眼关好的门，当我眼睛四处打转看见炉边的大扶手椅上还坐了个人，我感到一种不可言状的安慰。那人也是女人，并且也是个老妇人，她体态丰满、面色红润，而珀莱夫人则是面黄肌瘦。她的打扮同样很华丽，春天里五彩缤纷的花朵把她的紫色天鹅绒帽子编织成一顶绚丽的花冠。
en: Gracious heavens!The first view of her seemed to confirm my worst apprehensions.There she sat, dressed out in a light green muslin gown, on her head a lace cap with flourishing red roses in the frill.Her table was carefully spread.There were fruit, cakes, and coffee, with a bottle of something—I did not know what.Already the cold sweat started on my brow already I glanced back over my shoulder at the closed door when, to my unspeakable relief, my eye, wandering wildly in the direction of the stove, rested upon a second figure, seated in a large fauteuil beside it. This was a woman, too, and, moreover, an old woman, and as fat and as rubicund as Madame Pelet was meagre and yellow.Her attire was likewise very fine, and spring flowers of different hues circled in a bright wreath the crown of her violet-coloured velvet bonnet.

zh: 我只来得及大概观察一番，珀莱夫人就迈着她臆想的优雅而灵活的步伐走上前来跟我搭讪——
en: I had only time to make these general observations when Madame Pelet, coming forward with what she intended should be a graceful and elastic step, thus accosted me,—

zh: “先生能应我这样一个微不足道的人的邀请丢下书本和学习，真是太赏脸了。先生能否再赏个脸，允许我向您介绍我亲爱的朋友勒泰夫人吗？她就住在隔壁——女子学校里。”
en: ‘Monsieur is indeed most obliging to quit his books, his studies, at the request of an insignificant person like me.Will monsieur complete his kindness by allowing me to present him to my dear friend Madame Reuter, who resides in the neighbouring house—the young ladies’ school?’

zh: “啊！”我想，“我就知道她很老。”我向她鞠了一躬后便就坐了。勒泰夫人坐在我的对面。
en: ‘Ah!’ thought I, ‘I knew she was old.’ And I bowed and took my seat.Madame Reuter placed herself at the table opposite to me.

zh: “您觉得比利时怎么样啊，先生？”她操着极重的布鲁塞尔口音问我。现在我已经能够很好地区分优美纯正的巴黎人发音，比如说珀莱先生的发音，和喉音很重的佛兰芒人的发音了。我礼貌地回答了她的问题，暗自纳闷我面前这样一位粗俗而笨拙的老太太是怎么成为那所声誉极高的女子学校校长的。说真的，这里面肯定有问题。勒泰夫人看起来更像一位开朗快乐、自由自在的佛兰芒老妇人，甚至像一位小客栈的老板娘，而不像一位沉着、严肃而死板的寄宿学校女校长。一般来说，大陆国家的老妇人，至少是比利时人，对自己的举止，言行以及神态都无所顾忌，而我们英国庄严的老太太则对此嗤之以鼻，认为有失体面。从勒泰夫人的那张欢快的脸可以看出她同自己国家别的老妇没有什么两样。让我觉得实在奇怪的是她的左眼总是一眨一眨地斜瞟着，右眼习惯性地半睁着。我几次尝试弄清楚这两个古怪的老家伙邀请我来用茶点的动机，但都未成功，最终只好放弃了，听任它作为一个不解之谜，我坐在那里，先看看这个，再看看那个，同时还要尽情享用她们提供的充足的蜜饯、蛋糕和咖啡。她们也吃东西，但是没有什么极好的食欲；吃完一大半的食物之后，她们建议喝一小杯酒。我婉言谢绝了。珀莱夫人和勒泰夫人就没那么拘束；她们每人给自己调了一杯在我看来烈度相当高的鸡尾酒，放在炉子旁的一个台子上，为了方便起见，她们把椅子往那边拉了拉，并邀请我也拉过去。我照做了；我正好坐在她们中间，这样两人轮流跟我聊起来，先是珀莱夫人，接着又是勒泰夫人。
en: ‘How do you like Belgium, monsieur?’ asked she, in an accent of the broadest Bruxellois.I could now well distinguish the difference between the fine and pure Parisian utterance of M. Pelet, for instance, and the guttural enunciation of the Flamands.I answered politely, and then wondered how so coarse and clumsy an old woman as the one before me should be at the head of a ladies’seminary, which I had always heard spoken of in terms of high commendation.in truth there was something to wonder at.Madame Reuter looked more like a joyous, free-living old Flemish fermière, or even a maîtresse d’auberge, than a staid, grave, rigid directrice de pensionnat.In general the Continental, or at least the Belgian, old women permit themselves a license of manners, speech, and aspect such as our venerable grand-dames would recoil from as absolutely disreputable and Madame Reuter’s jolly face bore evidence that she was no exception to the rule of her country.There was a twinkle and leer in her left eye; her right she kept habitually half shut, which I thought very odd indeed.After several vain attempts to comprehend the motives of these two droll old creatures for inviting me to join them at their goûter, I at last fairly gave it up, and resigning myself to inevitable mystification, I sat and looked first at one, then at the other, taking care meantime to do justice to the confitures, cakes, and coffee, with which they amply supplied me.They, too, ate, and that with no delicate appetite; and having demolished a large portion of the solids, they proposed a petit verre.I declined.Not so Mesdames Pelet and Reuter; each mixed herself what I thought rather a stiff tumbler of punch, and placing it on a stand near the stove, they drew up their chairs to that convenience, and invited me to do the same.I obeyed; and being seated fairly between them, I was thus addressed first by Madame Pelet, then by Madame Reuter.

zh: “我们现在谈正事吧，”珀莱夫人说，然后她便发表了她精心准备的演说，大概意思是她有幸邀请我来是为了给她朋友勒泰夫人一个机会，让她开口提出一项对我有很多益处的重要建议。
en: ‘We will now speak of business,’ said Madame Pelet, and she went on to make an elaborate speech, which, being interpreted, was to the effect that she had asked for the pleasure of my company that evening in order to give her friend Madame Reuter an opportunity of broaching an important proposal, which might rum out greatly to my advantage.

zh: “要是你懂得这事能给你带来多少好处，”勒泰夫人说，“要我说，你像是个挺机灵的人。喝一点鸡尾酒吧（或者是奇尾酒，她是那么说的）；吃饱饭后喝点倒是一种适宜的有益于健康的饮料。”
en: ‘Pourvu que vous soyez sage,’ said Madame Reuter, ‘et à vrai dire, vous en avez bien l’air.Take one drop of the punch (or ponche, as she pronounced it); it is an agreeable and wholesome beverage after a full meal.’

zh: 我鞠躬致谢，但还是谢绝了。她继续说道：“我觉得，”她严肃地抿了一小口后说，“我深深地感觉到我的爱女委托给我办的事十分重要；因为您知道，先生，掌管隔壁那所学校的是我的女儿吧？”
en: I bowed, but again declined it. She went on,—‘I feel,’ said she, after a solemn sip—‘I feel profoundly the importance of the commission with which my dear daughter has entrusted me; for you are aware, monsieur, that it is my daughter who directs the establishment in the next house?’

zh: “啊！我还以为是您掌管呢，夫人。”尽管那么说，那时我确实回想起那所学校叫勒泰小姐寄宿学校，而不是勒泰夫人寄宿学校。
en: ‘Ah!I thought it was yourself, madame.’ Though, indeed at that moment I recollected that it was called Mademoiselle, not Madame, Reuter’s pensionnat.

zh: “我！噢，不！我管理家务，看管仆人，就像我的朋友珀莱夫人为她的儿子所做的那样——别的都不干。啊！你还以为我在学校上课吧，是吗？”
en: ‘I!Oh no!I manage the house and look after the servants, as my friend Madame Pelet does for monsieur her son—nothing more.Ah! you thought I gave lessons in class, did you?’

zh: 她大笑不止，似乎我的想法不可思议地激起了她的幻想。
en: And she laughed loud and long, as though the idea tickled her fancy amazingly.

zh: “夫人您不该笑的，”我说道。“如果您没有授课，我确定并不是因为您教不了。”说着我从口袋里抽出一方白手帕，抖开它，以法国式的优雅擦了擦鼻子，同时鞠了个躬。
en: ‘Madame is in the wrong to laugh,’ I observed.‘If she does not give lessons, I am sure it is not because she cannot.’ And I whipped out a white pocket-handkerchief, and wafted it, with a French grace, past my nose, bowing at the same time.

zh: “多么讨人喜欢的年轻人呐！”珀莱夫人低声夸道，勒泰夫人并不那么富有情感，只是又笑了笑，因为她是佛兰芒人而不是法国人。
en: ‘Quel charmant jeune homme!’ murmured Madame Pelet in a low voice, Madame Reuter, being less sentimental, as she was Flamand and not French, only laughed again.

zh: “我担心你是个危险人物，”她说。“如果你那么能恭维人，佐蕾德肯定会怕你；但是如果你是个好人，我将保守你的秘密，不告诉她你多么会阿谀奉承。现在，听听她给你提的建议吧。她听说你是位杰出的教师，而她又想为她的学校找到最好的教师（因为佐蕾德是个杰出的人，是个称职的女校长），所以今天下午她委托我过来一趟，向珀莱夫人打听是否能聘用你。佐蕾德是一位行事周密的将军，没有事先准备好她是不会鲁莽前行的。我想如果她知道我已经把她的意图透露给你她会不高兴的，她没让我说这么多，但是我认为向你透露这个秘密并没有什么坏处，珀莱夫人也是这个想法。不过小心点，你不要把我们出卖给佐蕾德——我的女儿，我的意思是说。她本人行事十分细心，且十分谨慎，无法理解为什么人们能从散播一些内幕消息中找到快乐。“
en: ‘You are a dangerous person, I fear,’ said she.‘If you can forge compliments at that rate, Zoraïde will positively be afraid of you; but if you are good, I will keep your secret, and not tell her how well you can flatter.Now, listen what sort of a proposal she makes to you. She has heard that you are an excellent professor, and as she wishes to get the very best masters for her school (car Zoraïde fait tout comme une reine, c’est une veritable maitresse-femme), she has commissioned me to step over this afternoon, and sound Madame Pelet as to the possibility of engaging you.Zoraïde is a wary general; she never advances without first examining well her ground.I don’t think she would be pleased if she knew I had already disclosed her intentions to you. She did not order me to go so far, but I thought there would be no harm in letting you into the secret, and Madame Pelet was of the same opinion.Take care, however, you don’t betray either of us to Zoraïde—to my daughter, I mean.She is so discreet and circumspect herself, she cannot understand that one should find a pleasure in gossiping a little.’

zh: “她跟我的儿子一模一样！”珀莱夫人喊道。
en: ‘C’est absolument comme mon fils!’ cried Madame Pelet.

zh: “这个世界从我们的少女时代就全改变了！”另一个插嘴道。“现在的年轻人竟然都这样古板。但是我们还是闲话少说吧，先生。珀莱夫人会向她儿子提及你在我女儿学校上课的事，然后他会跟你说的；明天你就到我们家去，要求见见我女儿，你就跟她提这件事，像是先从珀莱先生那得知的，千万不要提我的名字，无论如何我都不想惹佐蕾德不高兴。
en: ‘All the world is so changed since our girlhood!’ rejoined the other.‘Young people have such old heads now.—But to return, monsieur.Madame Pelet will mention the subject of your giving lessons in my daughter’s establishment to her son, and he will speak to you; and then to-morrow you will step over to our house, and ask to see my daughter, and you will introduce the subject as if the first intimation of it had reached you from M. Pelet himself, and be sure you never mention my name, for I would not displease Zoraïde on any account.’

zh: “好的，好的！”我打断她，因为这些喋喋不休的累赘话开始让我很烦躁。“我会跟珀莱先生商量一下，事情会如您希望的那样被安排好的。晚安了，夫人们；我非常感谢您二位。”
en: ‘Bien, bien!’ interrupted I, for all this chatter and circumlocution began to bore me very much.‘I will consult M. Pelet, and the thing shall be settled as you desire.Good-evening, mesdames; I am infinitely obliged to you.’

zh: “什么！您要走了吗？”珀莱夫人惊叫道。
en: ‘Comment!vous vous en allez déj E ’ eXclaimed Madame Pelet.

zh: “再吃些什么东西吧，先生；一个烤苹果，一些饼干，或者一杯咖啡如何？”
en: ‘Prenez encore quelquechose, monsieur; une pomme cuite, des biscuits, encore une tasse de cafe?’

zh: “谢谢，谢谢，夫人——再见了。”我最终离开了那栋房子。
en: ‘Merci, merci, madame—an revoir.’ And I backed at last out of the apartment.

zh: 回到自己的房间，我便自己在脑海里将晚上的事情顺了一遍。总而言之这件事很蹊跷，而且处理得很奇怪。两位老太太把整件事情搅合得有点错综复杂；但是，我心中对于这件事最主要的感觉倒是一种满足感。首先，在另一所学校授课是一种改变；其次教年轻的女学生们会是一件有趣的事情；被邀请去给寄宿学校的女学生们上课将是我人生中一种全新的体验。此外，当我瞥见那个被木板钉起来的窗户时，我心想，“现在起码我可以见到那个神秘的花园了。我将看到天使们和她们的伊甸园了。”
en: Having regained my own room, I set myself to turn over in my mind the incident of the evening.It seemed a queer affair altogether, and queerly managed.The two old women had made quite a little intricate mess of it; still, I found that the uppermost feeling in my mind on the subject was one of satisfaction.In the first place, it would be a change to give lessons in another seminary; and then to teach young ladies would be an occupation so interesting; to be admitted at all into a ladies’ boarding-school would be an incident so new in my life.Besides, thought I, as I glanced at the boarded window, ‘I shall now at last see the mysterious garden. I shall gaze both on the angels and their Eden.’

zh: 第十章
en: CHAPTER X

zh: 第二天上午我在珀莱先生家度过，时间似乎过得很慢。我恨不得快点到下午，那样我就能再去隔壁的寄宿学校，在那环境宜人的地方给学生上第一堂课，在我眼里，那地方真是太可爱了。中午时，午休时间到了；我们一点钟用餐。很快就到了上课的时间。终于，圣居迪勒教堂深沉的大钟缓缓敲响了下午两点的钟声，预示着我满心期待的时刻来临了。
en: Next day the morning hours seemed to pass very slowly at M. Pelet’s. I wanted the afternoon to come, that I might go again to the neighbouring pensionnat and give my first lesson within its pleasant precincts, for pleasant they appeared to me. At noon the hour of recreation arrived; at one o’clock we had lunch.This got on the time; and at last St. Gudule’s deep bell, tolling slowly two, marked the moment for which I had been waiting.

zh: 就在那窄窄的后楼梯下面，我碰到了珀莱先生。
en: At the foot of the narrow back stairs that descended from my room I met M. Pelet.

zh: “你今天看上去真是神采奕奕啊！”他说，“我还从没见你这么开心过呢。什么事那么开心呢？”
en: ‘Comme vous avez l’air rayonnant!’ said he. ‘Je ne vous ai jamais vu aussi gai.Que s’est-il donc passé?’

zh: “还用说嘛，我太喜欢这些改变了。”我回答说。
en: ‘Apparemment que j’aime les changements,’ replied I.

zh: “哦！明白了——原来是这样啊——不过我还是希望你明智一点儿。你年纪还小——还很年轻，相对你即将承担的责任，你得谨慎一点儿——明白吗？”
en: ‘Ah!je comprends—c’est cela—soyez sage seulement.Vous ètes bien jeune—trop jeune pour le role que vous allez jouer; il faut prendre garde—savez-vous?’

zh: “可是有什么该小心的呢？”
en: ‘Mais quel danger y a-t-il?’

zh: “我也说不好——不要给人留下深刻印象——就是这样吧。”
en: ‘Je n’en sais rien—ne vous laissez pas aller à de vives impressions—violà tout.’

zh: 我笑了。一想到我可能会创造深刻的印象，一阵细微的喜悦感就会涌上心头。而正是那死气沉沉、单调乏味的日常琐事一直折磨着我。男子学院里那些身穿宽大外套的孩子从未在我心里激起过什么深刻印象，除了偶尔在我发怒的时候。我从珀莱先生面前冲过去，沿着走廊阔步走去，他的笑声随之从我身后传来——一种纯正的法式的、放荡的、嘲讽的笑声。
en: I laughed.A sentiment of exquisite pleasure played over my nerves at the thought that “vives impressions” were likely to be created.It was the deadness, the sameness of life’s daily ongoings that had hitherto been my bane.My blouse-clad élèves in the boys’ seminary never stirred in me any “vives impressions” , except it might be occasionally some of anger.I broke from M. Pelet, and as I strode down the passage he followed me with one of his laughs—a very French, rakish, mocking sound.

zh: 我又一次站立在隔壁的门边，很快就又被请上那条让人心情愉快的通道，这通道四周是鸽灰色的仿大理石墙壁。我随着女仆走下台阶，转了个弯，发觉自己来到了一个类似走廊的地方。一个侧门开了，勒泰小姐那娇小丰满却不失优雅的身姿出现了。因为是大白天，所以我现在能看清她的衣着打扮。她穿着一件简单朴素的真丝长袍，长袍剪裁合适，将她那结实圆润的身形衬托得近乎完美；精致的小领子、绣着蕾丝的袖口和干净的巴黎风格短靴，将她的脖颈、手腕和双脚展现得美丽无比；可当她突然向我走近时，表情又是那么庄重！她的眼睛里和前额上都写着焦虑和忙碌。她看起来简直是严苛。“早安，先生。”她相当客气地问候我，却如此漠然、平淡，给我的深刻印象迎面甩来一条又冷又湿的毛巾。主人露面之后，女仆就转身离去了，我和勒泰小姐于走廊上并肩慢慢走着。
en: Again I stood at the neighbouring door, and soon was readmitted into the cheerful passage with its clear dove-colour imitation marble walls.I followed the portress, and descending a step, and making a turn, I found myself in a sort of corridor.A side door opened; Mdlle. Reuter’s little figure, as graceful as it was plump, appeared.I could now see her dress in full daylight.A neat, simple mousseline-laine gown fitted her compact round shape to perfection; delicate little collar and manchettes of lace, trim Parisian brodequins showed her neck, wrists, and feet to complete advantage; but how grave was her face as she came suddenly upon me!Solicitude and business were in her eye, on her forehead.She looked almost stern.Her ‘Bonjour, monsieur’ was quite polite, but so orderly, so commonplace, it spread directly a cool, damp towel over my vives impressions.The servant turned back when her mistress appeared, and I walked slowly along the corridor, side by side with Mdlle. Reuter.

zh: “先生今天要给一班授课，”她说，“教新课之前最好先来个听写或阅读，毕竟在外语教学中那些是最简单的形式；当然，第一次登台讲课感到紧张是在所难免的。”
en: ‘Monsieur will give a lesson in the first class today,’ said she; ‘dictation or reading will perhaps be the best thing to begin with, for those are the easiest forms of communicating instruction in a foreign language; and at the first a master naturally feels a little unsettled.’

zh: 依我的经验来看，她说得很对。我只好沉默以示赞同。我们往前走着，都默默不语。走廊的尽头是一个又高又大的方形的大厅。从一边的玻璃门看进去，会发现里面有一个长长的、窄窄的餐厅，有几张桌子、一个橱柜和两盏灯。大厅什么也没有。正面那几扇大玻璃门向运动场和花园打开着；对面是一条宽大而弯曲盘旋的楼梯；大厅的其他两面墙上各有一扇巨大的折叠门，此时都紧闭着，毋庸置疑，通过那对折叠门就可以进到教室。
en: She was quite right, as I had found from experience.It only remained for me to acquiesce.We proceeded now in silence.The corridor terminated in a hall, large, lofty, and square.A glass door on one side showed within a long narrow refectory, with tables, an armoire, and two lamps.It was empty.Large glass doors in front opened on the playground and garden; a broad staircase ascended spirally on the opposite side; the remaining wall showed a pair of great folding doors, now closed, and admitting, doubtless, to the classes.

zh: 勒泰小姐用余光瞥了我一下，或许是想确认我是否足够冷静，好被领进她那神秘的殿堂。我想，她应该觉得我的神情还算镇静，因为她已经推开了那扇门，我跟在她后面走了进去。迎接我们的是一阵沙沙的起立声。我并未左顾右盼，径直沿着两排桌凳之间的过道走上讲台，讲台有一个台阶那么高，上面有张孤零零的讲桌，我便坐在桌旁的空椅子上，这样就可以监视教室的一部分了，而另外一部分由坐在差不多高度的讲台上的女教师监视。讲台后面有一块可移动的隔板，可将这个教室和那边的教室隔开，隔板上连着一块漆得乌黑发亮的木制大黑板；讲桌上放着一支白色粗粉笔，以便老师将课文中出现的语法或语言难点写在黑板上进行讲解。粉笔旁边有一块湿海绵，可以擦去黑板上已经讲解过的字迹。
en: Mdlle. Reuter turned her eye laterally on me, to ascertain, probably, whether I was collected enough to be ushered into her sanctum sanctorum.I suppose she judged me to be in a tolerable state of self-government, for she opened the door, and I followed her through.A rustling sound of uprising greeted our entrance.Without looking to the right or left, I walked straight up the lane between two sets of benches and desks, and took possession of the empty chair and isolated desk raised on an estrade, of one step high, so as to command one division, the other division being under the surveillance of a maîtresse  similarly elevated.At the back of the estrade, and attached to a movable partition dividing this schoolroom from another beyond, was a large tableau of wood painted black and varnished; a thick crayon of white chalk lay on my desk, for the convenience of elucidating any grammatical or verbal obscurity which might occur in my lessons, by writing it upon the tableau; a wet sponge appeared beside the chalk, to enable me to efface the marks when they had served the purpose intended.

zh: 我仔细并特意地做了这些观察才扫视了一遍坐在我眼前这些学生。　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　我拿了支粉笔，回头看了下黑板，又摸了摸那块海绵，以确认湿度是否合适，此时，我发觉自己足可冷静地抬起头，从容地环顾四周。
en: I carefully and deliberately made these observations before allowing myself to take one glance at the benches before me. Having handled the crayon, looked back at the tableau, fingered the sponge, in order to ascertain that it was in a right state of moisture, I found myself cool enough to admit of looking calmly up and gazing deliberately round me.

zh: 我先是发现勒泰小姐已然溜走了，到处都见不到她的身影。只有一位女管事，或者是教师——就是坐在和我同样高度台子上?的那位——独自留在这里观察我的表现。她呆在一个光线稍微昏暗的地方，因为我眼睛近视，所以只能看见她那瘦骨嶙峋的身材和苍白的脸色。她坐着时，完全是一副无精打采、装腔作势的神态。
en: And first I observd that Mdlle. Reuter had already glided away; she was nowhere visible.A maîtresse, or teacher—the one who occupied the corresponding estrade to my own—alone remained to keep guard over me.She was a little in the shade, and with my short sight I could only see that she was of a thin bony figure and rather tallowy complexion, and that her attitude, as she sat, partook equally of listlessness and affectation.

zh: 明亮的光线从宽大的玻璃窗射进来，我觉得更清晰、更显眼的还是坐在我眼前的学生们，她们中有些是十四、十五和十六岁的女孩子，有些则是十八（在我看来）到二十岁的少女。她们全都穿着最朴素的衣服，梳着最简单的发型；并且一个个都容貌姣好，脸色红润，笑逐颜开，大眼睛亮晶晶的，丰满的身材甚至显得有点结实。刚看过去我就忍受不了，就像禁欲主义者那样。我头昏目眩，眉眼低垂，用极低的声音嘟哝道——
en: More obvious, more prominent, shone on by the full light of the large window, were the occupants of the benches just before me, of whom some were girls of fourteen, fifteen, sixteen, some young women from eighteen (as it appeared to me) up to twenty.The most modest attire, the simplest fashion of wearing the hair, were apparent in all; and good features, ruddy, blooming complexions, large and brilliant eyes, forms full, even to solidity, seemed to abound.I did not bear the first view like a stoic.I was dazzled, my eyes fell, and in a voice somewhat too low I murmured,—

zh: “小姐们，请把听写本拿出来。”
en: ‘Prenez vos cahiers de dictée, mesdemoiselles.’

zh: 我命令珀莱先生的学生们把阅读课本拿出来时，语气可不这样。一阵沙沙声和拉开课桌的声音紧随其后，被掀起的课桌盖暂时挡住了一个个低下去掏练习本的脑袋，这时，我听见了她们的嘻笑声和低语声。
en: Not so had I bid the boys at Pelet’s take their reading-books.A rustle followed, and an opening of desks; behind the lifted lids which momentarily screened the heads bent down to search for exercise-books, I heard tittering and whispers.

zh: “厄拉利，我快笑抽了。”一个学生说。
en: ‘Eulalie, je suis prête à pâmer de rire,’ observed one.

zh: “他讲话的时候脸可真红啊！”
en: ‘Comme il a rougi en parlant!’

zh: “是啊，这真是个缺乏经验的人。”
en: ‘Oui, c’est un veritable blanc-bec.’

zh: “别说了，奥尔唐斯，他听见了。”
en: ‘Tais-toi, Hortense; il nous écoute.’

zh: 这时，课桌盖沉了下去，脑袋们重现了出来。我注意到三个窃窃私语的学生。在她们的脸庞消失了一会儿又重新出现的时候，我毫不顾忌地盯着她们看。她们几句不痛不痒的尖酸私语竟让我如此气愤，甚至让我鼓起勇气决心要治服她们。这太令人惊奇了。我觉得坐在面前的这些穿着黑长袍、梳着蓬松辫子像修女一般的年轻女孩们竟有几分天使的模样，连我自己也被这样的想法吓到了。刚才那低低的嗤笑和轻浮的私语，使我的头脑从那让人喜欢又感到压迫的幻想中得到了几分释放。
en: And now the lids sank and the heads reappeared.I had marked three, the whisperers, and I did not scruple to take a very steady look at them as they emerged from their temporary eclipse.It is astonishing what case and courage their little phrases of flippancy had given me.The idea by which I had been awed was that the youthful beings before me, with their dark nun-like robes and softly-braided hair, were a kind of half-angels.The light titter, the giddy whisper, had already in some measure relieved my mind of that fond and oppressive fancy.

zh: 我说的那三个学生就坐在前排，离讲台不到半码远的位置，她们可算是班上最具女性美的几位了。我是后来才知道她们的名字的，现在不妨提一下；她们是厄拉利、奥尔唐斯和卡罗琳。厄拉利是一个身材高挑，身形曼妙的女生。肌白如雪，容貌堪比这个低地国家的圣母玛利亚。跟我见过的荷兰画家笔下的许多少女画像十分相似。她的身材或脸上没有一丝棱角——非常圆润光滑；不管思考也好，哀伤也罢，亦或是生气和害羞，她的肤色总是那样白皙，那样剔透。丰满的胸脯随着均匀的呼吸高低起伏着，眼睛微微转动。只凭着这些生命的迹象，我就能分辨出她们并不是什么漂亮的人物蜡像，而是真真实实的人。奥尔唐斯中等个子，身材肥胖。她体形并不优雅，但脸庞却很迷人，比厄拉利的还要富有朝气和活力；一头深褐色的头发，脸上的表情也复杂多样。她的眼眼里透着一钟古灵精怪的淘气样。她或许还很坚毅、理智，但这些从她的相貌上完全看不出来。
en: The three I allude to were just in front, within half a yard of my estrade, and were among the most womanly-looking present.Their names I knew afterwards, and may as well mention now; they were Eulalie, Hortense, Caroline.Eulalie was tall, and very finely shaped.She was fair, and her features were those of a Low Country Madonna.Many a figure de Vierge have I seen in Dutch pictures exactly resembling hers.There were no angles in her shape or in her face—all was curve and roundness; neither thought, sentiment, nor passion disturbed by line or flush the equality of her pale, clear skin.Her noble bust heaved with her regular breathing, her eyes moved a little.By these evidences of life alone could I have distinguished her from some large handsome figure moulded in wax.Hortense was of middle size, and stout.Her form was ungraceful, her face striking, more alive and brilliant than Eulalie’s; her hair was dark brown, her complexion richly coloured.there were frolic and mischief in her eye.Consistency and good sense she might possess, but none of her features betokened those qualities.

zh: 卡罗琳显然已经发育成熟，但是身材却有点娇小。她的头发乌黑亮丽，双眼深邃幽黑，神情端庄无比，脸色是苍白的橄榄色，肌肤晶莹剔透，颈部周围也洁白如洗。在很多人眼里，这一切组合成了一个完美无瑕的美人。真不知道，她那苍白的皮肤和端庄的神情，怎么能引起人们感官欲望。我觉得那种感官欲望定然来自她的嘴唇和眼睛，所有见过她的人都无法否认她的魅力。现在她就已经如此性感，十年以后，肯定变得粗俗不堪，将来也一定会做不少傻事，这一点很明显地写在她脸上。
en: Caroline was little, though evidently full-grown.Raven-black hair, very dark eyes, absolutely regular features, with a colourless olive complexion, clear as to the face and sallow about the neck, formed in her that assemblage of points whose union many persons regard as the perfection of beauty.How, with the tintless pallor of her skin and the classic straightness of her lineaments, she managed to look sensual, I don’t know.I think her lips and eyes contrived the affair between them, and the result left no uncertainty on the beholder’s mind.She was sensual now, and in ten years’ time she would be coarse, promise plain was written in her face of much future folly.

zh: 如果说在看这些女孩们的时候我的眼神是毫无顾忌的，那么，她们的眼神可以说是近乎放肆了。厄拉利目不转睛地盯着我，看似被动，实是自信地等着我为她那高贵的魅力即兴赞叹一番。奥尔唐斯一边放肆地注视着我，一边咯咯地笑着。突然，她莽撞地对我说：
en: If I looked at these girls with little scruple, they looked at me with still less.Eulalie raised her unmoved eye to mine, and seemed to expect, passively but securely, an impromptu tribute to her majestic charms.Hortense regarded me boldly, and giggled at the same time, while she said, with an air of impudent freedom,—

zh: “先生，先给我们做点简单的听写吧。”
en: ‘Dictez-nous quelque chose de facile pour commencer, monsieur.’

zh: 卡罗琳甩了甩头，将遮在她那双黝黑滚圆的眼睛上的蓬松浓密又略显粗糙的卷发甩到一边。她的嘴巴张得像一个逃亡的黑奴的嘴巴那么大，两排整齐、洁白的牙齿显露无遗；接着，她向我投来了一个含情脉脉的微笑。就如同波利娜·伯吉斯那样美，却不如柳克丽丝·德波吉亚纯洁。卡罗琳出生贵族家庭。在我后来听闻她那贵族母亲的个性之后，我也就丝毫不讶异于她的早熟了。从我看到她们的第一眼开始，我就知道，这三位小姐肯定认为自己是学校的皇后，自己的魅力定能使其他同学黯然无光。还不到五分钟，她们就将自己的性格暴露在我眼前，在不到五分钟的时间里，我就横下心来决定用强硬的手腕让她们屈服于我。
en: Caroline shook her loose ringlets of abundant but somewhat coarse hair over her rolling black eyes.parting her lips, as full as those of a hot-blooded Maroon, she showed her- well-set teeth sparkling between them, and treated me at the same time to a smile de sa façon.Beautiful as Pauline Borghese, she looked at the moment scarcely purer than Lucrèce de Borgia.Caroline was of noble family.I heard her lady-mother’s character afterwards, and then I ceased to wonder at the precocious accomplishments of the daughter.These three, I at once saw, deemed themselves the queens of the school, and conceived that by their splendour they threw all the rest into the shade.In less than five minutes they had thus revealed to me their characters, and in less than five minutes I had buckled on a breast-plate of steely indifference, and let down a visor of impassable austerity.

zh: “拿起笔来开始听写，”我用一种冷漠而平淡的语气说道，就像跟朱尔·范德凯科夫那伙人讲话一样。
en: ‘Take your pens and commence writing,’ said I, in as dry and trite a voice as if I had been addressing only Jules Vanderkelkov and Co.

zh: 听写开始了。那三位美丽的女孩不停地打断我，尽是问些愚蠢的问题或说些没用的话；对有些问题，我默而不答，而另一些问题，也只是小声简洁地应付过去。
en: The dictée now commenced.My three belles interrupted me perpetually with little silly questions and uncalled-for remarks, to some of which I made no answer, and to others replied very quietly and briefly.

zh: “先生，英文里面有个句号加一个逗号用英语怎么说来着？”
en: ‘Comment dit-on point et virgule en anglais, monsieur?’

zh: “是分号，小姐。”
en: ‘Semi-colon, mademoiselle.’

zh: “分号?啊，真是太好笑了！”（咯咯的笑声。）
en: ‘Semi-collong?Ah, comme c‘est drôle!’ (Giggle.)

zh: “我的笔真是太难用——简直没办法写了！”
en: ‘J’ai une si mauvaise plume—impossible d’écrire!’

zh: “可是，先生——我跟不上您的节奏——您念得太快了。”
en: ‘Mais, monsieur—je ne sais pas suivre—vous allez si vite.’

zh: “我怎么一点也没听懂！”
en: ‘Je n’ai rien compris, moi!’

zh: 这时班里响起一阵嗡嗡声，那位教师第一次开了口，喊道——
en: Here a general murmur arose, and the teacher, opening her lips for the first time, ejaculated,—

zh: “小姐们，请安静！”
en: ‘Silence, mesdemoiselles!’

zh: 安静并没有到来。反而，前排的那三位小姐说得更大声了。
en: No silence followed; on the contrary, the three ladies in front began to talk more loudly.

zh: “学英语真是太难了！”
en: ‘C’est si difficile, l’anglais!’

zh: “我讨厌听写。”
en: ‘Je déteste la dictée.’

zh: “净是听写这些不懂的东西，真讨厌！”
en: ‘Quel ennui d’écrire quelque chose quc l’on ne comprend pas!’

zh: 坐在后排的几名学生笑了起来。混乱开始弥漫于教室。现在我必须采取些及时的措施了。
en: Some of those behind laughed.A degree of confusion began to pervade the class.It was necessary to take prompt measures.

zh: “把练习本拿给我，”我对厄拉利说道，语气相当严厉，在她还没有来得及递给我前，我就俯下身抓起她的本子。
en: ‘Donnez-moi votre cahier,’ said I to Eulalie in an abrupt tone; and bending over, I took it before she had time to give it.

zh: “还有你，小姐，把你的也拿给我，”随后，我又对坐在第一排的另一边的一位脸色苍白、相貌平平的姑娘说，语气比刚才缓和多了，我立刻就发现，她的外表是班上最丑陋的，上课却是最专心的。她起身走近我，大方而恭敬地行了一个屈膝礼后把练习本递给了我。我迅速地扫视了一下两人的听写。厄拉利的字模糊难辨，本子上也墨迹斑斑，满是粗心而犯的错误；西尔维（就是那个丑女孩的名字）则写得工工整整，没有一点不合情理的错误，只有些拼写错误。我镇定地大声地宣读了这两份听写练习，指出了其中的错误，然后，看着厄拉利。
en: ‘Et vous, mademoiselle; donnez-moi le votre,’ continued I, more mildly, addressing a little pale, plain-looking girl, who sat in the first row of the other division, and whom I had remarked as being at once the ugliest and the most attentive in the room.She rose up, walked over to me, and delivered her book with a grave, modest curtsy.I glanced over the two dictations.Eulalie’s was slurred, blotted, and full of silly mistakes; Sylvie’s (such was the name of the ugly little girl) was clearly written, it contained no error against sense, and but few faults of orthography.I coolly read aloud both exercises, marking the faults; then I looked at Eulalie.

zh: “真是丢人！”我说完便故意把她的本子撕成四片并将碎片扔给她，然后微笑着把练习本还给西尔薇，对她说——
en: ‘C’est honteux!’ said I, and I deliberately tore her dictation in four parts, and presented her with the fragments I returned Sylvie her book with a smile, saying,—

zh: “很好，我真为你感到骄傲。”
en: ‘C’est bien; je suis content de vous.’

zh: 西尔维看似镇定而开心。而厄拉利却鼓鼓得像只被斗得发怒的火鸡。不过她没有发作。第一排学生刚才那种自负和轻佻的神气不见了，取而代之的是默不作声和闷闷不乐。这种情形于我非常有利，接下来的课就会不受任何干扰地顺利进行了。
en: Sylvie looked calmly pleased.Eulalie swelled like an incensed turkey.But the mutiny was quelled.The conceited coquetry and futile flirtation of the first bench were exchanged for a taciturn sullenness, much more convenient to me, and the rest of my lesson passed without interruption.

zh: 这时，院子里钟声叮当，宣布是下课的时间了。我也听到了我们自己的钟声，随即，某一所公立大学的钟声也跟着响起来。教室的秩序瞬间消失。每个学生都站了起来。我急忙抓起我的帽子，向那位女老师点头致意了一下，赶在里面一帮学生蜂拥而出的高潮前，离开了教室；据我所知，里面还有大约一百名学生，我已经听到了她们起立时的嘈杂声。
en: A bell clanging out in the yard announced the moment for the cessation of school labours.I heard our own bell at the same time, and that of a certain public college immediately after.Order dissolved instantly.Up started every pupil.I hastened to seize my hat, bow to the maîtresse, and quit the room before the tide of externats should pour from the inner class, where I knew near a hundred were prisoned, and whose rising tumult I already heard.

zh: 我刚穿过大厅，来到走廊上，恰好勒泰小姐再次向我迎了上来。
en: I had scarcely crossed the hall and gained the corridor when Mdlle. Reuter came again upon me.

zh: “到这儿来坐会儿吧。”她说着打开走廊一侧房间的房门，刚才她就是从那里出来的。从那个精致的玻璃柜可以看出这是一个餐厅，玻璃柜里满是杯子和瓷器，构成了餐厅家具的一部分。我们刚一走进房间关上门，走读生们就把整个走廊挤得水泄不通，扯取着挂在木制衣架上的的斗篷、帽子和手提包。隔一段时间，就能听见一位女管事大声呵斥，竭尽全力地想要维持秩序，却无济于事。我也觉得这没有用。这帮粗野的学生根本不知道什么是纪律，亏得这所学校还被认为是布鲁塞尔管理最好的学校之一。
en: ‘Step in here a moment,’ said she, and she held open the door of the side room from whence she had issued on my arrival.It was a salle-Emanger, as appeared from the beaufet, and the armoire vitrée, filled with glass and china, which formed part of its furniture.Ere she had closed the door on me and herself, the corridor was already filled with day-pupils, tearing down their cloaks, bonnets, and cabas from the wooden pegs on which they were suspended.The shrill voice of a maîtresse was heard at intervals, vainly endeavouring to enforce some sort of order—vainly, I say. Discipline there was none in these rough ranks, and yet this was considered one of the best conducted schools in Brussels.

zh: “好了，你的第一堂课结束了。”勒泰小姐用极其镇静平淡的预期开口说道。虽然我上课的教室和她的房间仅仅隔着一堵墙，但她却好像对刚才的混乱毫不知情一样。
en: ‘Well, you have given your first lesson,’ began Mdlle. Reuter in the most calm, equable voice, as though quite unconscious of the chaos from which we were separated only by a single wall.

zh: “你满意学生的表现吗？或者说她们有没有任何行为使你恼怒？不必对我有丝毫隐瞒，请你完全相信我。”
en: ‘Were you satisfied with your pupils, or did any circumstance in their conduct give you cause for complaint?Conceal nothing from me; repose in me entire confidence.’

zh: 很高兴的是，我觉得我完全有能力管理好我的学生，无需任何人的帮助。一开始，学校里那种魅力，那种金色的光晕，让我有坠入迷雾的感觉，现在这都已经大大地消散了。我不能说女子寄宿学校的现实与之前那种模糊的想像有差别会让我感到心烦或丧气。我只是觉得受到了启发，被人逗乐了，所以，我觉得我没有任何理由向勒泰小姐抱怨，对于她的关心和信任，我抱以微笑。
en: Happily, I felt in myself complete power to manage my pupils without aid. The enchantment, the golden haze which had dazzled my perspicuity at first, had been a good deal dissipated.I cannot say I was chagrined or downcast by the contrast which the reality of a pensionnat de demoiselles presented to my vague ideal of the same community.I was only enlightened and amused; consequently, I felt in no disposition to complain to Mdlle. Reuter, and I received her considerate invitation to confidence with a smile.

zh: “非常感谢，小姐；一切都进展得很顺利。”
en: ‘A thousand thanks, mademoiselle; all has gone very smoothly.’

zh: 她看上去更多的是怀疑。
en: She looked more than doubtful.

zh: “那么第一排那三个女孩呢？”她说。
en: ‘Et les trois demoiselles du premier bane?’ said she.

zh: “啊！一切都会好起来的！”我回答道。勒泰小姐不再问我问题了。但她的眼睛——不大、不亮、不动人、也不愠怒，却充满狡黠、敏锐和实在的眼睛——显出一丝怀疑的神色。她的眼睛瞬间闪现出一道光芒，好像在说：“随你怎么守口如瓶吧，我并不指望你坦白。你想要隐瞒的事，我早就知道了。”
en: ‘Ah!tout va an mieux!’ was my answer, and Mdlle. Reuter ceased to question me; but her eye—not large, not brilliant, not melting, or kindling, but astute, penetrating, practical—showed she was even with me.It let out a momentary gleam, which said plainly, ‘Be as close as you like; I am not dependent on your candour.What you would conceal I already know.’

zh: 经过一番平静、不露痕迹的过渡之后，女校长的态度转变了。那种焦急关切的表情不见了，她开始聊起了天气和小镇，天南地北地侃起来，并客套式地问候起珀莱先生和珀莱夫人。我一一回答了她的所有问题。她一直拖延着谈话的时间，我也只好应和着。她坐了很久，谈了很多，并不时地转换话题；很显然，她这样纠缠我是有特别目的的。单凭她的谈话看不出来究竟，但从她的表情里我找到了一些线索，她的话不过都是些客套之语，眼睛却时不时地盯着我的脸看。她并不是正视着我，而是斜看过来，目光如此娴静和诡秘，但没有一次能过逃过我的眼睛。她急切地观察着我，我对她也毫不放松。很快我便发觉，她是在观察我的真实个性。她在探寻我性格中坚强、脆弱以及怪异之处。她一下用这种方法测试我，一下又用那种方法考验我，希望能够找到一条裂缝，一个漏洞，好趁机插足，将她有力的小脚踏在我的脖子上，成为主宰我天性的女主人。读者们，不要误解我的意思，她并非想在爱情上赢得优势，她那时渴望的只是政治家的权力。如今，我在她的学校里当了老师，她想知道她的智力在哪方面胜过我，她要用什么感情、什么方法才能领导我。
en: By a transition so quiet as to be scarcely perceptible, the directress’s manner changed.The anxious business air passed from her face, and she began chatting about the weather and the town, and asking in neighbourly wise after M. and Madame Pelet.I answered all her little questions.She prolonged her talk; I went on following its many little windings.She sat so long, said so much, varied so often the topics of discourse, that it was not difficult to perceive she had a particular aim in thus detaining me. Her mere words could have afforded no clue to this aim, but her countenance aided, while her lips uttered only affable commonplaces, her eyes reverted continually to my face.Her glances were not given in full, but out of the corners, so quietly, so stealthily, yet I think I lost not one.  I watched her as keenly as she watched me.I perceived soon that she was feeling after my real character.She was searching for salient points, and weak points, and eccentric points.She was applying now this test, now that, hoping in the end to find some chink, some niche where she could put in her little firm foot and stand upon my neck, mistress of my nature.Do not mistake me, reader—it was no amorous influence she wished to gain; at that time it was only the power of the politician to which she aspired.I was now installed as a professor in her establishment, and she wanted to know where her mind was superior to mine, by what feeling or opinion she could lead me.

zh: 我很享受这样的游戏，并不急着结束。有时，我给她一点的希望，说话语气就故意松软一点；等她以为自己占了上风，那敏锐的目光就变得明亮起来。引诱她一会后，我便沾沾自喜地突然改变语气，用精明、有力的语气结束一番对话；这时，她的脸又拉了下来。最后，一个仆人进来通知用餐。我们不得不结束这场心理战；到分开时，也没得出个胜负。即使勒泰小姐没有给我任何机会对她进行情感攻势，我也成功地拆穿她的一个个小阴谋。这场战斗不分胜负。走出房间时，我又一次伸出手来；她也把手给了我。那是一双纤小、白嫩的手，却冰凉无比！我直视着她的眼睛，她也不得不直视我。这场最后的较量于我不利。我的目光一碰上她的就退却了——她的目光还是那样稳重、温和和平静；这种目光令我大失所望。
en: I enjoyed the game much, and did not hasten its conclusion.Sometimes I gave her hopes, beginning a sentence rather weakly, when her shrewd eye would light up; she thought she had me.Having led her a little way, I delighted to turn round and finish with sound, hard sense, whereat her countenance would fall.At last a servant entered to announce dinner.The conflict being thus necessarily terminated, we parted without having gained any advantage on either side.Mdlle. Reuter had not even given me an opportunity of attacking her with feeling, and I had managed to baffle her little schemes of craft.It was a regular drawn battle.I again held out my hand when I left the room; she gave me hers.It was a small and white hand, but how cool!I met her eye, too, in full, obliging her to give me a straightforward look.This last test went against me.It left her as it found her—moderate, temperate, tranquil; me it disappointed.

zh: “我变得更明智了。”在返回珀莱先生家的路上我这样想着，“瞧这个小女人。她不正像小说家和浪漫作家笔下的那些妇女吗？要读懂诗歌和小说中描绘的女性性格，那就得思考，不管是善良还是邪恶的性格，那都是由情感塑造的。这就是一个标本，而且是一个最具理性、最可敬的标本，而且大部分由抽象的理性构成。连塔列朗那种毫无激情的人，都不可拿来跟佐蕾德·勒泰相提并论。”这就是我那时候的想法。后来我才发现，情感迟钝的人个性通常也比较鲜明。
en: ‘I am growing wiser,’ thought I, as I walked back to M. Pelet’s. ‘Look at this little woman.Is she like the women of novelists and romancers?To read of female character as depicted in poetry and fiction, one would think it was made up of sentiment, either for good or bad.Here is a specimen and a most sensible and respectable specimen too, whose staple ingredient is abstract reason.No Talleyrand was ever more passionless than Zoraïde Reuter.’ So I thought then.I found afterwards that blunt susceptibilities are very consistent with strong propensities.

zh: 第十一章
en: CHAPTER XI

zh: 我的确和那个圆滑的小政治家谈了很久，回到住处时发现晚饭已经进行到一半了。该校有一项老规矩，就是不允许用餐的时候迟到，要是有哪个佛兰芒仆人，在用汤完毕、准备开始享用第一道菜的时候才进门，珀莱先生定会当众教训他一番，并且不许他喝汤吃鱼，以示惩罚。可是现在这种情况发生在我身上。那位客气而偏心的绅士却只是摇了摇头。我坐下来，打开餐巾，开始做饭前祷告。这时，他客气地差遣仆人去厨房给我端来一盘胡萝卜菜羹（因为今天是素食日），还留了一块鳕鱼干给我，才让人把头盘菜撤走。吃完晚餐，男孩们一窝蜂地涌到外面去玩了。金特和范达姆（那两个仆人）当然跟在他们后面一起出去了。
en: I had indeed had a very long talk with the crafty little politician, and on regaining my quarters I found that dinner was half over.To be late at meals was against a standing rule of the establishment, and had it been one of the Flemish ushers who thus entered after the removal of the soup and the commencement of the first course, M. Pelet would probably have greeted him with a public rebuke, and would certainly have mulcted him both of soup and fish.As it was, that polite though partial gentleman only shook his head, and as I took my place, unrolled my napkin, and said my heretical grace to myself, he civilly dispatched a servant to the kitchen, to bring me a plate of purée aux carottes (for this was a maigre day), and before sending away the first course, reserved for me a portion of the stock fish of which it consisted.Dinner being over, the boys rushed out for their evening play.Kint and Vandam (the two ushers) of course followed them.

zh: 可怜的家伙们！要不是因为他们看上去如此笨拙，如此沉闷，对天上地下的一切事物如此不闻不问，那么，我会极其同情他们的，因为他们必须随时随地地围着那群粗鲁的孩子转。看完他们这样，再对比我自己，在回宿舍的路上我不禁觉得自己受到了特别的优待。我敢说，在宿舍里虽然谈不上什么欢乐，但至少还是不受约束的。今天晚上（过去也常有这样的情况），我还会得到进一步的优待。
en: Poor fellows! if they had not looked so very heavy, so very soulless, so very indifferent to all things in heaven above or in the earth beneath, I could have pitied them greatly for the obligation they were under to trail after those rough lads everywhere and at all times; even as it was, I felt disposed to scout myself as a privileged prig when I turned to ascend to my chamber, sure to find there, if not enjoyment, at least liberty; but this evening (as had often happened before) I was to be still further distinguished.

zh: “嘿，坏家伙！”我刚抬脚迈上一级台阶的时候，就听到身后珀莱先生的声音，“你要去哪儿？进餐厅来，我得教训你一下！”
en: ‘Eh bien, mauvais sujet!’ said the voice of M. Pelet behind me, as I set my foot on the first step of the stair, ‘où allez-vous?Venez à la salle-Emanger, que je vous gronde un peu.’

zh: “抱歉，先生，”我边说边跟在他身后进了他的私人客厅，“我晚上回来迟了。但这怪不得我啊。”
en: ‘I beg pardon, monsieur,’ said I, as I followed him to his private sitting-room, ‘for having returned so late.It was not my fault.’

zh: “那正是我想知道的，”珀莱先生边说边把我引进了那个舒适的客厅，客厅里的炭火烧得正旺，因为季节原因，炉子已经被搬走了。他按了下铃，叫了“两杯咖啡”，不一会我们就分别在炭火的两边坐了下来，颇有英国人的风格。我们中间放着一张小圆桌，上面有一个咖啡壶、一个糖罐和两只白色的大陶瓷杯。当珀莱先生娴熟地从一个盒子里抽出一支雪茄的时候，我又想起那两个在外面跟着孩子跑的看管，甚至现在我都还能听到他们为控制操场秩序而发出的嘶哑的喊声。
en: ‘That is just what I want to know,’ rejoined M. Pelet, as he ushered me into the comfortable parlour with a good wood-fire, for the stove had now been removed for the season.Having rung the bell he ordered ‘Coffee for two,’ and presently he and I were seated, almost in English comfort, one on each side of the hearth, a little round table between us, with a coffee-pot, a sugar-basin, and two large white china cups.While M. Pelet employed himself in choosing a cigar from a box, my thoughts reverted to the two outcast ushers, whose voices I could hear even now crying hoarsely for order in the playground.

zh: “照顾他们，真是件苦差事。”我说道。
en: ‘C’est une grande responsabilité, que la surveillance,’ observed I.

zh: “你说什么？”珀莱先生问。
en: ‘Plaît-il??’ dit M. Pelet.

zh: 我便表达了自己的想法，觉得范达姆先生和金特先生看管那群孩子有时肯定会有点劳累。
en: I remarked that I thought Messieurs Vandam and Kint must sometimes be a little fatigued with their labours.

zh: “两个狗娘养的——两个狗娘养的。”校长鄙夷地低声骂道。与此同时，我把一杯咖啡递给了他。
en: ‘Des bêtes de somme—des bêtes de somme,’ murmured scornfully the director.Meantime I offered him his cup of coffee.

zh: “小伙子，请便。”当我把两大块大陆方糖加进他的杯子时，他温和地对我说道。“现在跟我说说为什么会在勒泰小姐家呆那么久。我知道她的学校可是和我的学校同一时间放学，都是四点钟；但你回到家的时候已经超过五点了。“
en: ‘Servez-vous, mon garçon,’ said he blandly, when I had put a couple of huge lumps of Continental sugar into his cup.‘And now tell me why you stayed so long at Mdlle. Reuter’s.I know that lessons conclude, in her establishment as in mine, at four o’ clock, and when you returned it was past five.’

zh: “先生，小姐要和我谈话。”
en: ‘Mademoiselle wished to speak with me, monsieur.’

zh: “真的啊！那请问谈论的什么话题？”
en: ‘Indeed!On what subject, if one may ask?’

zh: “小姐谈的是些无关紧要的话题，先生。”
en: ‘Mademoiselle talked about nothing, monsieur.’

zh: “真是个好话题！她是在教室里，当着学生的面跟你谈的吗？”
en: ‘A fertile topic!And did she discourse thereon in the schoolroom, before the pupils?’

zh: “不是的。跟您一样，先生，她也请我进她的客厅去。”
en: ‘No.Like you, monsieur, she asked me to walk into her parlour.’

zh: “那么勒泰夫人——那个老保姆——我妈的八卦姐妹，当然也在啦？”
en: ‘And Madame Reuter—the old duenna—my mother’s gossip, was there, of course?’

zh: “她不在，先生。很荣幸，就我跟小姐单独在一起。”
en: ‘No, monsieur.I had the honour of being quite alone with mademoiselle.’

zh: “太有趣了——这真是。”珀莱先生微笑着说道，眼睛盯着炭火。
en: ‘C’est joli—cela,’ observed M. Pelet, and he smiled and looked into the fire.

zh: “但并不是你想的那样。”我郑重地小声说道。
en: ‘Honi soit qui mal y pense,’ murmured I significantly.

zh: “你知道——我对我那位可爱的邻居是有所了解的。”
en: ‘Je connais un peu ma petite voisine—voyez-vous.’

zh: “那样的话，先生一定能够帮我解开这个谜团，为什么小姐会让我在她的沙发前坐上整整一个小时，对着我喋喋不休，滔滔不绝地发表演说，而谈的又都是些微不足道的小事儿？”
en: ‘In that case, monsieur will be able to aid me in finding out what was mademoiselle’s reason for making me sit before her sofa one mortal hour, listening to the most copious and fluent dissertation on the merest frivolities.’

zh: “她在试探你的性格。”
en: ‘She was searching your character.’

zh: “我想也是，先生。”
en: ‘I thought so, monsieur.’

zh: “她发现你的弱点了吗？”
en: ‘Did she find out your weak point?’

zh: “我弱点是什么？”
en: ‘What is my weak point?’

zh: “什么，情绪不定呀。克利姆斯沃斯，任何一个女人，只要把箭插得足够深，最后总能找到你心中的那深不可测的情感源泉。”
en: ‘Why, the sentimental.Any woman sinking her shaft deep enough will at last reach a fathomless spring of sensibility in thy breast, Crimsworth.’

zh: 我顿时心中热血翻腾，随即便烧到脸上。
en: I felt the blood stir about my heart and rise warm to my cheek.

zh: “有的女人或许可以，先生。”
en: ‘Some women might, monsieur.’

zh: “勒泰小姐算不算呢？那么，跟我坦白说吧，我的孩子，她也还年轻，可能比你大几岁吧。不过你不正喜欢这样的吗，不但有母亲般的关爱，还有妻子般柔情？”
en: Is Mdlle. Reuter of the number?Come, speak frankly, mon fils; elle est encore jeune, plus âgée que toi peut-etre, mais juste assez pour unir la tendresse d'une petite maman à l’amour d’une épouse dévouée; n’est-ce pas que cela t’irait supérieurement?’

zh: “不，先生；我觉得妻子就应该是妻子，而不是半个母亲。”
en: ‘No, monsieur; I should like my wife to be my wife, and not half my mother.’

zh: “那么，她的年纪对你来说是不是稍大了点？”
en: ‘She is, then, a little too old for you?’

zh: “不，先生；要是她其他方面适合我的话，年龄绝对不是问题。”
en: ‘No, monsieur; not a day too old if she suited me in other things.’

zh: “她哪点不合你意呢，威廉？难道她本人不可爱吗？”
en: ‘In what does she not suit you, William?She is personally agreeable, is she not?’

zh: “非常可爱。我就是喜欢她那种的发型和面容；她的体态虽说有点像比利时人，却韵味十足。”
en: ‘Very.Her hair and complexion are just what I admire; and her turn of form, though quite Belgian, is full of grace.’

zh: “很好！那你觉得她的脸庞、相貌怎么样呢？“
en: ‘Bravo!And her face, her features—how do you like them?’

zh: “有一点严肃，特别是嘴巴。”
en: ‘A little harsh, especially her mouth.’

zh: “啊，是的！她的嘴巴，“珀莱先生兀自低声笑着说。“她的嘴很有个性——刚毅；可是笑容还是非常令人愉快的，你不觉得吗？“
en: ‘Ah, yes!her mouth,’ said M. Pelet, and he chuckled inwardly.‘There is character about her mouth—firmness; but she has a very pleasant smile; don’t you think so?’

zh: “相当狡黠。”
en: ‘Rather crafty.’

zh: “说得没错，但是那种狡黠的表情是由于眉毛的缘故。你留意过她的眉毛没？”
en: ‘True, but that expression of craft is owing to her eyebrows.Have you remarked her eyebrows?’

zh: 我回答说没有。
en: I answered that I had not.

zh: “那么，你没见过她低眉垂眼的样子？”他说。
en: ‘You have not seen her looking down, then?’ said he.

zh: “没有。”
en: ‘No.’

zh: “无论如何，她的眉毛太有趣了。仔细观察一下，当她做针线活或帮其他妇女打下手的时候，当她娴静地坐着，精神集中在手里的针和丝绸，同时还听着旁边人的讨论，这时候，你就可以发现她与众不同之处了。　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　她不参与。她那娇柔的心思全都放在手里的针线上；五官也很平静，不会微笑表示同意，也不会皱眉表示反对。双手勤快地做着那微不足道的活儿。对她来说，能绣好钱包或者做好帽子，就足够了。有哪位先生靠近她的话，她脸上的表情就会变得更加沉静，更加庄重，以掩盖她平时的仪态。这时注意观察她的眉毛，然后告诉我，是不是一边像猫，一边像狐狸？”
en: ‘It is a treat, notwithstanding.Observe her when she has some knitting, or some other woman’s work in hand, and sits the image of peace, calmly intent on her needles and her silk, some discussion meantime going on around her, in the course of which peculiarities of character are being developed or important interests canvassed.She takes no part in it.Her humble, feminine mind is wholly with her knitting; none of her features move, she neither presumes to smile approval nor frown disapprobation, her little hands assiduously ply their unpretending task.If she can only get this purse finished or this bonnet-grec completed, it is enough for her.If gentlemen approach her chair, a deeper quiescence, a meeker modesty settles on her features and clothes her general mien.Observe then her eyebrows, et dites-moi s’il n’y a pas du chat dans l’un et du renard dans l‘autre.’

zh: “下次有机会我一定好好瞧瞧。”我说。
en: ‘I will take careful notice the first opportunity,’ said I.

zh: “接着，”珀莱先生接着说，”她眼皮会跳跃，浅色的睫毛也跟着上扬。这时，一双蓝色的眼睛立马就从眼睑底下显露出来，向四周扫视一下又缩回去了。
en: ‘And then,’ continued M. Pelet, ’the eyelid will flicker, the light-coloured lashes he lifted a second, and a blue eye, glancing out from under the screen, will take its brief, sly, searching survey, and retreat again.

zh: 我微微笑了下，珀莱也笑了；片刻沉默以后，我问，——
en: I smiled and so did Peter, and after a few minutes’ silence, I asked,—

zh: “你觉得她会结婚吗？”
en: ‘Will she ever marry, do you think?’

zh: “当然会！鸟儿不也要配对吗？当然，她愿意也打算在找到合适的对象时就结婚，没有人比她更清楚自己可以给别人留下什么印象。没人比她更喜欢不动声色地俘获男人的心。克利姆斯沃思，如果她还没有悄悄地在你的内心留下足迹，那就是我误解她了。”
en: ‘Marry!Will birds pair?Of course it is both her intention and resolution to marry when she finds a suitable match, and no one is better aware than herself of the sort of impression she is capable of producing.No one likes better to captivate in a quiet way. I am mistaken if she will not yet leave the print of her stealing steps on thy heart, Crimsworth.’

zh: “她的足迹？搞错啦，才没有！我的心又不是让人随意行走的木板。”
en: ‘Of her steps?Confound it, no!My heart is not a plank to be walked on.’

zh: “但是天鹅爪子柔软的触摸并不会伤害它呀。”
en: ‘But the soft touch of a palate de velours will do it no harm.’

zh: “她的天鹅爪子可没伸向我。在我面前，她可是很矜持保守的。”
en: ‘She offers me no palate de velours.She is all form and reserve with me.’

zh: “一开始是这样的。让尊重为地基，感情为第一层楼，而爱则为上层建筑。勒泰小姐可是个技艺精湛的建筑师。”
en: ‘That to begin with.Let respect be the foundation, affection the first floor, love the superstructure.Mdlle. Reuter is a skilful architect.’

zh: “那兴趣，珀莱先生——兴趣。难道小姐不考虑这一点吗？”
en: ‘And interest, M. Pelet—interest.Will not mademoiselle consider that point?’

zh: “当然，当然要考虑了，这还用说。兴趣是粘合在两块石头之间的水泥。既然我们谈论完了女校长，那么学生呢？那些年轻的美人没有值得琢磨的吗？”
en: ‘Yes, yes, no doubt; it will he the cement between every stone.And now we have discussed the directness, what of the pupils?N’y-a-t-il pas de belles études parmi ces jeunes têtes?’

zh: “研究她们的性格？是啊。都是些奇怪家伙们，至少，我是这么觉得。不过第一次见面，还不能看出什么来。”
en: ‘Studies of character?Yes; curious ones, at least, I imagine; but one cannot divine much from a first interview.’

zh: “哎，真是缺乏判断力。那你现在告诉我，在那些貌美如花的年轻女孩子面前，你不觉得有点害羞吗？”
en: ‘Ah, you affect discretion; but tell me now, were you not a little abashed before those blooming young creatures?’

zh: “起先是有的；但当我冷静下来后，就容地应付过了。”
en: ‘At first, yes; but I rallied and got through with all due sang-froid.

zh: “我不相信。”
en: ‘I don’t believe you.’

zh: “可这无论如何是真的。开始我觉得她们像天使一样，但很快就发现这只是个幻觉。是班上那三个年龄最大、最漂亮的女生让我改变了之前的看法；她们的确聪明了得，以至于我在五分钟之内就看穿她们了，至少，我知道她们是什么样的人——三个彻头彻尾的风尘女子。”
en: ‘It is true, notwithstanding.At first I thought them angels, but they did not leave me long under that delusion.Three of the eldest and handsomest undertook the task of setting me right, and they managed so cleverly that in five minutes I knew them, at least, for what they were—three arrant coquettes.’

zh: “我知道她们！”珀莱先生叫道，“无论是在教堂里，或是公共场所，她们都艳压群芳。一个是高傲的金发美女，一个是漂亮的捣蛋鬼，一个是皮肤淡褐色的美人。”
en: ‘Je les connais!’ exclaimed M. Pelet. ‘Elles sont toujours au premier rang à l’église et a la promenade; une blonde superbe, une jolie espiegle, une belle brune.’

zh: “就是她们。”
en: ‘Exactly.’

zh: “她们都是可爱的小家伙——艺术家的宠儿。要是把她们聚在一起，该多么引人注目啊！厄拉利（我知道她们的名字）是一个有着柔顺的辫子、象牙般双眉的娴静女孩。奥尔唐斯一头深栗色的头发又是编又是拧的，好像她不知道该拿她那些浓密的头发怎么办；她嘴唇朱红，脸蛋粉嫩，眼睛调皮且带着笑意。而卡罗琳·布勒蒙！啊，真是个美人儿——无可挑剔的美人儿！黑色的鬈发像云朵一样飘散在这个天使般的脸蛋周围！多么迷人的嘴唇啊！多么高贵的黑眼睛啊！就连你们的拜伦也会对她顶礼膜拜的。可你——你这个冷漠的孤岛居民！——在这么精致可人的阿弗罗迪特面前，你怎么能无动于衷，视而不见呢？”
en: ‘Lovely creatures all of them—heads for artists.What a group they would make, taken together!Eulalie (I know their names), with her smooth braided hair and calm ivory brow.Hortense, with her rich chestnut locks, so luxuriantly knotted, plaited, twisted, as if she did not know how to dispose of all their abundance, with her vermilion lips, damask cheek, and roguish laughing eye. And Caroline de Blemont!Ah, there is beauty—beauty in perfection!What a cloud of sable curls about the face of a houri!What fascinating lips!What glorious black eyes!Your Byron would have worshipped her, and you—you cold, frigid islander!—you played the austere, the insensible in the presence of an Aphrodite so exquisite?’

zh: 要是我相信这位校长所说的话，那我定会耻笑他的热情。但我发现，他的语气里有一种狂喜的韵味。我明白他只是假装热情想让我卸下防备，好对他坦白，所以我连笑都没笑。他继续说道——
en: I might have laughed at the director’s enthusiasm had I believed it real, but there was something in his tone which indicated got-up raptures.I felt he was only affecting fervour in order to put me off my guard, to induce me to come out in return, so I scarcely even smiled.He went on,—

zh: “说实话，威廉——只是五官端正的佐蕾德·勒泰小姐和她那些貌美如花的学生比起来不是逊色很多吗？”
en: ‘Confess, William—do not the mere good looks of Zoraïde Reuter appear dowdyish and commonplace compared with the splendid charms of some of her pupils?’

zh: 这个问题真烦人，但我清楚地感到，校长努力（原因他内心最清楚——那时，我也想不通）想要激起我内心那与正确和高尚相异的想法和愿望。当他看到我丝毫不受他那邪恶煽动的影响时，接着说道——
en: The question discomposed me, but I now felt plainly that my principal was endeavouring (for reasons best known to himself—at that time I could not fathom them) to excite ideas and wishes in my mind alien to what was right and honourable.The iniquity of the instigation proved its antidote, and when he further added,—

zh: “这三个漂亮的女孩都会有一个美好的将来；只有像你这样低调、绅士和智慧的年轻人，才有可能成为三位中任何一位小姐和她钱包的主人。”
en: ‘Each of those three beautiful girls will have a handsome fortune; and with a little address, a gentlemanlike, intelligent young fellow like you might make himself master of the hand, heart, and purse of any one of the trio.’

zh: 我看了他一眼，用质疑的语气答道：“是吗，先生？”这让他吓了一跳。
en: I replied by a look and an interrogative ‘Monsieur?’ which startled him.

zh: 他勉强挤出一丝笑容，再次强调自己只是在开玩笑，并问我是不是把他的话当真了。就在这时钟声响了，娱乐时间结束了。这天晚上珀莱先生像往常一样要去朗读戏剧片段及情书给他的学生们听。他没等我回答就起身离开了房间，边走还边吟诵几句贝兰热的诗句。
en: He laughed a forced laugh, affirmed that he had only been joking, and demanded whether I could possibly have thought him in earnest.Just then the bell rang; the play-hour was over.It was an evening on which M. Pelet was accustomed to read passages from the drama and the belles lettres to his pupils.He did not wait for my answer, but rising, left the room, humming as he went some gay strain of Béranger’s.

zh: 第十二章
en: CHAPTER XII

zh: 我继续留在勒泰小姐的女子学院任教，日复一日，我发现了不少可以比较理想和现实的机会。在来布鲁塞尔之前，我对女性性格又了解多少呢？真是少之又少。女性性格对我又是一种什么样的概念呢？这一概念模糊、不牢靠、轻飘而耀眼。如今当我与它接触之后，我才发觉那是一种很明显的、实实在在的东西——有时也非常坚硬，通常又很沉重。里面注满了金属，有铅，也有铁。
en: Daily, as I continued my attendance at the seminary of Mdlle. Reuter, did I find fresh occasions to compare the ideal with the real.What had I known of female character previously to my arrival at Brussels?Precious little.And what was my notion of it?Something vague, slight, gauzy, glittering.Now when I came in contact with it I found it to be a palpable substance enough—very hard too sometimes, and often heavy.There was metal in it, both lead and iron.

zh: 让那些幻想着尘世天使和人间花朵的理想主义者及梦想家们到这里来看一下吧，而我则要打开文件夹，向他们展示一两幅用铅笔勾勒的素描。这些素描是我在勒泰小姐学校的二班教室里完成的，我从那收集了大概一百来件少女标本，种类繁多，题材不一。花色齐全，各个阶级、各个国籍都有。我坐在讲台上，扫视着那一长排桌子时，看到的是法国人、英国人、比利时人、奥地利人，还有普鲁士人。她们大多数来自资产阶级家庭，但也有不少女伯爵，有两位将军的女儿，还有几位是上校、上尉及政府办公人员的女儿。与这些小姐们并肩坐在一起的还有那些命中注定要当店铺老板女儿的年轻女子，以及该国一些真正的佛兰芒土著女子。在衣着打扮上她们几乎没什么区别，举手投足也相差无几。当然也有与众不同的；但这绝大多数人使学校的校风变得粗俗、喧闹，有个特征是：学生之间或者学生跟老师之间，直接全然不顾对方的忍耐力，各自急切地追求着各自的利益和便利，对别人的利益和便利通常漠视不理。　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　如果说谎能得到好处的话，大多数人都会明目张胆地撒谎。一有什么好处可谋，所有人都变得巧舌如簧；然而，一旦发现客气已不能带来什么利益时，立马就能驾轻就熟地转脸无情。公开的争吵在学生中间是很罕见的；但在人后嚼舌头和散布谣言的现象却是司空见惯的。学校规矩严禁亲密的友谊，女孩子之间互相关心，只不过是因为她们厌烦孤单寂寞，需要有人陪伴而已。所有人都被人怀疑在背后做了什么见不得人的坏事。而她们所做的防备措施更是数不胜数，让她们处于即便不是愚蠢，但也不是无知的境地。可为什么，这些已经年过十四岁的女孩几乎没有一个能够谦逊、大方地直视一个男子呢？她们对一个男子最普通的眼神的回应都是鲁莽的调情，或放荡、愚蠢的勾引。我完全不了解罗马天主教的秘密，也不盲信神学；但我怀疑，天主教国家女孩这么明显，这么普遍的早熟与不纯洁，即使不能从罗马教堂的教义中，也可以从其戒律中找到根源。我记录下了我的所见。这些姑娘们都出身于社会上受人尊崇的阶层。她们全都在精心呵护下长大，然而，很多人的思想却很堕落。对于她们大致的看法就这么多。接下来，我们看看一两副精挑细选的素描画像吧。
en: Let the idealists, the dreamers about earthly angels and human flowers, just look here while I open my portfolio and show them a sketch or two, pencilled after nature.I took these sketches in the second-class schoolroom of Mdlle. Reuter’s establishment, where about a hundred specimens of the genus jeune fille collected together offered a fertile variety of subject.A miscellaneous assortment they were, differing both in caste and country.As I sat on my estrade and glanced over the long range of desks, I had under my eye French, English, Belgians, Austrians, and Prussians.The majority belonged to the class bourgeois; but there were many countesses, there were the daughters of two generals, and of several colonels, captains, and government employes.These ladies sat side by side with young females destined to be demoiselles de magasins, and with some Flamandes, genuine aborigines of the country.In dress all were nearly similar, and in manners there was small difference; exceptions there were to the general rule, but the majority gave the tone to the establishment, and that tone was rough, boisterous, marked by a point-blank disregard of all forbearance towards each other or their teachers, an eager pursuit by each individual of her own interest and convenience, and a coarse indifference to the interest and convenience of every one else.Most of them could lie with audacity when it appeared advantageous to do so.All understood the art of speaking fair when a point was to be gained, and could with consummate skill and at a moment’s notice  the instant civility ceased to be profitable.Very little open quarrelling ever took place amongst them, but backbiting and talebearing were universal.Close friendships were forbidden by the rules of the school, and no one girl seemed to cultivate more regard for another than was just necessary to secure a companion when solitude would have been irksome.They were each and all supposed to have been reared in utter unconsciousness of vice.The precautions used to keep them ignorant, if not innocent, were innumerable.How was it, then, that scarcely one of those girls, having attained the age of fourteen, could look a man in the face with modesty and propriety?An air of bold, impudent flirtation, or a loose, silly leer, was sure to answer the most ordinary glance from a masculine eye.I know nothing of the arcana of the Roman Catholic religion, and I am not a bigot in matters of theology, but I suspect the root of this precocious impurity, so obvious, so general in Popish countries, is to be found in the discipline if not the doctrines of the Church of Rome.I record what I have seen.These girls belonged to what are called the respectable ranks of society.They had all been carefully brought up, yet was the mass of them mentally depraved.So much for the general view; now for one or two selected specimens.

zh: 第一幅画是奥里莉亚·科斯洛的全身像。她是一位德国小姐，或者更准确地说是一位德、俄混血儿。她今年十八岁，被送到布鲁塞尔来接受教育。她中等身材，体格壮硕，身长腿短，胸部虽未完全成型却很丰满，腰部被一件紧身胸衣残忍而不协调地包裹着；她的衣着是经过精心搭配的，一双大脚被硬塞进小靴子里；脑袋很小，头发被整齐地梳成辫子，上面还涂着发油和树胶以保持完美；她前额低平，一双极小的灰眼睛发出凶狠的光芒；样子有点像鞑靼人；鼻子扁平，颧骨突出；但总的来说，并不是非常难看，脸色也还可以。　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　这就是她的外貌。至于思想嘛，可以说无知到了令人可悲的地步，甚至连自己的母语——德语都写不好也说不好，法语更是一塌糊涂，还要学英语，真是太荒唐了。尽管她上学已十二年了，但由于她的各种练习无一例外都是叫一位同学帮她完成的，上课时又偷偷摸摸把课外书放在大腿上看，这就怪不得她进步的速度就像蜗牛爬行了。我不知道奥里莉亚的日常生活里有些什么习惯，因为我没有机会成天观察她。但从她的课桌、书本和考卷上看来，我应该说她是一个不修边幅，甚至是脏乱的女生。她的外套，就如我所说的，保持得很干净。而当我从她的凳子后面走过去时，会发现她的脖子由于没有清洗而灰灰的；头发因为抹了发胶与发油显得油乎乎的，让人都懒得伸手去触摸，更别说用手指去揉一揉了。奥里莉亚在班上表现得非常好，至少我在的时候是这样的。这可以被视为少女幼稚的标志吧。我进教室的那一刻，她正用胳膊肘推邻桌的同学，还沉浸于难以掩饰的笑声中。我在讲台上坐下后，她的眼光便锁住了我；看来她是下定决心要引起我的注意了，有可能的话，还想独霸我的注意力。为此，她用各种各样的目光对我展开攻势——孱弱的、挑衅的、诱惑的、嘲弄的。后来发现这种攻势对我完全不起作用——因为人们都对那些不请自来的东西不屑一顾——她不得不换一种手段，制造起噪音来。她一会叹息，一会呻吟，一会又发出难以用言语名状的声音。我在教室里巡视时，如果从她身边走过，她就会把脚伸出来碰我的脚。这时，如果我碰巧没发现她的诡计，让自己的靴子碰到她的靴子时，她就装出一副想笑又不敢笑的痉挛的样子；如果诡计被我识破且躲开了，她就会绷着脸愠怒地操着难听的低地德语，用蹩脚的法语低声骂我。
en: The first picture is a full length of Aurelia Koslow, a German fräulein,, or rather a half-breed between German and Russian.She is eighteen years of age, and has been sent to Brussels to finish her education.She is of middle size, stiffly made, body long, legs short, bust much developed but not compactly moulded, waist disproportionately compressed by an inhumanly braced corset, dress carefully arranged, large feet tortured into small bottines, head small, hair smoothed, braided, oiled, and gummed to perfection, very low forehead, very diminutive and vindictive gray eyes, somewhat Tartar features, rather flat nose, rather high cheekbones, yet the ensemble not positively ugly, tolerably good complexion.So much for person.As to mind—deplorably ignorant and ill-informed, incapable of writing or speaking correctly even German, her native tongue; a dunce in French, and her attempts at learning English a mere farce.Yet she has been at school twelve years; but as she invariably gets her exercises of every description done by a fellow-pupil, and reads her lessons off a book concealed in her lap, it is not wonderful that her progress has been so snail-like.I do not know what Aurelia’s daily habits of life are, because I have not the opportunity of observing her at all times; but from what I see of the state of her desk, books, and papers, I should say she is slovenly and even dirty.Her outward dress, as I have said, is well attended to; but in passing behind her bench, I have remarked that her neck is gray for want of washing, and her hair, so glossy with gum and grease, is not such as one feels tempted to pass the hand over, much less to run the fingers through.Aurelia’s conduct in class, at least when I am present, is something extraordinary, considered as an index of girlish innocence.The moment I enter the room, she nudges her next neighbour and indulges in a half-suppressed laugh.As I take my seat on the estrade, she fixes her eye on me; she seems resolved to attract and if possible monopolize my notice.To this end she launches at me all sorts of looks—languishing, provoking, leering, laughing.As I am found quite proof against this sort of artillery—for we scorn what, unasked, is lavishly offered—she has recourse to the expedient of making noises.Sometimes she sighs, sometimes groans, sometimes utters inarticulate sounds for which language has no name.If, in walking up the schoolroom, I pass near her, she puts out her foot that it may touch mine.If I do not happen to observe the manoeuvre, and my boot comes in contact with her brodequin, she affects to fall into convulsions of suppressed laughter; if I notice the snare and avoid it, she expresses her mortification in sullen muttering, where I hear myself abused in bad French, pronounced with an intolerable Low German accent.

zh: 科斯洛小姐不远处坐着另一位叫阿德尔·德朗萨尔的年轻女士。她是比利时人，个子有点矮，身形笨拙，腰身粗壮，脖子、四肢都短短的，脸色白里透红，五官端正，眉目分明，眼睛和头发都是淡褐色的，牙齿整洁，年纪十五岁多一点，但身材却丰满得像一个壮实的二十岁英国女子。这幅画像给出的不正是一位略微矮胖却样貌好看的少女吗？当我看着面前这些年轻的面孔，我的目光总会停留在阿德尔身上。她也好像总是凝神等着跟我的眼神交汇，而且时常能够成功。她长相非凡——那么年轻、稚嫩、有朝气，却又像蛇发女妖一般。前额上布有猜忌、愠怒和火爆的表情，目光含有凶狠的习性，嘴角露着嫉妒的、豹子般的狡诈。总体来说，她坐下时非常安静。她那庞大的身形看似弯不下来，那上窄下宽的脑袋也是如此——看上去就要从那短脖子上断开来一样。她的脸上只有两种表情——经常出现的是一种严峻、不满的皱眉的样子，有时会变成一种极其可恶而狡诈的微笑。同学们对她退避三舍，虽说那些学生有许多也很坏，但几乎没有谁能坏到她那个地步。
en: Nor far from Mdlle. Koslow sits another young lady, by name Adele Dronsart.This is a Belgian, rather low of stature, in form heavy, with broad waist, short neck and limbs, good red and white complexion, features well chiselled and regular, well-cut eyes of a dear brown colour, light brown hair, good teeth, age not much above fifteen, but as full grown as a stout young Englishwoman of twenty.This portrait gives the idea of a somewhat dumpy but good-looking damsel, does it not?Well, when I looked along the row of young heads, my eye generally stopped at this of Adele’s.Her gaze was ever waiting for mine, and it frequently succeeded in arresting it.She was an unnatural-looking being—so young, fresh, blooming, yet so Gorgon-like.Suspicion, sullen ill-temper were on her forehead, vicious propensities in her eve, envy and panther-like deceit about her mouth.In general she sat very still.Her massive shape looked as if it could not bend much, nor did her large head so broad at the base, so narrow towards the top—seem made to turn readily on her short neck.She had but two varieties of expression—the prevalent one a forbidding, dissatisfied scowl, varied sometimes by a most pernicious and perfidious smile.She was shunned by her fellow-pupils, for, bad as many of them were, few were as bad as she.

zh: 奥里莉亚与阿德尔都在二班的第一组。第二组由一位名叫朱安娜·特里斯塔的寄宿生领导。这位女孩是比利时与西班牙混血儿。她母亲是佛兰芒人，已经去世了，父亲是加泰罗尼亚商人，居住在某个不知名的群岛上；朱安娜就是在那儿出生的，后来被送到欧洲来求学。我真想知道，看到这个女孩的脑袋和脸孔还有谁敢收她作学生。她的头型和亚历山大六世的毫无二致。她极少有仁爱之心，对人也很少表现出崇敬、责任感和忠心；然而她又非常自尊、坚定、充满破坏力和战斗力。她脑袋的形状像阁楼一样，前额向内收缩，后脑勺又向外突出。虽然五官巨大而醒目，却很漂亮。她个性坚韧，脾气暴躁，脸色苍白、阴郁，头发和眼睛都是黑色的；身形消瘦、僵直，不过看上去比例很好，年龄是十五岁。
en: Aurelia and Adele were in the first division of the second class.The second division was headed by a pensionnaire named Juanna Trista.This girl was of mixed Belgian and Spanish origin.Her Flemish mother was dead, her Catalonian father was a merchant residing in the—Isles, where Juanna had been born, and whence she was sent to Europe to be educated.I wonder that any one, looking at that girl’s head and countenance, would have received her under their roof.She had precisely the same shape of skull as Pope Alexander the Sixth.Her organs of benevolence, veneration, conscientiousness, adhesiveness, were singularly small; those of self-esteem firmness, destructiveness, combativeness, preposterously large.Her head sloped up in the penthouse shape, was contracted about the forehead, and prominent behind.She had rather good though large and marked features.Her temperament was fibrous and bilious, her complexion pale and dark, hair and eyes black, form angular and rigid but proportionate, age fifteen.

zh: 朱安娜不算太瘦，却脸色憔悴，眼里满是凶狠贪婪的神色。尽管她的额头很窄，却有足够的空间能够清晰地刻下两个单词：叛逆和仇恨。从她其他的五官里——我觉得是眼睛——明显可以看出她的懦弱。特里斯塔小姐认为，粗俗的工作日式的暴乱比较适合用来扰乱我的第一堂课。她嘴巴里噪音阵阵，象一匹马一样，口水乱喷，尽说些粗野的话。坐在她身后的是一群粗俗、其貌不扬的佛兰芒人，这里面还有两三个残疾人和低能儿。她们在低地国家如此常见，似乎证明了那儿的气候不但让人类智力退化，还让人的身体产生畸形，真是太可怕了。不一会儿我就发现，这些佛兰芒人完全是受了她的影响，跟她一起掀起了杀猪一般的暴动，最后我无计可施，只能罚她和她的两个走卒起来站了五分钟，而后把她们赶出教室，骚乱才得以平息；那两个走卒被赶到教室隔壁的一个大厅，主犯则被单独反锁在一个小房间里，我做这些的时候勒泰小姐也在场。　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　　看我对付学生的果断样子，她都被吓呆了——她在学校里还从来没见过这么严厉的处罚手段。面对她的惊恐，我以冷静的表情回应她，而后又给了她一个微笑，这可能会显得有点奉承，但肯定让她放松不少。朱安娜·特里斯塔在欧洲的时间长得足够用狠毒和忘恩负义来回报所有对她好的人；后来，她去到某某群岛找她父亲了，一想到那儿有一群奴隶可以让她肆意打骂，她就兴奋得不得了。
en: Juanna was not very thin, but she had a gaunt visage, and her regard was fierce and hungry.Narrow as was her brow it presented space enough for the legible graving of two words, Mutiny and Hate.In some one of her other lineaments—I think the eye—cowardice had also its distinct cipher.Mdlle. Trista thought fit to trouble my first lessons with a coarse work-day sort of turbulence.She made noises with her mouth like a horse, she ejected her saliva, she uttered brutal expressions.Behind and below her were seated a band of very vulgar, inferior-looking Flamandes, including two or three examples of that deformity of person and imbecility of intellect whose frequency in the Low Countries would seem to furnish proof that the climate is such as to induce degeneracy of the human mind and body.These, I soon found, were completely under her influence, and with their aid she got up and sustained a swinish tumult, which I was constrained at last to quell by ordering her and two of her tools to rise from their seats, and, having kept them standing five minutes, turning them bodily out of the schoolroom the accomplices into a large place adjoining called the grande salle, the principal into a cabinet, of which I closed the door and pocketed the key.
