I wonder of what she deprived herself to scrape together the twenty francs.I wonder what sort of a place she has to live in, and what sort of a woman her aunt is, and whether she is likely to get employment to supply the place she has lost.No doubt she will have to trudge about long enough from school to school, to inquire here and apply there, she rejected in this place, disappointed in that.Many an evening she’ll go to her bed tired and unsuccessful.And the directress would not let her in to bid me good-bye?I might not have the chance of standing with her for a few minutes at a window in the schoolroom and exchanging some half-dozen of sentences—getting to know where she lived—putting matters in train for having all things arranged to my mind?No address on the note,’ I continued, drawing it again from the pocket-book and examining it on each side of the two leaves.‘Women are women that is certain, and always do business like women.Men mechanically put a date and address to their communications.And these five-franc pieces’ (I hauled them forth from my purse)—‘if she had offered me them herself instead of tying them up with a thread of green silk in a kind of Lilliputian packet, I could have thrust them back into her little hand, and shut up the small, taper fingers over them—so—and compelled her shame, her pride, her shyness, all to yield to a little bit of determined will.Now where is she?How can I get at her?’

zh: 我打开房间门，走到楼下的厨房。
en: Opening my chamber door, I walked down into the kitchen.

zh: “谁送这个包裹过来的？”我问那个递给我包裹的仆人。
en: ‘Who brought the packet?’ I asked of the servant who had delivered it to me.

zh: “一个小信差，先生。”
en: ‘Un petit commissionaire, monsieur.’

zh: “他说什么了吗？”
en: ‘Did he say anything?’

zh: “没有。”
en: ‘Rien.’

zh: 我便走回楼上，以便能好好思考这些事。
en: And I wended my way up the back stairs, wondrously the wiser for my inquiries.

zh: “没关系，”我再次关上房门自言自语道，“没关系，就算走遍布鲁塞尔我也要找到她。”
en: ‘No matter,’ said I to myself, as I again closed the door—‘no matter; I’ll seek her through Brussels.’

zh: 我真的这样做了。只要我有一小会的空闲时间，我便去找她，日复一日，找了四个星期。每逢周日我便整日地找她；我到大路上找，到林阴小道上找，到公园找；我到圣居迪勒教堂和圣雅克教堂找；到两所基督教礼拜堂找；到那两个专供德国人、法国人和英国人做礼拜的基督教堂找，我会在其中一个教堂遇见她，对此我从未怀疑过。我的所有找寻都是徒劳无功；我确定我会在那两个礼拜堂见到她，但这想法和我其他的估计一样，被事实证明是没有根据的。每当礼拜结束时，我便站在两个礼拜堂的门口，直到每个人都出来，我认真地审视着每件长袍盖住的苗条身姿，窥视着每个圆帽遮盖下的年轻脑袋。还是白费力气。我看着一个个少女走过我的身边，将她们的黑色披肩拉下来盖住倾斜的双肩，但是没有一个人有亨利小姐那样的气质和风度。我看着一张张苍白而又深思的脸蛋，配着褐色头发；但是我从来没有见到亨利小姐那样的前额，那样的双眼，那样的眉毛。我所见的所有的面部特征似乎都渐渐消失，因为我的眼睛没能找到我想要看到的特质——宽阔的眉间，大眼睛黝黑而严肃，以及眼睛上那线条分明的精致眉毛。
en: And I did. I sought her day by day, whenever I had a moment’s leisure, for four weeks.I sought her on Sundays all day long; I sought her on the boulevards, in the Allée Verte, in the Park; I sought her in St. Gudule and St. Jacques; I sought her in the two Protestant chapels; I attended these latter at the German, French, and English services, not doubting that I should meet her at one of them.All my researches were absolutely fruitless; my security on the last point was proved by the event to be equally groundless with my other calculations.I stood at the door of each chapel after the service, and waited till every individual had come out scrutinizing every gown draping a slender form, peering under every bonnet covering a young head.In vain.I saw girlish figures pass me, drawing their black scarfs over their sloping shoulders, but none of them had the exact turn and air of Mdlle. Henri’s. I saw pale and thoughtful faces encadrees in bands of brown hair, but I never found her forehead, her eyes, her eye- brows.All the features of all the faces I met seemed frittered away, because my eye failed to recognize the peculiarities it was bent upon—an ample space of brow and a large dark, and serious eye, with a fine but decided line of eyebrow traced above.

zh: “很有可能她已经离开布鲁塞尔了——也许她去英国了，因为她说过她会去。”我心里自语道，在第四个周日的下午，我离开了皇家礼拜堂的大门，刚转过身，看门人就关门上锁，我跟在最后一批信徒后面。现在他们在广场上渐渐散开了。很快我就超过了那一对对英国男女们。（天啊！他们就不能穿得好看点吗？我满眼尽是用名贵绸缎做成的镶着多层荷叶边的邋遢衣服，尽是绣着昂贵花边的不得体的大领子，尽是裁剪糟糕的外套和形状古怪的裤子；每个周日英国人做礼拜时，皇家礼拜堂唱诗班都穿这种衣服，祈祷结束后，他们又涌入广场，与那些匆匆赶来参观科堡大教堂的外国人清新整洁的打扮形成鲜明对比，实在是有损英国人的形象。）我超过了这一对对英国人，超过了一群群可爱的英国小孩，超过了一个个英国的男侍从和女仆人；我穿过了皇室住宅区，来到了国王大街，从那里拐进了卢汶街，一条古老寂静的街道。我感到有点饿，现在才想起摆在珀莱家餐桌上的茶点——小奶油面包和水——但是我又不想回去，于是走进一家面包店，要了一份充饥的couc——这是一个佛兰芒词，我不知道怎么拼它——是科林斯语加英语构成的，意思就是一种内有葡萄干的圆形甜面包——还有一杯咖啡；吃完后我又朝卢汶门慢慢走去。
en: ‘She has probably left Brussels—perhaps is gone to England, as she said she would,’ muttered I inwardly, as on the afternoon of the fourth Sunday I turned from the door of the chapel-royal, which the doorkeeper had just closed and locked, and followed in the wake of the last of the congregation, now dispersed and dispersing over the square.I had soon outwalked the couples of English gentlemen and ladies.(Gracious goodness!why don’t they dress better?My eye is yet filled with visions of the high-flounced, slovenly, and rumbled dresses in costly silk and satin, of the large unbecoming collars in expensive lace, of the ill-cut coats and strangely fashioned pantaloons which every Sunday, at the English service, filled the choirs of the chapel-royal, and after it issuing forth into the square, came into disadvantageous contrast with freshly and trimly attired foreign figures, hastening to attend salut at the church of Coburg.)I had passed these pairs of Britons, and the groups of pretty British children, and the British footmen and waiting-maids; I had crossed the Place Royale, and got into the Rue Royale; thence I had diverged into the Rue de Louvain, an old and quiet street.I remember that, feeling a little hungry, and not desiring to go back and take my share of the gouter, now on the refectory table at Pelet’s—to wit, pistolets and water—I stepped into a baker’s and refreshed myself on a couc—it is a Flemish word, I don’t know how to spell it—A Corinthe—anglice, a currant bun—and a cup of coffee; and then I strolled on towards the Porte de Louvain.

zh: 我很快便走出了市区，慢慢登着山，那山从城门外就开始向上倾斜了，我不慌不忙地登着；因为是下午，所以虽然多云，但仍很闷热，没有一丝风来让空气清新一下。布鲁塞尔居民无须走太远去寻求宁静，只要走到城外半里格，他就会发现这座城正静静地、茫然地凝望着广阔的田野沉思，环绕着布拉班特首都的田野虽然肥沃，但也很沉闷，放眼望去，没有树木，也没有道路。我登上山顶，驻足良久，俯瞰着那虽已开垦却了无生气的田野，顿时有一种想法，就是离开来时走的公路踏进那些耕地——它们如同布罗布丁纳格菜地的菜一样肥沃——耕地向前方延伸开来，遥远而宽阔，直到地平线，它的颜色也由深绿变成暗蓝，与暴雨之前的铅灰色天空融为一体；于是，我拐入了右边上的一条岔道。没走多久，这小道就正如我所预料的那样把我带进了农田，一座高耸且长的白墙立在我面前的农田之中，从墙上方露出的叶子可以猜出，里面是一些种植着茂密的紫杉和柏树的苗圃，因为那些搭在白色低矮围墙上的正是这两种树的树枝。这些树阴沉地环绕着一个无疑是矗立在围墙中央的巨大十字架，同时十字架展开的黑色大理石双臂又凌驾在那些不祥的树冠之上。我向前走去，想知道这个守卫森严的花园是谁家的；我转过墙角，心想该会看到庄严宏伟的住宅。我来到大铁门前。那边有一间用作门房的小屋；不过我不需要钥匙——大门是开着的。我推开一扇门——门上的铰链已经被雨腐蚀了，因而门转动时铰链发出阴沉的吱吱声。入口被浓密的植物遮蔽着。我穿过林阴大道，看到在左右两边到处刻着铭文和标志，这些清楚地告诉我自己来到了什么地方。这是个为所有活着的人准备的房间，那些十字架，墓碑还有石刻花圈都说明这里是“卢汶门外基督教公墓”。
en: Very soon I was out of the city, and slowly mounting the hill, which ascends from the gate, I took my time; for the afternoon, though cloudy, was very sultry, and not a breeze stirred to refresh the atmosphere.No inhabitant of Brussels need wander far to search for solitude; let him but move half a league from his own city, and he will find her brooding still and blank over the wide fields, so drear though so fertile, spread out treeless and trackless round the capital of Brabant.Having gained the summit of the hill, and having stood and looked long over the cultured but lifeless campaign, I felt a wish to quit the highroad, which I had hitherto followed, and get in among those tilled grounds—fertile as the beds of a Brobdignagian kitchen-garden—spreading far and wide even to the boundaries of the horizon, where from a dusk green distance changed them to a sullen blue, and confused their tints with those of the livid and thunderous-looking sky. Accordingly I turned up a by-path to the right.I had not followed it far ere it brought me, as I expected, into the fields, amidst which, just before me, stretched a long and lofty white wall enclosing, as it seemed from the foliage showing above, some thickly planted nursery of yew and cypress, for of that species were the branches resting on the pale parapets, and crowding gloomily about a massive cross, planted doubtless on a central eminence and extending its arms, which seemed of black marble, over the summits of those sinister trees.I approached, wondering to what house this well-protected garden appertained; I turned the angle of the wall, thinking to see some stately residence.I was close upon great iron gates.There was a hut serving for a lodge near; but I had no occasion to apply for the key—the gates were open.I pushed one leaf back—rain had rusted its hinges, for it groaned dolefully as they revolved.Thick planting embowered the entrance.Passing up the avenue, I saw objects on each hand which, in their own mute language of inscription and sign, explained clearly to what abode I had made my way. This was the house appointed for all living; crosses, monuments, and garlands of everlastings announced, ‘The Protestant Cemetery, outside the gate of Louvain.’

zh: 这个地方很大，即使不走回头路也足够在里面转上半个小时；而对于那些喜欢研究墓场年鉴的人来说，这些各种各样的碑文足够他花上两到三倍的时间去研究。这里埋葬着不同血统、不同语言、不同国家的人；在那一块块用石头、大理石或者青铜做成的墓碑上，分别用英语、法语、德语、拉丁语刻着那些长眠者的姓名、生卒年月、以及献给他们的最后歌颂或敬爱之词。这里有一个英国人在玛丽·史密斯或者简·布朗的遗体上竖了一个大理石墓碑，上面仅仅刻着她的名字。在那边一个法国鳏夫在他的爱弥尔或塞莱斯蒂纳的坟前堆满了绚丽的玫瑰花丛，花丛中立着的碑上写着同样绚丽的话语，作为对她诉说不尽的美德的见证。每个国家，每个部落，每个家族都以自己的方式哀悼死者，而所有哀悼都如此无声无息！尽管小路的起伏很流畅，我自己的步子也放得很慢，但是脚步声听起来仍触目惊心，因为它是墓场肃杀气氛的唯一破坏者，或者说，全部破坏者。那天下午像是达成共识一般，不只是风，就连一阵阵飘荡的气流都躲到各处睡觉了：北边一片肃静，南边一片沉静，东边十分安静，西边也不再低语，沉静了。天上的云像被挤压了，毫无光彩，但也显然一动不动。公墓的树下萦绕着一种闷热且令人窒息的阴暗，沉默的柏树冲破了这阴暗，笔直耸立着，阴暗上方的柳枝也纹丝不动低垂着；花儿们懒散无力，无精打采地等着夜露或者雷雨；只有那些树阴下的坟墓及其掩盖的长眠者们无动于衷地躺在那里，不理会是艳阳还是阴暗，是雨水还是干旱。
en: The place was large enough to afford half an hour’s strolling without the monotony of treading continually the same path; and for those who love to peruse the annals of graveyards here was variety of inscription enough to occupy the attention for double or treble that space of time.Hither people of many kindreds, tongues, and nations had brought their dead for interment; and here, on pages of stone, of marble, and of brass, were written names, dates, last tributes of pomp or love, in English, in French, in German, and Latin.Here the Englishman had erected a marble monument over the remains of his Mary Smith or Jane Brown, and inscribed it only with her name.There the French widower had shaded the grave of his Elmire or Celestine with a brilliant thicket of roses, amidst which a little tablet rising bore an equally bright testimony to her countless virtues.Every nation, tribe, and kindred mourned after its own fashion; and how soundless was the mourning of all!My own tread, though slow and upon smooth-rolled paths, seemed to startle, because it formed the sole break to a silence, otherwise total.Not only the winds but the very fitful, wandering airs, were that afternoon, as by common consent, all fallen asleep in their various quarters: the north was hushed, the south silent, the east sobbed not, nor did the west whisper.The clouds in heaven were condensed and dull, but apparently quite motionless.Under the trees of this cemetery nestled a warm, breathless gloom, out of which the cypresses stood up straight and mute, above which the willows hung low and still; where the flowers, as languid as fair, waited listless for night-dew or thunder-shower; where the tombs, and those they hid, lay impassible to sun or shadow, to rain or drought.

zh: 因为不愿再让自己的脚步声打破这宁静，我离开小道走上了草地，慢慢地向一片紫杉林迈进。我看见有个东西在林中晃动。我原以为那可能是一根断枝在摆动——我眼睛近视，没看清楚形状，只是感觉到它在动弹——但那黑黝黝的形状在林荫道的空旷处若隐若现。不久我便发现那个东西是有生命的，而且是个人。直到靠近点，我才发现是个女人在那里慢慢地走来走去，而且显然和我一样以为自己是一个人在这儿，也和我一样在这里沉思。不久她便回到一个座位上，我猜想她刚刚才从那边站起来，或者说我应该刚刚就看到她在那坐着了。那是在一个角落里，被一丛丛的树掩蔽着。她面前是那座白墙，靠墙竖立着一块小石碑，石碑底下的草地是刚翻过的——这是一座新坟。我带上眼镜，轻轻地贴着她身后走过，瞥了一眼石头上刻的字，写道：“朱利安娜·亨利，卒于布鲁塞尔，享年六十，一八几几年八月十日。”细读完这些碑文，我把目光转向弯腰坐在我眼前思索的身影，她竟然对我这个近在咫尺的生命体毫无感觉。那是一个身材修长，十分年轻的身影，身穿最普通的黑布孝服，头戴一顶小巧简单的黑色孝帽。我感觉到，也看出来那是谁了；我在那站了一阵，从头到脚一动不动，享受着这种认出她的喜悦。我已经找了她一个月，从没发现过她的一丝行踪，我以为没有任何希望任何机会再见到她了。仅仅是一个小时前，我已经被迫放弃希望了，已经无力地坠入了令人沮丧的念头：生活的洪流与命运的冲力已将她永远地卷离我的身边；但没想到，当我被消沉的意志压得低下头——就在我用目光寻找墓场草皮上的悲哀脚印之时——我却在这找到了我丢失的珍宝，它就落在用眼泪灌溉的草地上，倚在生满苔藓腐烂发霉的杉树根下。
en: Importuned by the sound of my own footsteps, I turned off upon the turf, and slowly advanced to a grove of yews.I saw something stir among the stems.I thought it might be a broken branch swinging—my short-sighted vision had caught no form, only a sense of motion—but the dusky shade passed on, appearing and disappearing at the openings in the avenue.I soon discerned it was a living thing, and a human thing.And drawing nearer, I perceived it was a woman, pacing slowly to and fro, and evidently deeming herself alone as I had deemed myself alone, and meditating as I had been meditating.Ere long she returned to a seat which I fancy she had but just quitted, or I should have caught sight of her before.It was in a nook, screened by a clump of trees.There was the white wall before her, and a little stone set up against the wall, and at the foot of the stone was an allotment of turf freshly turned up—a new- made grave.I put on my spectacles, and passed softly close behind her; glancing at the inscription on the stone, I read, ‘Julienne Henri, died at Brussels, aged sixty, August 10th, 18--.’Having perused the inscription, I looked down at the form sitting bent and thoughtful just under my eyes, unconscious of the vicinity of any living thing.It was a slim, youthful figure in mourning apparel of the plainest black stuff, with a little, simple black crape bonnet.I felt, as well as saw, who it was; and moving neither hand nor foot, I stood some moments enjoying the security of conviction.I had sought her for a month, and had never discovered one of her traces, never met a hope or seized a chance of encountering her anywhere.I had been forced to loosen my grasp on expectation, and, but an hour ago, had sunk slackly under the discouraging thought that the current of life and the impulse of destiny had swept her for ever from my reach; and, behold, while bending sullenly earthward beneath the pressure of despondency—while following with my eyes the track of sorrow on the turf of a graveyard—here was my lost jewel dropped on the tear-fed herbage, nestling in the mossy and mouldy roots of yew trees.

zh: 弗朗西斯十分安静地坐在那里，胳膊撑在膝盖上，手托着脸。我知道她会长时间坐在那一动不动，一直思考着问题。最终一滴泪水夺眶而出。她一直盯着面前石碑上的名字，内心无疑一直忍受着那种生者追忆故人时所感到的被遗弃的痛苦。泪水不停滚落，她用手帕擦了又擦，却悲伤地呜咽起来，最后在一阵伤心的痛哭后，她再次安静地坐在那。我轻轻地将手搭在她的肩膀上，没有必要让她多做准备，因为她既不会歇斯底里，也不会吓昏到不省人事。我猛地推她一下，确实会使她大吃一惊；但是正如我想象的那样，我静静地碰碰她，仅仅唤起了她的注意，尽管她快速转过脸来——尤其，在某些人看来像是闪电一样快——但是我相信，在她做出那个突然的动作之前，她的脑海里已经闪过究竟是什么人偷偷闯进她的孤独，甚至已经闪入她的心房，至少，在她没有因认出我而眼中闪着最富表情的亮光之前，这惊讶没有使她睁开眼睛来看我。在她整张脸上露出清晰、热情、最生动的喜悦前，她并没有因为紧张而显得吃惊不已。我几乎没时间观察她那憔悴苍白的神色，便看见她整个脸上都泛起强烈的喜悦的光芒，涌出片片红晕，焕发着光芒，没等我对此表示由衷的高兴，那红晕已经在我学生的脸上蔓延开了。这是沉闷的夏天阵雨之后露出的第一缕阳光，还有什么比这束阳光发展得更快呢，那简直是像炽烈燃烧的火焰！
en: Frances sat very quiet, her elbow on her knee and her head on her hand.I knew she could retain a thinking attitude a long time without change.At last a tear fell.She had been looking at the name on the stone before her, and her heart had no doubt endured one of those constrictions with which the desolate living, regretting the dead, are at times so sorely oppressed.Many tears rolled down, which she wiped away again and again with her handkerchief; some distressed sobs escaped her, and then, the paroxysm over, she sat quiet as before.I put my hand gently on her shoulder; no need further to prepare her, for she was neither hysterical nor liable to fainting fits.A sudden push, indeed, might have startled her, but the contact of my quiet touch merely woke attention as I wished; and though she turned quickly, yet so lightning-swift is thought—in some minds especially—I believe the wonder of what, the consciousness of who it was that thus stole unawares on her solitude, had passed through her brain and flashed into her heart even before she had effected that hasty movement; at least Amazement had hardly opened her eyes and raised them to mine ere Recognition informed their irids with most speaking brightness.Nervous surprise had hardly discomposed her features ere a sentiment of most vivid joy shone clear and warm on her whole countenance.I had hardly time to observe that she was wasted and pale, ere called to feet a responsive inward pleasure by the sense of most full and exquisite pleasure glowing in the animated flush, and shining in the expansive light, now diffused over my pupil’s face.It was the summer sun flashing out after the heavy summer shower; and what fertilizes more rapidly than that beam, burning almost like fire in its ardour?

zh: 我讨厌冒失——那种厚颜无耻的眉目传情和毫无情感的神经质的冒失；但是我喜欢坚强心灵的勇气，喜欢那种大方开朗的热情。我十分喜欢弗朗西斯·埃文斯那清澈的淡褐色眼睛毫不畏惧地直视我的眼睛时所闪烁的光芒。我喜欢她叫我时的声调：
en: I hate boldness—that boldness which is of the brassy brow and insensate nerves; but I love the courage of the strong heart, the favour of the generous blood.I loved with passion the light of Frances Evans’s clear haze eye when it did not fear to look straight into mine.I loved the tones with which she uttered the words,—

zh: “老师！老师！”
en: ‘Mon maître!mon maître!’

zh: 我喜欢此时此刻她把手放在我手里。我喜欢她站在那的模样，身无分文，无父无母，对于好色之徒来说她毫无魅力，但对我来说她就是块珍宝——她是我这个世界上最同情的人，她想我所想，感我所感；她是我储藏爱的理想圣地；她是谨慎与远见、勤勉与毅力、克己与自制的化身——我渴望将我的礼物交给她，交给这样一个值得信赖的人看管——那就是我的全部感情；她是诚实、忠贞、独立和责任感的典范，这些品质能够维持一种真正的生活；她默默地拥有一口深井，充满了温柔和激情，她和蔼宁静，纯洁超然，天生感情丰富而强烈——这些对组成一个美好家庭都是必要的，是温馨舒适的来源。我知道她心里的井是多么地平静而深邃；我知道那危险的火焰在她理智的目光下燃烧得多么安全；我曾见过当火焰产生的热量扰乱生命之河时，火焰会在瞬间窜高迸裂；我也曾见过理智战胜反抗，将火焰泯为灰烬。
en: I loved the movement with which she confided her hand to my hand.I loved her as she stood there, penniless and parentless; for a sensualist charmless, for me a treasure—my best object of sympathy on earth, thinking such thoughts as I thought, feeling such feelings as I felt; my ideal of the shrine in which to seal my stores of love; personification of discretion and forethought, of diligence and perseverance, of self-denial and self-control—those guardians, those trusty keepers of the gift I longed to confer on her—the gift of all my affections;model of truth and honour, of independence and conscientiousness—those refiners and sustainers of an honest life; silent possessor of a well of tenderness, of a flame, as genial as still, as pure as quenchless, of natural feeling, natural passion—those sources of refreshment and comfort to the sanctuary of home.I knew how quietly and how deeply the well bubbled in her heart; I knew how the more dangerous flame burned safely under the eye of reason; I had seen when the fire shot up a moment high and vivid, when the accelerated heat troubled life’s current in its channels; I had seen reason reduce the rebel, and humble its blaze to embers.

zh: 我对弗朗西斯·埃文斯有信心；我尊重她，当我挽着她的手臂带她走出那块墓地时，我有了另一种感情，如同信心一样强烈，同敬重一样坚定，又比两者都要热忱——那就是爱。
en: I had confidence in Frances Evans; I had respect for her, and as I drew her arm through mine and led her out of the cemetery, I felt I had another sentiment, as strong as confidence, as firm as respect, more fervid than either—that of love.

zh: “好了，我的学生，”当那发出刺耳声音的铁门在我们身后关上时，我说道：“这下，我又找到你了。我已经苦寻你一个月之久了，怎么也没想到我迷失的羔羊会在墓场里晃荡。”
en: ‘Well, my pupil,’ said I, as the ominous-sounding gate swung to behind us—‘well, I have found you again.A month’s search has seemed long, and I little thought to have discovered my lost sheep straying amongst graves.’

zh: 我以前都是称呼她“小姐”，而现在这样说话，对我们来说都是一种崭新的方式。她的回答让我知道她对这种方式并不生气也不反感。
en: Never had I addressed her but as ‘mademoiselle’ before, and to speak thus was to take up a tone new to both her and me.Her answer apprised me that this language ruffled none of her feelings, woke no discord in her heart.

zh: “老师，”她说，“您真的这么费心找我？我从没想过您会这么关心我的去留，但是被人从您身边赶走我确实很伤心。对那件事我真的很抱歉，更加沉重的打击本该使我忘记它，但我忘不了。”
en: ‘Mon maitre,’ she said, ‘have you troubled yourself to seek me?I little imagined you would think much of my absence, but I grieved bitterly to be taken away from you.I was sorry for that circumstance when heavier troubles ought to have made me forget it.’

zh: “你姑妈过世了？”
en: ‘Your aunt is dead?’

zh: “是的，两个星期前过世的。她离开的时候满心遗憾，但我不知道她的遗憾是什么。她生前的最后一个晚上还一直在重复说，‘弗朗西斯，我走了之后你该有多么孤单呐——无亲无友。’她也很希望自己能够葬在瑞士，当初是我劝她在花甲之年离开莱芒河畔，来到这地势平坦的法兰德斯地区的，但似乎只是叫她来送死。我多么想能满足她最后一个愿望，将她的遗体运回祖国，但那是不可能的。我只得把她葬在这。”
en: ‘Yes, a fortnight since, and she died full of regret, which I could not chase from her mind.She kept repeating, even during the last night of her existence, “Frances, you will be so lonely when I am gone—so friendless.”She wished, too, that she could have been buried in Switzerland, and it was I who persuaded her in her old age to leave the banks of Lake Leman, and to come only, as it seems, to die in this flat region of Flanders.Willingly would I have observed her last wish, and taken her remains back to our own country, but that was impossible.I was forced to lay her here.’

zh: “我猜她只病了很短一段时间吧？”
en: ’She was ill but a short time, I presume?’

zh: “只有三个星期。她生病之后，我向勒泰小姐请假回家照顾她陪伴她。她欣然地准了我的假。”
en: ‘But three weeks.When she began to sink I asked Mdlle. Reuter’s leave to stay with her and wait on her.I readily got leave.’

zh: “你还回学校吗？”我急忙问道。
en: ‘Do you return to the pensionnat?’ I demanded hastily.

zh: “先生，我在家住了一个星期之后，一天晚上在我刚把姑妈送上床勒泰小姐就来了。她走到姑妈房间跟她谈话，像往常一样极其彬彬有礼而又和善可亲；后来她出来跟我坐了很久，当她起身离开时她说道：‘小姐，你教你们班学生教得很好，这是事实，她们都很熟练地掌握了你所教授的手工课，所以没有必要再教她们了。尽管如此，我还是会在未来一段时间内对你的离开感到很遗憾。考虑到这些还年轻的学生们，我又找到一个老师来接替你的工作，虽然她的手艺确实不如你，但她会尽她所能，毫无疑问你将另寻高就。我确定，凭你的能力，随处都可以找到愿意聘用你的学校和家庭。’说完，她便付了我最后一个季度的薪水。我像一般小姐肯定都会想到的那样，很直率地问她是不是想把我赶出学校。她对我的粗俗话语笑了笑，回答说‘我们的雇佣关系已经解除，但是她希望仍能和我保持朋友的友好关系，她愿意随时把我当做朋友’，然后她便说了些路况很好，天气很晴朗之类的话，很开心地走了。”
en: ‘Monsieur, when I had been at home a week Mdlle. Reuter called one evening, just after I had got my aunt to bed. She went into her room to speak to her, and was extremely civil and affable, as she always is; afterwards she came and sat with me a long time, and just as she rose to go away she said, ‘Mademoiselle I shall not soon cease to regret your departure from my establishment, though indeed it is true that you have taught your class of pupils so well that they are all quite accomplished in the little works you manage so skilfully, and have not the slightest need of further instruction.My second teacher must in future supply your place, with regard to the younger pupils, as well as she can, though she is indeed an inferior artiste to you, and doubtless it will he your part now to assume a higher position in your calling.I am sure you will everywhere find schools and families willing to profit by your talents.” And then she paid me my last quarter’s salary.I asked, as mademoiselle would no doubt think, very bluntly, if she designed to discharge me from the establishment.She smiled at my inelegance of speech, and answered that “our connection as employer and employed was certainly dissolved, but that she hoped still to retain the pleasure of my acquaintance; she should always be happy to see me as a friend,” and then she said something about the excellent condition of the streets, and the long continuance of fine weather, and went away quite cheerful.’

zh: 我打从心底笑起来；这一切多么像校长啊——她的行为跟我所预料和猜测的极其相似，她撒谎的证据被弗朗西斯无意间揭露了。“她一直在询问亨利小姐的住址。”确实。“亨利小姐一直缄默不语，”等等，我才发现她竟然来这个她宣称一无所知的人家拜访过！
en: I laughed inwardly; all this was so like the directress—so like what I had expected and guessed of her conduct; and then the exposure and proof of her lie, unconsciously afforded by Frances.‘She had frequently applied for Mdlle. Henri’s address,’ forsooth.‘Mdlle. Henri had always evaded giving it,’ etc., etc., and here I found her a visitor at the very house of whose locality she had professed absolute ignorance!

zh: 我正想对我的学生所说的情况讲点什么，这时被哗哗啦啦的雨点打断了。豆大的雨滴打在我们脸上，落在小道上，嘀嘀咕咕地着预示远方马上有暴雨袭来。窒闷的空气和铅色的天空所发出的明显警告把我引上了返回布鲁塞尔的路，此刻我加快了脚步，同伴也加快了脚步，由于道路一直是下坡，我们走得很快。在真正的大雨来临前，之前的雨停了一会，我们趁机通过了卢汶门，又回到了城里。
en: Any comments I might have intended to make on my pupil’s communication were checked by the plashing of large rain-drops on our faces and on the path, and by the muttering of a distant but coming storm.The warning obvious in stagnant air and leaden sky had already induced me to take the road leading back to Brussels, and now I hastened my own steps and those of my companion, and as our way lay down hill, we got on rapidly.There was an interval after the fall of the first broad drops before heavy rain came on; in the meantime we had passed through the Porte de Louvain, and were again in the city.

zh: “你住在哪儿？”我问道，“我要将你安全送到家。”
en: ‘Where do you live?’ I asked.‘I will see you safe home.’

zh: “内日河畔圣母大街。”弗朗西斯回答道。
en: ‘Rue Notre Dame aux Neiges,’ answered Frances.

zh: 那里离卢汶大街不远，我们站到她家门前的台阶上时，乌云才被震耳的雷声划破，被刺眼的闪电撕碎，散开那铅色的皱痕，顷刻间，暴雨便如瀑布般倾泻而出。
en: It was not far from the Rue de Louvain, and we stood on the doorsteps of the house we sought ere the clouds, severing with loud peal and shattered cataract of lightning, emptied their livid folds in a torrent, heavy, prone, and broad.

zh: “进来吧！进来！”弗朗西斯走到屋里，见我没有跟上便喊道。她的话使我下定了决心。。我跨过门槛，将那闪电雷鸣的白茫茫暴雨关在门外，跟随她上楼来到她的房间。我们俩都没有被淋湿；门上方的一道房檐挡住了倾盆而下的大雨。我们的衣服上只沾了最初的几颗大雨点。如果再晚一分钟，我们浑身上下就不会有一块干的地方了。
en: ‘Come in!come in!’ said Frances, as, after putting her into the house, I paused ere I followed.The word decided me. I stepped across the threshold, shut the door on the rushing flashing, whitening storm, and followed her upstairs to her apartments.Neither she nor I was wet; a projection over the door had warded off the straight-descending flood.None but the first large drops had touched our garments.One minute more and we should not have had a dry thread on us.

zh: 踏过一小块绿色的羊毛垫子，我发现自己置身于一个小房间，油漆的地板中间是一块绿地毯。房间内家具很少，但都很明亮，并且极其干净；地方虽小，但摆设得井井有条——这种井然抚慰了我拘谨的心灵。我犹豫着是否要进她的房间，因为我想起了勒泰小姐的话，担心她家徒四壁，这样贸然闯入会使这位修补花边的小姐尴尬。这个地方也许很穷，或者真的很穷，但是它的整洁胜过了高贵，只要那干净的壁炉上有明亮的一小簇火焰在燃着，我就敢说它比宫殿更有魅力。然而室内没有生火，也没有放着要烧的木柴；这位补花边的小姐没有能力允许自己乱用钱，尤其是现在她唯一的亲人刚刚去世，手头很紧，又无人接济，她不得不自食其力。弗朗西斯到里屋脱下帽子，出来的时候浑然一个朴素又整洁的模特，身着合体的黑色素裙，准确地勾勒出她的酥胸与纤腰，纯白的领子向后翻卷，露出白皙姣好的脖颈，浓密的褐色头发整齐地由两鬓向后梳去，在后面编成一条希腊式的大辫子。她没有装饰品——既没有胸针、耳环，也没有丝带；没有那些，她一样打扮得很体面——那完美的体型，匀称的身段，优雅的姿态，都恰到好处地体现出来。她一回到这小客厅便找寻我的目光，此刻我正盯着壁炉看。看着那冰冷空荡的壁炉，我的心里涌起一阵怜惜之痛，我知道她立刻看出了我的心思。她理解得快，决定得快，行动得更快，她立马在腰间系上荷兰麻布围裙，走了出去，不一会拿着个篮子回来了；篮子有个盖，她打开盖子，拿出木柴和煤炭，熟练利索地将它们放入壁炉。
en: Stepping over a little mat of green wool, I found myself in a small room with a painted floor and a square of green carpet in the middle.The articles of furniture were few, but all bright and exquisitely clean; order reigned through its narrow limits—such order as it soothed my punctilious soul to behold.And I had hesitated to enter the abode, because I apprehended after all that Mdlle. Reuter’s hint about its extreme poverty might be too well founded, and I feared to embarrass the lace-mender by entering her lodgings unawares!Poor the place might be; poor truly it was; but its neatness was better than elegance, and had but a bright little fire shone on that clean hearth, I should have deemed it more attractive than a palace.No fire was there, however, and no fuel laid ready to light; the lace-mender was unable to allow herself that indulgence especially now when, deprived by death of her sole relative she had only her own unaided exertions to rely on.Frances went into an inner room to take off her bonnet, and she came out a model of frugal neatness, with her well- fitting black stuff dress, so accurately defining her elegant bust and taper waist, with her spotless white collar turned back from a fair and shapely neck, with her plenteous brown hair arranged in smooth bands on her temples, and in a large Grecian plait behind.Ornaments she had none—neither brooch, ring, nor ribbon; she did well enough without them—perfection of fit, proportion of form, grace of carriage, agreeably supplied their place.Her eye, as she re-entered the small sitting-room, instantly sought mine, which was just then lingering on the hearth.I knew she read at once the sort of inward ruth and pitying pain which the chill vacancy of that hearth stirred in my soul.Quick to penetrate, quick to determine, and quicker to put in practice, she had in a moment tied a holland apron round her waist; then she disappeared, and reappeared with a basket; it had a cover; she opened it, and produced wood and coal; deftly and compactly she arranged them in the grate.

zh: “她就剩那么一点，但是为了招待客人她会全部用上。”我想道。
en: ‘It is her whole stock, and she will exhaust it out of hospitality,’ thought I.

zh: “你要干什么？”我问道，“不会这么热的晚上还生火吧？我会被闷死的。”
en: ‘What are you going to do?’ I asked; ‘not surely to light a fire this hot evening?I shall be smothered.’

zh: “是的，先生，下雨了，我感到冷嗖嗖的。而且我还要生火泡茶，因为我周日都要喝茶的；只能委屈您忍受一下热了。”
en: ‘Indeed, monsieur, I feel it very chilly since the rain began.Besides, I must boil the water for my tea, for I take tea on Sundays; you will be obliged to try and bear the heat.’

zh: 她划着一根火柴，木柴便燃烧起来；说真的，与外面的黑暗和吵闹的大雨比起来，那壁炉上静静燃烧的火焰都变得很令人振奋了。某处传来一阵低沉的呜呜声，似乎除了我之外还有个生命对这个变化感到高兴：是一只黑猫，它正在一个铺着地毯的小脚凳旁睡觉，被火光惊醒，便跑了出来，用脑袋蹭着跪在那里的弗朗西斯的长袍。她抚摸着它，说它是她“可怜的朱莉安娜姑妈”的心头至爱。
en: She had struck a light; the wood was already in a blaze; and truly, when contrasted with the darkness, the wild tumult of the tempest without, that peaceful glow which began to beam on the now animated hearth seemed very cheering.A low, purring sound from some quarter announced that another being besides myself was pleased with the change: a black cat, roused by the light from its sleep on a little cushioned footstool, came and rubbed its head against Frances‘ gown as she knelt.She caressed it, saying it had been a favourite with her ‘pauvre tante Julienne.’

zh: 生起了火，打扫完壁炉，弗朗西斯把一个样式极为古老的小水壶放在红红的火焰上，那个小水壶我记得曾在英国的一些古老农舍见过。弗朗西斯洗过了手，又马上解下围裙。然后她打开壁橱拿出一个茶盘，不一会儿就在上面摆好了一套陶瓷茶具，茶具的式样、形状以及大小都极为古老；她又在每个小碟子里摆上一只老式银勺；在糖罐里又摆上同样老式的银钳子，接着又从壁橱里拿出一个鸡蛋大小的银质奶酪罐。在进行这一系列的准备时，她还间或抬起头来看看我，看出我眼里的好奇，便微笑着问道，——
en: The fire being lit, the hearth swept, and a small kettle of a very antique pattern, such as I thought I remembered to have seen in old farmhouses in England, placed over the now ruddy flame, Frances’ hands were washed, and her apron removed in an instant.Then she opened a cupboard, and took out a tea-tray, on which she had soon arranged a china tea-equipage, whose pattern, shape, and size denoted a remote antiquity; a little, old-fashioned silver spoon was deposited in each saucer; and a pair of silver tongs, equally old-fashioned, were laid on the sugar-basin; from the cupboard, too, was produced a tiny silver cream-ewer, not larger than an egg-shell.While making these preparations, she chanced to look up, and reading curiosity in my eyes, she smiled and asked,—

zh: “像是在英格兰吗，先生？”
en: ‘Is this like England, monsieur?’

zh: “像是在一百年前的英格兰，”我回答道。
en: ‘Like the England of a hundred years ago,’ I replied.

zh: “真的吗？这个茶盘上所有东西都有至少一百年的历史了。这些茶杯，这些勺子，还有这个罐子都是传家宝；我的曾祖母将它们传给我的祖母，我的祖母又传给我母亲，我母亲将它们从英格兰带到瑞士，然后传给我；从我是个小姑娘时起我就想将它们带回英格兰，回到它们的故乡去。”
en: ‘Is it truly?Well, everything on this tray is at least a hundred years old. These cups, these spoons, this ewer, are all heirlooms; my great-grandmother left them to my grandmother, she to my mother, and my mother brought them with her from England to Switzerland, and left them to me; and ever since I was a little girl I have thought I should like to carry them back to England, whence they came.’

zh: 她放了些奶油面包在桌上。她沏上茶，就像外国人那样沏茶——我是说，把一茶匙茶叶分到六个杯子里。她给我摆好一把椅子，我就座后，她不无得意地问道：
en: She put some pistolets on the table.She made the tea, as foreigners do make tea—that is, at the rate of a teaspoonful to half a dozen cups.She placed me a chair, and as I took it she asked, with a sort of exultation,—

zh: “会不会让你觉得现在是在家里？”
en: ‘Will it make you think yourself at home for a moment?’

zh: “如果我在英格兰有家，我相信我会有那种感觉。”我回答说。事实上，看着这位肤色白皙、长得像英格兰人的姑娘在做着英式茶点，又讲着英语，确实会有几分那种错觉。
en: ‘If I had a home in England, I believe it would recall it,’ I answered; and, in truth, there was a sort of illusion in seeing the fair-complexioned English-looking girl presiding at the English meal and speaking in the English language.

zh: “那您没有家了？”她问道。
en: ‘You have, then, no home?’ was her remark.

zh: “没有，也从来没有过。如果我有家的话，那一定要是我自己建立的家庭，但这个任务我还没开始做。”我说着这些话，一种从未经历过的刺痛穿过我的心。那是一种因为地位低下、金钱匮乏而感到羞辱的痛苦，伴随着这种痛苦，我也产生了一种强烈的欲望，那就是努力工作，努力多赚钱，出人头地，拥有更多；随着财富不断增多，我势必会渴望创建一个我从来没有过的家庭，娶到我心里暗暗发誓要娶的妻子。
en: ‘None, nor ever have had.If ever I possess a home, it must be of my own making, and the task is yet to begin.’ And as I spoke, a pang, new to me, shot across my heart.It was a pang of mortification at the humility of my position and the inadequacy of my means, while with that pang was born a strong desire to do more, earn more, be more, possess more; and in the increased possessions my roused and eager spirit panted to include the home I had never had, the wife I inwardly vowed to win.

zh: 弗朗西斯的茶比热水、糖水或者牛奶好不了多少，她的面包上也没有黄油，但我尝起来却觉得比吗哪还可口。
en: Frances’ tea was little better than hot water, sugar, and milk-, and her pistolets, with which she could not offer me butter, were sweet to my palate as manna.

zh: 用完餐，弗朗西斯洗完那些珍贵的茶盘和瓷器后又收了起来，本来就很光亮的桌子被她擦得更加光亮，“我朱莉安娜姑妈的小猫”特别享受了她端来的一盘食物。之后她又扫去壁炉上散落的炉渣和煤灰，终于坐了下来；当她拿过一把椅子和我面对面坐着时，我第一次看见她显露出一丝窘迫不安。这也不足为奇，因为我不自觉地过于专注地盯着她看，始终过于关注她的一举一动：因为她优雅熟练的动作迷住了我——那纤纤细手的每一个动作都那么灵巧利索，甚至富有艺术魅力；当她最终静静地坐下来时，她脸上所流露出的智慧对我来说简直美极了，于是我沉溺了。她的脸色非但没有因为沉默而镇定下来，反而更加兴奋，她的眼神还是有点悲伤，虽然我一直期待着她能够抬起眼帘好让我欣赏一下我喜爱的目光——在那种目光下，烈火能被温柔熄灭，锐气能被情感削弱，至少在此刻，欢乐能够玩弄思想——但是我的这个期待并没有得到满足，我最后才意识到这种失望很可能只怪我自己。要想打破这种她坐在那一动不动的僵局，我就不能再盯着她看，而要跟她说话。想起以前我对她所采用的那种权威式的语气在她身上往往能起舒缓作用，我对她说：
en: The repast over, and the treasured plate and porcelain being washed and put by, the bright table rubbed still brighter, ‘le chat de ma tante Julienne’ also being fed with provisions brought forth on a plate for its special use, a few stray cinders, and a scattering of ashes too, being swept from the hearth, Frances at last sat down; and then, as she took a chair opposite to me, she betrayed, for the first time, a little embarrassment.And no wonder, for indeed I had unconsciously watched her rather too closely, followed all her steps and all her movements a little too perseveringly with my eyes: for she mesmerized me by the grace and alertness of her action—by the deft, cleanly, and even decorative effect resulting from each touch of her slight and fine fingers; and when at last she subsided to stillness, the intelligence of her face seemed beauty to me, and I dwelt on it accordingly.Her colour, however, rising rather than settling with repose, and her eyes remaining downcast, though I kept waiting for the lids to be raised that I might drink a ray of the light I loved—a light where fire dissolved in softness, where affection tempered penetration, where, just now at least, pleasure played with thought—this expectation not being gratified, I began at last to suspect that I had probably myself to blame for the disappointment.I must cease gazing, and begin talking, if I wished to break the spell under which she now sat motionless.So recollecting the composing effect which an authoritative tone and manner had ever been wont to produce on her, I said,—

zh: “小姐，拿一本英语书出来，因为雨还下得很大，我可能还得再呆半个小时。”她一下子松了一口气，站起身拿了一本书，转身坐在我给她在我旁边安排的椅子上。她从古典文学书架上选了一本《失乐园》，我猜她觉得宗教性质的书最适合礼拜天读。我让她从头读起，当她读到弥尔顿向神圣的缪斯祈祷，缪斯曾在“神秘的奥勒布山或西奈山山顶”向一位希伯来牧羊人讲述世界的概念是怎样从混沌的状态中产生并且成熟的，我完全沉浸于三重享受之中：一是她在我的身边，二是听见她的嗓音——在我耳边那甜美悦耳的嗓音——，三是不时欣赏一下她的面孔。最后一种享受我是通过纠正她语调、顿号或者重音等方式达到的，只要我坚持自己的意见时我便盯着她看，但也不至让她羞红脸。
en: ‘Get one of your English books, mademoiselle; for the rain yet falls heavily, and will probably detain me half an hour longer.Released and set at ease, up she rose, got her book, and accepted at once the chair I placed for her at my side.She had selected ’Paradise Lost‘ from her shelf of classics, thinking, I suppose, the religious character of the book best adapted it to Sunday.I told her to begin at the beginning, and while she read Milton’s invocation to that heavenly muse, who on the ‘secret top of Oreb or of Sinai’ had taught the Hebrew shepherd how in the womb of chaos the conception of a world had originated and ripened, I enjoyed, undisturbed, the treble pleasure of having her near me, hearing the sound of her voice—a sound sweet and satisfying in my ear—and looking by intervals at her face.Of this last privilege I chiefly availed myself when I found fault with an intonation, a pause, or an emphasis; as long as I dogmatized I might also gaze, without exciting too warm a flush.

zh: “可以了，”当她读完六页左右我对她说（她读了很长时间，因为她读得很慢，还经常停下来问我问题，并听我给她讲解），“可以了；现在雨停了，我必须马上走了。”因为那时我朝窗外看，天空确实已经变蓝了。乌云已经四散开来，八月的夕阳透过窗格投入一束光芒，犹如红宝石上的反光。我站了起来，戴上了手套。
en: ‘Enough,’ said I, when she had gone through some half-dozen pages (a work of time with her, for she read slowly, and paused often to ask and receive information), ‘enough; and now the rain is ceasing, and I must soon go.’ For, indeed, at that moment, looking towards the window, I saw it all blue.The thunder-clouds were broken and scattered, and the setting August sun sent a gleam like the reflection of rubies through the lattice.I got up; I drew on my gloves.

zh: “你被勒泰小姐解雇后还没有找到适合的职位吧？”
en: ‘You have not yet found another situation to supply the place of that from which you were dismissed by Mdlle. Reuter?’

zh: “没有，先生。我到处都问过了，但是他们都向我要介绍信；说真话，我不想去找那个女校长，因为我觉得她对我所做的既不公正也不体面。她用阴险的手段教唆学生跟我对着干，让我在她那工作得很不愉快；她最终又用虚假伪善的手段解雇了我，还声称她那样做是为了我好，但是实际上是在关键时候断了我主要的生活来源，因为彼时不光我要生活，还有另外一个人的生活也在靠我维持。我不会再求她什么。”
en: ‘No, monsieur.I have made inquiries everywhere, but they all ask me for references; and to speak truth, I do not like to apply to the directress, because I consider she acted neither justly nor honourably towards me.She used underhand means to set my pupils against me, and thereby render me unhappy while I held my place in her establishment; and she eventually deprived me of it by a masked and hypocritical manÂ¦uvre, pretending that she was acting for my good, but really snatching from me my chief means of subsistence, at a crisis when not only my own life, but that of another, depended on my exertions.Of her I will never more ask a favour.’

zh: “那么你打算怎么办呢？你现在要怎么过活？”
en: ‘How, then, do you propose to get on?How do you live now?’

zh: “我还有一些修补花边的活，认真点还不至于饿死，而且我坚信只要我努力还是可以找到好一点的职位的。我才试着找了两个星期的工作，我的勇气和信心还没有枯竭。”
en: ‘I have still my lace-mending trade; with care it will keep me from starvation, and I doubt not by dint of exertion to get better employment yet. It is only a fortnight since I began to try; my courage or hopes are by no means worn out yet.’

zh: “如果你能找到工作，之后怎样呢？你的最终目标是什么呢？”
en: ‘And if you get what you wish, what then?What are your ultimate views?’

zh: “攒足够的钱，穿过英吉利海峡。我一直把英格兰当做我的乐土。”
en: ‘To save enough to cross the Channel.I always look to England as my Canaan.’

zh: “好的，好的，不久后我会再来看你，现在晚安了。”就这样我突然地离开了她。我费了很大力气才抵制住内心的强烈欲望，那种欲望促使我想要跟她告别时更温情些，更意味深长些。如果将她紧紧拥入怀中一阵，再在她脸蛋和额头上亲吻一下，那也是很自然吧？我并非不切实际，那就是我想要的全部。那样的话我就可以心满意足地走了。然而理智甚至连这一点也没有允许我。它命令我从她脸上收回目光，从她的房间走出去——像离开珀莱夫人那样冷淡无情地离开她。我服从了，但是我满怀恨意地发誓终有一天要报复。在这场抗争中，我宁死也要赢得想干什么就干什么的权利。现在在我前方有一个目标——就是要娶到那位日内瓦姑娘为妻，只要她对我这个老师的关心跟我对她的关心一样或者只有一半，那我就要娶她为妻。如果她不是那样关心我，那在我教她学习时她怎么会那么温顺，那样微笑而且那么开心呢？当我口授或者改错时，她为何那么安静，那么满足又那么愉快地坐在我身边？我之前说过，当我走进房间时，不管之前她的脸色多么地伤心或者多么地苦闷，只要我走到她的身边，跟对她说上几句话，给她一点指导，或者责备她几句，她都会立刻陷入幸福之中，平静又振奋地抬头看着我。我的责备在她那儿最适用。当我责怪她时，她总是拿着一把铅笔刀削着铅笔或者钢笔，烦躁不安地噘着嘴巴，不时简短地为自己辩解几句。每当我因为怕她把笔都削完而夺走她的钢笔或铅笔时，每当我为了活跃气氛而打断她的辩解时，她就会抬起眼睛，以一种特殊的眼神瞥向我，说真话，那甜蜜快乐又带有挑战性的一瞥令我激动不已——从来没有什么能让我这样激动——并使我稀里糊涂地（幸亏她不知道这一点）即便不做她的奴隶，也甘愿臣服于她。在这些小事之后她的精神会很高涨，常常长达几个小时，而且正如我之前说过的，她的身体从此吸收了能量与活力，在她姑妈去世和她被解雇之前，这种能量与活力几乎使她的躯体获得了新生。
en: ‘Well, well, ere long I shall pay you another visit, Good-evening now,’ and I left her rather abruptly.I had much ado to resist a strong inward impulse, urging me to take a warmer, a more expressive leave.What so natural as to fold her for a moment in a close embrace, to imprint one kiss on her cheek and forehead?I was not unreasonable; that was all I wanted.Satisfied in that point I could go away content.And Reason denied me even this.She ordered me to turn my eyes from her face and my steps from her apartment—to quit her as dryly and coldly as I would have quitted old Madame Pelet.I obeyed, but I swore rancorously to be avenged one day. I’ll earn a right to do as I please in this matter, or I’ll die in the contest.I have one object before me now—to get that Genevese girl for my wife; and my wife she shall be—that is, provided she has as much, or half as much, regard for her master as he has for her.And would she be so docile, so smiling, so happy under my instructions if she had not?Would she sit at my side, when I dictate or correct, with such a still, contented, halcyon mien? For I had ever remarked that, how- ever sad or harassed her countenance might be when I entered a room, yet after I had been near her, spoken to her a few words, given her some directions, uttered perhaps some reproofs, she would, all at once, nestle into a nook of happiness, and look up serene and revived.The reproofs suited her best of all.While I scolded she would chip away with her penknife at a pencil or a pen, fidgeting a little, pouting a little, defending herself by monosyllables; and when I deprived her of the pen or pencil, fearing it would be all cut away, and when I interdicted even the monosyllabic defence, for the purpose of working up the subdued excitement a little higher, she would at last raise her eyes and give me a certain glance, sweetened with gaiety, and pointed with defiance, which, to speak truth, thrilled me as nothing had ever done, and made me, in a fashion (though happily she did not know it), her subject, if not her slave.After such little scenes her spirits would maintain their flow, often for some hours, and, as, I remarked before, her health therefrom took a sustenance and vigour which, previously to the event of her aunt’s death and her dismissal, had almost recreated her whole frame.

zh: 上面的几句话我是花了好几分钟才写出来的，但这一切都是我在从弗朗西斯房间出来下楼梯的短暂时间里想出的。就在我打开前门时，忽然想起我还没有还她那二十法郎。我停住了——我不可能再拿着那些钱，但是要强行把它们物归原主也很难。我现在已经见到了她那简陋的住所，目睹了她贫困中的傲骨，有序中的傲气，以及对于保守传统的讲究挑剔，更了解了她小家的布局与节俭。我确定，如果我还给她这学费，她会感到痛苦的。我确定她不会接受任何人的恩惠，尤其是从我的手中。然而这四枚五法郎硬币对我的自尊心也是一种负担，我必须摆脱。我忽然想出一个权宜之计——毫无疑问，这是个笨办法，但却是我能想到的最好的。我冲到楼上，敲了敲门，装作很急地又进了她的房间：“小姐，我忘了一只手套。肯定是落在这儿了。”
en: It has taken me several minutes to write these last sentences; but I had thought all their purport during the brief interval of descending the stairs from Frances‘ room.Just as I was opening the outer door I remembered the twenty francs which I had not restored.I paused—impossible to carry them away with me, difficult to force them back on their original owner.I had now seen her in her own humble abode, witnessed the dignity of her poverty, the pride of order, the fastidious care of conservatism, obvious in the arrangement and economy of her little home.I was sure she would not suffer herself to be excused paying her debts.I was certain the favour of indemnity would be accepted from no hand, perhaps least of all from mine.Yet these four five-franc pieces were a burden to my self- respect, and I must get rid of them.An expedient—a clumsy one no doubt, but the best I could devise—suggested itself to me.I darted up the stairs, knocked, re-entered the room as if in haste,—‘Mademoiselle, I have forgotten one of my gloves.I must have left it here.’

zh: 她立即起身去找。在她转身的时候，我正站在壁炉旁悄悄地拿起一只小花瓶，把钱偷偷地溜进下面。那是一套瓷器装饰品中的一只，和那些茶杯一样古老，然后说道，“啊，我的手套在这！它掉到炉子围栏里了。晚安了，小姐，”我再一次离开了。
en: She instantly rose to seek it.As she turned her, back, I—being now at the hearth—noiselessly lifted a little vase, one of a set of china ornaments, as old-fashioned as the tea-cups slipped the money under it, then saying, ‘Oh, here is my glove!I had dropped it within the fender.Good-evening, mademoiselle,’ I made my second exit.

zh: 尽管这次即兴的回访很短，但却让我有时间去掉一块心病。我看到弗朗西斯已经将烧得发红的煤块从跳跃着的炉火夹了下来。迫于要计较每个铜板，才会在每处细节上省钱，所以我一离开她就熄了火，她认为一个人烧那么旺的火太奢侈了。
en: Brief as my impromptu return had been, it had afforded me time to pick up a heartache.I remarked that Frances had already removed the red embers of her cheerful little fire from the grate.Forced to calculate every item, to save in every detail, she had instantly on my departure retrenched a luxury too expensive, to be enjoyed alone.

zh: “还好不是冬天，”我暗想，“不过再过两个多月，十一月的风雨就要来袭了。如果在那之前我能有资格往那个炉子里上随意加煤该多好啊！”
en: ‘I am glad it is not yet winter,’ thought I; ‘but in two months more come the winds and rains of November.Would to God that before then I could earn the right and the power to shovel coals into that grate ad libitum!’

zh: 人行道已经快干了，芬芳清新的微风在被闪电净化后的空气中飘拂。我背西而行，此时西边的天空就像块蓝色的蛋白石，湛蓝中夹杂着一丝深红。夕阳仿佛被拉长了，整个天边都染上了泰尔红紫色，瑰丽辉煌。我向东边走去，面对着朵朵白云，在我面前出现一道彩虹——一道完美的彩虹，又高又宽，十分鲜艳。我久久地看着，双眼迷醉在这美景下，思绪也沉浸其中了；那天晚上，我躺在床上兴奋得难以入睡，注视着窗外悄无声息的成片闪电，云层逐渐散去了，它们却仍然在其间嬉戏，在整个星海上空洒下银辉。最后，我睡着了，在梦中又见到了那轮落日，那排彩云，那道浩瀚的彩虹。我觉得似乎站在一个高坡上。背倚一道护墙。身下是一道深不可测的深渊，但因为能听见波浪不停的拍打声，我猜那是大海——大海一直延伸到天际，海水的颜色由淡绿过渡成深蓝，远处的一切都很柔和，都陷入雾霭之中。突然水天的交接处出现一道金光，那金光慢慢浮起，靠近，扩大，变化；那道金光悬在天地之间，彩虹之下，柔和而暗沉的云朵在它后面散开。它像长了翅膀一般翱翔着，如珍珠般美丽、羊毛般柔软并闪闪发亮的气流霓裳一般披在身上；肉红色的光芒仿佛为它勾勒出面孔与四肢：一颗更富光泽的大星星在一位天使的额头闪烁，抬起的手臂和手掌像是一道光束，直指头顶的彩虹，一个声音在我心中低语：“希望在朝着努力微笑！”
en: Already the pavement was drying; a balmy and fresh breeze stirred the air, purified by lightning.I felt the west behind me, where spread a sky like opal; azure immingled with crimson.The enlarged sun, glorious in Tyrian tints, dipped his brim already.Stepping, as I was, eastward, I faced a vast bank of clouds, but also I had before me the arch of an evening rainbow—a perfect rainbow, high, wide, vivid.I looked long; my eye drank in the scene, and I suppose my brain must have absorbed it; for that night, after lying awake in pleasant fever a long time, watching the silent sheet-lightning, which still played among the retreating clouds, and flashed silvery over the stars. I at last fell asleep; and then in a dream were reproduced the setting sun, the bank of clouds, the mighty rain- bow.I stood, methought, on a terrace.I leaned over a parapeted wall.there was space below me, depth I could not fathom; but hearing an endless dash of waves, I believed it to be the sea—sea spread to the horizon, sea of changeful green and intense blue; all was soft in the distance, all vapour-veiled.A spark of gold glistened on the line between water and air, floated up, approached, enlarged, changed; the object hung midway between heaven and earth under the arch of the rainbow; the soft but dusk clouds diffused behind.It hovered as on wings; pearly, fleecy, gleaming air streamed like raiment round it; light, tinted with carnation, coloured what seemed face and limbs; a large star shone with still lustre on an angel’s forehead; an upraised arm and hand, glancing like a ray, pointed to the bow overhead, and a voice in my heart whispered, ‘Hope smiles on effort!’

zh: 第二十章
en: CHAPTER XX

zh: 我所需要的是丰厚的待遇；丰厚的待遇就是我现在的目标，我下定决心要得到的东西，但是它从来没像现在这样离我如此遥远。随着八月的来临，学年结束了，已经考完试，派发完奖金了，学校的人都已离开，所有学院和寄宿学校的大门都关闭了，一直到十月初或者中旬才会再次打开。八月的最后一天即将来临，我的地位怎么样了呢？从上个季度初到现在我向前迈进一步了吗？刚好相反，我向后退了一步。因为放弃了在勒泰小姐学校的英语老师工作，我就自动减去了自己每年二十英镑的收入，这样年收入就从每年六十英镑降到四十英镑，即使这个数目现在也很不稳定。
en: A competency was what I wanted; a competency it was now my aim and resolve to secure, but never had I been farther from the mark.With August the school year (l’année scolaire) closed, the examinations concluded, the prizes were adjudged, the schools dispersed, the gates of all colleges, the doors of all pensionnats shut, not to be reopened till the beginning or middle of October.The last day of August was at hand, and what was my position?Had I advanced a step since the commencement of the past quarter?On the contrary, I had receded one. By renouncing my engagement as English master in Mdlle. Reuter’s establishment I had voluntarily cut off £20 from my yearly income; I had diminished my £60 per annum to £40, and even that sum I now held by a very precarious tenure.

zh: 我已经有段时间没提过珀莱先生了。我想，那次月下散步是本故事中最后一次对这位绅士形象的显著描写了。事实上，自从那件事情之后我们之间交往的性质就有了变化。他还真不知道那个寂静的时刻，一轮毫无遮掩的皓月和一扇打开的格子窗已经向我暴露了他那自私的爱情和虚伪的友谊，所以他还像以前那么圆滑殷勤，但我已变得像一头豪猪一样浑身是刺，像一根带黑刺的短棍一样不屈不挠。对于他的逗趣我从来不笑，也一刻都不愿跟他多呆。他请我去他家客厅和他喝咖啡的邀请，无一不被我拒绝，而且拒绝得生硬坚决。过去他拿女校长打趣（现在也还是那么做），总会逗得我大乐，如今大不相同，我只会冷冷地静静听着。对我的冷漠行为，珀莱非常有耐心地忍受了很长一段时间。他甚至更加殷勤，但是当他发现对我礼貌到阿谀奉承的地步还是不能打动我、使我态度缓和时，他终于也改变了态度。轮到他对我冷淡了。他也不再邀请我，脸色变得多疑而阴沉。我从他眉宇间沉思困惑的样子看出，在不断的自我检查与比较之下，他还是急切地想尽力对所有事情得出一个解释性的结论。我想不久他就成功了，因为他并不缺乏洞察力，也许佐蕾德小姐也在帮助他解开这个难题。
en: It is some time since I made any reference to M. Pelet.The moonlight walk is, I think, the last incident recorded in this narrative where that gentleman cuts any conspicuous figure.The fact is, since that event a change had come over the spirit of our intercourse.He, indeed, ignorant that the still hour, a cloudless moon, and an open lattice had revealed to me the secret of his selfish love and false friendship, would have continued smooth and complaisant as ever; but I grew spiny as a porcupine and inflexible as a black- thorn cudgel.I never had a smile for his raillery, never a moment for his society.His invitations to take coffee with him in his parlour were invariably rejected, and very stiffly and sternly rejected too.His jesting allusions to the directress (which he still continued) were heard with a grim calm very different from the petulant pleasure they were formerly wont to excite.For a long time Pelet bore with my frigid demeanour very patiently.He even increased his attentions; but finding that even a cringing politeness failed to thaw or move me, he at last altered too.In his turn he cooled; his invitations ceased; his countenance became suspicious and overcast, and I read in the perplexed yet brooding aspect of his brow a constant examination and comparison of premises, and an anxious endeavour to draw thence some explanatory inference.Ere long, I fancy, he succeeded, for he was not without penetration; perhaps, too, Mdlle. Zoraïde might have aided him in the solution of the enigma.

zh: 不论怎样，我不久就发现他那疑心重重的举动已经消失了；他干脆放弃了对我友好热情的伪装，换上一副沉默不语的正经样子，但仍小心翼翼，彬彬有礼。这就是我想要在他身上达到的目的，如此一来，我又重新感到相对自在了。我实在不喜欢我在他家的位置。但是既然摆脱了假情假意和口是心非给我带来的烦恼，我还是能够忍受的，尤其是校长对我的过分仇视和嫉妒并没有扰乱我达观的心绪。我发现他并没有刺伤我的敏感处，伤口很快便彻底愈合了，只剩下对他一贯奸诈嘴脸的蔑视，也永远不再信任那只我查明了企图暗中刺伤我的手。
en: At any rate, I soon found that the uncertainty of doubt had vanished from his manner; renouncing all pretence of friendship and cordiality, he adopted a reserved, formal, but still scrupulously polite deportment.This was the point to which I had wished to bring him, and I was now again comparatively at my ease.I did not, it is true, like my position in his house.But being freed from the annoyance of false professions and double-dealing I could endure it, especially as no heroic sentiment of hatred or jealousy of the director distracted my philosophical soul.He had not, I found, wounded me in a very tender point, the wound was so soon and so radically healed, leaving only a sense of contempt for the treacherous fashion in which it had been inflicted, and a lasting mistrust of the hand which I had detected attempting to stab in the dark.

zh: 这种状态一直持续到七月中旬，然后发生了一点小变化。一天晚上珀莱比他以往晚回来一个小时，明显显得喝多了，这对他来说有点反常，因为如果他有着几样他的同胞们最坏的缺点，那至少他还保留着他们的一样美德——那就是，饮酒节制。然而这一次他却喝得烂醉如泥，他在大厅里疯狂地摇铃，惊动了整个学校（除了学生们，因为他们宿舍不在住宅楼，而在另一栋楼的教室上面，所以免受干扰），又叫仆人马上把午饭送过来——因为他以为当时是中午，实际上城市的午夜钟声刚刚敲过——他狂怒地斥责过仆人开饭不准时后，又跑去责骂他那可怜的老母亲；老太太劝他去睡觉，他却疯疯癫癫地大骂起“那个该死的英国人克里姆斯沃斯”来。当时我还没有睡觉，因为我手头有几本德语书，最近总是读到很晚。我听见楼下的骚动声，并辨出是校长在大喊大叫，声音异样而又十分骇人。我打开了一点门缝，听见他在叫人把“克里姆斯沃斯”给他带来，他要在大厅的桌子上割断他的喉咙，洗净他的人格。他断定克里姆斯沃斯的人格肮脏，带有可憎的英国血统。“他要不就是疯了，要不就是醉了，”我暗想，“无论哪种情况，那个老太太和仆人们都很需要一个男人的帮助。”于是我径直下楼来到大厅。我看见他步履蹒跚，眼珠快速地狂转着。他那半傻半疯的模样倒还挺有意思的。
en: This state of things continued till about the middle of July, and then there was a little change.Pelet came home one night, an hour after his usual time, in a state of unequivocal intoxication; a thing anomalous with him, for if he had some of the worst faults of his countrymen, he had also one at least of their virtues—that is, sobriety.So drunk, however, was he upon this occasion, that after having roused the whole establishment (except the pupils, whose dormitory, being over the classes in a building apart from the dwelling-house, was consequently out of the reach of disturbance) by violently ringing the hall bell and ordering lunch to be brought in immediately—for he imagined it was noon, whereas the city bells had just tolled midnight—after having furiously rated the servants for their want of punctuality, and gone near to chastise his poor old mother, who advised him to go to bed, he began raving dreadfully about ‘le maudit Anglais, Creemsvort.’ I had not yet retired; some German books I had got hold of had kept me up late.I heard the uproar below, and could distinguish the director’s voice exalted in a manner as appalling as it was unusual.Opening my door a little, I became aware of a demand on his part for ‘Creemsvort’ to be brought down to him, that he might cut his throat on the hall table and wash his honour, which he affirmed to be in a dirty condition, in infernal British blood.‘He is either mad or drunk,’ thought I, ‘and in either case the old woman and the servants will be the better of a man’s assistance;’ so I descended straight to the hall.I found him staggering about, his eyes in a fine frenzy rolling.A pretty sight he was—a just medium between the fool and the lunatic.

zh: “好了，珀莱先生，”我说道，“你还是去睡觉吧。”我抓住他的胳膊。他刚刚还在嚷嚷着要给我洗血，现在看见了我本人，又被我抓着，当然就更激动了。他挣扎着，对我愤怒地拳打脚踢。但是一个醉汉哪里打得过一个清醒的人；就算在正常状态下，珀莱那单薄的身躯也不可能与我健壮的体魄对抗。我将他扶上楼，又花了好长时间才把他弄上床。在这期间，他一直在嘟囔着一些话，尽管断断续续，但是有一定的含义；他骂我是一个背信弃义国家里的奸诈小人，同时又诅咒着佐蕾德·勒泰。他称她为“愚蠢的坏女人”，骂她是个水性杨花的烂货，堕落得一头钻进了无耻投机者的怀抱，最后那句“投机者”显然愤怒地将矛头间接转向了我。我把他放在床上安顿好，在这期间他不断地从床上弹起来；但直到我小心翼翼地用钥匙锁上他房间的门回到自己的房间，才确定他会在里面安安分分地睡到天亮，并能够不受影响地从刚刚目睹的情景中得出结论。
en: ‘Come, M. Pelet,’ said I, ‘you had better go to bed,’ and I took hold of his arm. His excitement, of course, increased greatly at sight and touch of the individual for whose blood he had been making application.He struggled and struck with fury.But a drunken man is no match for a sober one; and, even in his normal state, Pelet’s worn-out frame could not have stood against my sound one.I got him upstairs, and, in process of time, to bed.During the operation he did not fail to utter comminations which, though broken, had a sense in them; while stigmatizing me as the treacherous spawn of a perfidious country, he in the same breath anathematized Zoraïde Reuter.He termed her ‘femme sotte et vicieuse,’ who, in a fit of lewd caprice, had thrown herself away on an unprincipled adventurer, directing the point of the last appellation by a furious blow, obliquely aimed at me.I left him in the act of bounding elastically out of the bed into which I had tucked him; but as I took the precaution of turning the key in the door behind me, I retired to my own room, assured of his safe custody till the morning, and free to draw undisturbed conclusions from the scene I had just witnessed.

zh: 如今那位女校长正好被我的冷漠激怒，对我的轻蔑感到迷惑，又因怀疑我爱上另一个女人而深受刺激，此时她恰恰已经坠入她自己设置的圈套——她陷入了自己编织的情网，而她原本是想用那张网缠住我的。联想起那天在花园发生的事情，我从校长刚刚的表现可以推测出，他的情人泄露了她对他感情的疏远——或者我该说是意向的转移，感情这词在这里显得太过温情也太过纯洁——这使他发现她那空洞的心房中已没有了他，如今被他的职员占据着。当我发觉自己对此事有这样的想法时，不禁吃了一惊。珀莱拥有这样一所历史悠久的学校，是一位十分适宜又有利可图的佳偶——而佐蕾德是一个精于算计又很自私自利的女人——我很惊讶她心中纯粹的个人感情竟会在一时间压过世俗的利益。但是从珀莱所说的话中显然可以知道，她不但拒绝了他，还无意中说出了对我的偏爱。他的醉话里有一句是这样的，“那个女人看上了你的年轻，你这个没进化好的笨蛋，提到你那该死的英国礼节时还说你如贵族般风度翩翩，说你道德高尚——去你的吧！还说有卡顿那样的品质——笑话！”我想她的心态一定很古怪，尽管在那种心态之下她很自然地将财产和地位看得过重，但一个无财无权的下属对她的讽刺和轻蔑所产生的作用竟然远胜那位前途一片光明的校长的大肆奉承与殷勤。我暗暗地笑了笑；这也真是奇怪，尽管征服校长不合时宜地满足了我的自尊心，但我更美好的感情丝毫未被触动。次日，我见到了女校长，她借故和我在走廊上见了一面，她以一种如希洛人般谦卑的行为和表情想博得我的注意，可是我不能爱她，我甚至对她同情不起来。当她饶有兴趣地问及我的健康状况时，我所能做的只是简短而冷漠地回答几句，然后生硬地鞠了个躬离开。她那时的仪态和举止——在过去的很长一段时间也是这样——使我产生一种特别的印象。它们封锁了一切善的东西，引诱出我天性里一切恶的东西；有时它们能削弱我的感官，但却总是使我的心肠变得坚硬。我意识到它所造成的危害，内心也斗争过是否要改变。我素来痛恨专制之人；可是看，我也有了一个主动送上的奴隶，我本人也快要成为一个自己都憎恨的专制者了！在接受这位仍然年轻貌美的女崇拜者的赤裸裸地诱惑时，我心里有一种低贱的满足感，可就在享受这种乐趣时又有一种令人愤怒的堕落感。当她像个奴隶一样轻悄悄地走到我的身边，我立即会像个帕夏一样产生一种野蛮的肉欲。我有时忍受她的崇拜；有时又很排斥。我的冷淡和严肃却也同样地助长了我本想抑制的邪恶。
en: Now, it was precisely about this time that the directress, stung by my coldness, bewitched by my scorn, and excited by the preference she suspected me of cherishing for another, had fallen into a snare of her own laying—was herself caught in the meshes of the very passion with which she wished to entangle me.Conscious of the state of things in that quarter, I gathered, from the condition in which I saw my employer, that his ladylove had betrayed the alienation of her affections—inclinations, rather, I would say; affection is a word at once too warm and too pure for the subject—had let him see that the cavity of her hollow heart, emptied of his image, was now occupied by that of his usher.It was not without some surprise that I found myself obliged to entertain this view of the case.Pelet, with his old-established school, was so convenient, so profitable a match—Zoraïde was so calculating, so interested a woman—I wondered mere personal preference could, in her mind, have prevailed for a moment over worldly advantage.Yet it was evident from what Pelet said that not only had she repulsed him, but had even let slip expressions of partiality for me.One of his drunken exclamations was, ‘And the jade dotes on your youth, you raw blockhead, and talks of your noble deportment, as she calls your accursed English formality, and your pure morals, forsooth! des m¦urs de Caton a-t-elle dit—sotte!’Hers, I thought, must be a curious soul, where, in spite of a strong natural tendency to estimate unduly advantages of wealth and station, the sardonic disdain of a fortuneless subordinate had wrought a deeper impression than could he imprinted by the most flattering assiduities of a prosperous chef d’institution.I smiled inwardly; and, strange to say, though my amour propre was excited not disagreeably by the conquest, my better feelings remained untouched.Next day, when I saw the directress, and when she made an excuse to meet me in the corridor, and besought my notice by a demeanour and look subdued to Helot humility, I could not love, I could scarcely pity her.To answer briefly and dryly some interesting inquiry about my health, to pass her by with a stern bow, was all I could.Her presence and manner had then, and for some time previously and consequently, a singular effect upon me.They sealed up all that was good, elicited all that was noxious in my nature; sometimes they enervated my senses, but they always hardened my heart.I was aware of the detriment done, and quarrelled with myself for the change.I had ever hated a tyrant; and, behold, the possession of a slave, self-given, went near to transform me into what I abhorred!There was at once a sort of low gratification in receiving this luscious incense from an attractive and still young worshipper, and an irritating sense of degradation in the very experience of the pleasure.When she stole about me with the soft step of a slave, I felt at once barbarous and sensual as a pasha.I endured her homage sometimes; sometimes I rebuked it.My indifference or harshness served equally to increase the evil I desired to check.

zh: 有一次我无意听到她对她的母亲说：“他是多么地高傲啊！他高傲地微笑时就像太阳神阿波罗一样漂亮。“
en: ‘Que le lui sied bien!’ I once overheard her say to her mother.‘Il est beau comme Apollon quand il sourit de son air hautain.’

zh: 这位快乐的老夫人哈哈笑起来，说她觉得她的女儿着了魔；因为我除了品德端正、四肢健全之外，一点都不具备美男的特征。“在我看来，”她继续说道，“他戴上眼镜就像一只猫头鹰。”
en: And the jolly old dame laughed, and said she thought her daughter was bewitched; for I had no point of a handsome man about me, except being straight and without deformity.‘Pour moi,’ she continued, ‘il me fait tout l’effet d‘un chathuant, avec ses bésicles.’

zh: 多么可敬的老姑娘啊！如果她不是有点太老太胖、脸色又过于通红的话，我就会走过去亲亲她。与她女儿那病态的幻觉相比，她明智而真实的评价多么全面。
en: Worthy old girl!I could have gone and kissed her had she not been a little too old, too fat, and too red-faced.Her sensible, truthful words seemed so wholesome, contrasted with the morbid illusions of her daughter.

zh: 发酒疯的次日早晨，珀莱醒来，已经记不得前一天晚上发生的事情了，所幸她的母亲很谨慎，没有跟他说我亲眼目睹他出尽的洋相。他没有再借酒浇愁，但即使是清醒的，他也很快表现出那嫉妒的铁块已坠入了他的心灵。他是一个彻头彻尾的法国人，在他性格的各种构成要素中，法兰西民族的凶残特点绝对少不了。这种特点在他酒后的愤怒行为中第一次展现出来的，当时他对我个人充满仇恨的威胁体现了他恶魔似的本性，如今这种本性表现得较为隐蔽些，在他看到我时脸部肌肉会短暂地收缩，而当他的浅蓝色眼睛与我的相遇时便会闪耀着凶猛的光芒。他彻底避开了同我讲话，现在连假客气也一并省了。对于眼下我们之间的关系，我已经很厌烦，有时候几乎到了不可控制的地步，不想住在这间房子里，为这样一个人卖力；但是谁能挣脱环境的束缚呢？在那个时候，我不能。每天早晨起床我都想摆脱他的束缚，恨不得夹着我的皮箱离开这里，即便是当一个乞丐，至少也是自由的；晚上，当我从小姐的寄宿学校回来，就有一个愉快的声音回荡在我的耳边，一张机敏而又温顺、沉思而又温和的面孔出现在我的眼前，一个骄傲而又顺从、敏感而又聪慧、严肃而又热情的身影出现在我的脑海，一种热烈而又谦卑、高贵而又踏实、纯洁而又有力的情感使我的回忆既愉快又伤感——我能建起新的关系，承担新的义务，这使我不想再漂泊，再反叛，而应该用斯巴达人那样的品德去宽恕我所记恨的那些人。
en: When Pelet awoke on the morning after his frenzy fit, he retained no recollection of what had happened the previous night, and his mother fortunately had the discretion to refrain from informing him that I had been a witness of his degradation.He did not again have recourse to wine for curing his griefs, but even in his sober mood he soon showed that the iron of jealousy had entered into his soul.A thorough Frenchman, the national characteristic of ferocity had not been omitted by nature in compounding the ingredients of his character.It had appeared first in his access of drunken wrath when some of his demonstrations of hatred to my person were of a truly fiendish character, and now it was more covertly betrayed by momentary contractions of the features, and flashes of fierceness in his light blue eyes when their glance chanced to encounter mine.He absolutely avoided speaking to me; I was now spared even the falsehood of his politeness.In this state of our mutual relations my soul rebelled, sometimes almost ungovernably, against living in the house and discharging the service of such a man; but who is free from the constraint of circumstances?At that time I was not.I used to rise each morning eager to shake off his yoke, and go out with my portmanteau under my arm, if a beggar, at least a freeman; and in the evening, when I came back from the pensionnat de demoiselles, a certain pleasant voice in my ear; a certain face, so intelligent yet so docile, so reflective yet so soft, in my eyes; a certain cast of character, at once proud and pliant, sensitive and sagacious, serious and ardent, in my head; a certain tone of feeling, fervid and modest, refined and practical, pure and powerful, delighting and troubling my memory—visions of new ties I longed to contract, of new duties I longed to undertake, had taken the rover and the rebel out of me, and had shown endurance of my hated lot in the light of a Spartan virtue.

zh: 但是珀莱的愤怒已经平息，两个星期的时间足够它产生、发展，然后消亡。在那段时间隔壁学校解雇了一位讨厌的老师，同时我也下定决心追寻我的学生，由于女校长拒绝告诉我女学生的地址，我立刻辞掉了我在她学校的工作。我的最后一招似乎立即使得勒泰小姐恢复了理智。她的洞察力和判断力长期被蛊惑人的幻象误导着，当幻象消失时，它们立即又回到了正确的轨道。我所说的正确轨道并不意味着陡峭艰难的原则之路——她从来没踏上过那条路——而是常识的大路，在这条路上她最近偏离得很厉害。她在常识这条路上仔细搜寻着，终于发现并不遗余力地追求起她旧时的求婚者珀莱先生；不久她就征服了他。我不知道她用了什么手段去安慰、迷惑他，但是她的确成功缓和了他的愤怒，并蒙蔽了他的双眼，这一点不久就被珀莱仪表和态度上的变化所证明。她肯定使他相信我从前不是，现在也不是他的对手，因为两周来他针对我的狂怒以一种过分和平友好的方式结束了，其中还颇有一些沾沾自喜的成分，让我在感到恼怒之余，更觉可笑。珀莱的单身生活是以地道的法国方式度过的，即无视道德的约束，我想他的婚后生活肯定也会是非常法国式的。他经常向我吹嘘他的那些已婚的老朋友是多么地害怕他；我猜想现在他们不难以其人之道还治其人之身了。
en: But Pelet’s fury subsided; a fortnight sufficed for its rise, progress, and extinction.In that space of time the dismissal of the obnoxious teacher had been effected in the neighbouring house, and in the same interval I had declared my resolution to follow and find out my pupil, and upon my application for her address being refused I had summarily resigned my own post.This last act seemed at once to restore Mdlle. Reuter to her senses.Her sagacity, her judgment, so long misled by a fascinating delusion, struck again into the right track the moment that delusion vanished.By the right track I do not mean the steep and difficult path of principle—in that path she never trod—but the plain highway of common sense, from which she had of late widely diverged.When there she carefully sought, and having found, industriously pursued the trail of her old suitor, M. Pelet. She soon overtook him.What arts she employed to soothe and blind him I know not, but she succeeded both in allaying his wrath and hoodwinking his discernment, as was soon proved by the alteration in his mien and manner.She must have managed to convince him that I neither was nor ever had been a rival of his, for the fortnight of fury against me terminated in a fit of exceeding graciousness and amenity, not unmixed with a dash of exulting self-complacency, more ludicrous than irritating.Pelet’s bachelor life had been passed in proper French style with due disregard to moral restraint and I thought his married life promised to be very French also.He often boasted to me what a terror he had been to certain husbands of his acquaintance; I perceived it would not now be difficult to pay him back in his own coin.

zh: 变化仍在继续。刚一放暑假我便注意到珀莱家里开始忙起一些重要的事情。粉刷匠、打磨匠、家具商都立即开始工作，到处谈论着“夫人的卧室”、“夫人的客厅”。我想那位老女人不可能一下子身价倍增，居然让她儿子孝心大发，专门为她装修起房间来；我和厨师、两个女仆以及管厨房的人断定将有一位年轻的新夫人将要入住这座漂亮的房子了。
en: The crisis drew on. No sooner had the holidays commenced than note of preparation for some momentous event sounded all through the premises of Pelet.Painters, polishers, and upholsterers were immediately set to work, and there was talk of ‘la chambre de madame,’ ‘le salon de madame.’ Not deeming it probable that the old duenna at present graced with that title in our house had inspired her son with such enthusiasm of filial piety as to induce him to fit up apartments expressly for her use, I concluded, in common with the cook, the two housemaids, and the kitchen-scullion, that a new and more juvenile madame was destined to be the tenant of these gay chambers.

zh: 不久后，这件即将到来的大事便被正式公开了。再过一个星期，弗朗索瓦·珀莱校长先生将与佐蕾德·勒泰小姐喜结连理。校长先生亲自通知了我这件事，最后亲切地向我表示他希望我一如既往地继续做他最得力的助手和最信赖的朋友，还说要给我加工资，每年再加二十法郎。我谢过了他，当时没给他明确答复。他离开之后，我脱下衬衫穿上外套，向弗朗德尔门外走去，我走了很远，想以此来冷却我的血液，平静我的神经，好把凌乱的思想理出一个头绪。事实上，我刚刚所收到的根本就是解聘通知。我不能也不想对自己隐瞒这种想法，勒泰小姐现在已经注定会成为珀莱夫人，我继续住在这个即将属于她的房子里也不合适。现在她对我的态度既尊重又颇为得体，但是我知道她之前的感情并没有改变。如今感情被礼节压抑，被策略遮掩，但是时机一到一切都会化为乌有——诱惑可以让束缚战栗。
en: Presently official announcement of the coming event was put forth.In another week’s time M. François Pelet, directeur, and Mdlle. Zoraïde Reuter, directrice, were to be joined together in the bonds of matrimony.Monsieur, in person heralded the fact to me, terminating his communication by an obliging expression of his desire that I should continue, as heretofore, his ablest assistant and most trusted friend, and a proposition to raise my salary by an additional two hundred francs per annum.I thanked him, gave no conclusive answer at the time, and, when he had left me, threw off my blouse put on my coat, and set out on a long walk outside the Porte de Flandre, in order, as I thought, to cool my blood, calm my nerves, and shake my disarranged ideas into some order.In fact, I had just received what was virtually my dismissal.I could not conceal, I did not desire to conceal, from myself the conviction that, being now certain that Mdlle.Reuter was destined to become Madame Pelet, it would not do for me to remain a dependent dweller in the house which was soon to be hers.Her present demeanour towards me was deficient neither in dignity nor propriety; but I knew her former feeling was unchanged.Decorum now repressed, and policy masked it, but opportunity would be too strong for either of these—temptation would shiver their restraints.

zh: 我不是教皇——我不能自诩绝无过失：简而言之，如果我继续住下去，很可能头三个月就会在没有戒心的珀莱的屋檐下上演一部活色生香的现实版法国现代小说。然而，法国现代小说无论从实践上还是理论上都不对我的胃口。尽管我的人生经验还有限，但我还是有幸目睹了身边一个有趣而浪漫的家庭背叛实例。这个实例没有被小说里的金色光晕萦绕，我看见它赤裸而真切地暴露着，十分可憎。我看到一个机关算尽、惯于行骗的人是多么堕落，也看到一个身体慢慢被邪恶的灵魂侵蚀掉是多么腐败。我曾因被迫长时间注视这种景象而感到十分痛苦；但我现在并不后悔，因为这种简单的回忆是抵制诱惑最有效的解毒剂。这种痛苦在我的理性上刻下了这样的信条：靠侵犯别人的权利而获得的不正当快乐是虚幻且有毒的，它的空虚会在当时使人失望，它的毒素会在日后使人痛苦，它的后果就是使人永世堕落。
en: I was no pope—I could not boast infallibility: in short, if I stayed, the probability was that in three months’ time a practical modern French novel would be in full process of concoction under the roof of the unsuspecting Pelet.Now, modern French novels are not to my taste, either practically or theoretically.Limited as had yet been my experience of life, I had once had the opportunity of contemplating, near at hand, an example of the results produced by a course of interesting and romantic domestic treachery.No golden halo of fiction was about this example; I saw it bare and real, and it was very loathsome.I saw a mind degraded by the practice of mean subterfuge, by the habit of perfidious deception, and a body depraved by the infectious influence of the vice-polluted soul.I had suffered much from the forced and prolonged view of this spectacle; those sufferings I did not now regret, for their simple recollection acted as a most wholesome antidote to temptation.They had inscribed on my reason the conviction that unlawful pleasure, trenching on another’s rights, is delusive and envenomed pleasure; its hollowness disappoints at the time, its poison cruelly tortures afterwards, its effects deprave for ever.

zh: 从这一切我得出结论，那就是我必须离开珀莱家，而且立即离开。“但是，”谨慎告诉我，“你既不知道去哪也不知道怎么生存。”这时真爱之梦朝我走来。亨利小姐似乎是站在我这边，她的纤腰邀请我的手臂去拥抱，她的小手请求着我的大手去握住。我觉得她的手就是为了让我抓在手里而存在的；我既不能放弃我的权利，也永远不能避开她的眼神，在她眼里我看到了满满的幸福，看到了两心相印；我对她的表情有着很大的影响力，我能够在她体内燃起欢乐，灌注敬畏，搅动心底的愉悦，唤起闪光的灵魂，有时弄醒那令人愉快的恐惧。成功与富有的希望，工作与升迁的决心一个个站起来反对我，这里我几乎要坠入彻底贫困的深渊；“这一切，”我内心里一个声音说道，“都是因为你害怕一种可能根本不会发生的邪恶！”，“它会发生，你知道它会。”固执的良心回答说。“做你感觉是对的事吧。听我的话，即使陷入贫穷的泥潭中我也会让你站稳脚跟。”然后，当我快速地沿着这条路走时，内心里突然出现一个陌生的庞然大物，虽然看不见，但它是存在的。在它仁慈时，我只想到我的幸福安宁，但现在它却注视着我内心正与邪的斗争，等着看我是否会遵循它的话，听着我良心里的窃窃私语，或者偷听着我跟它共同的敌人——邪恶的幽灵——试图将我引上迷途。万能的理智给我暗示的是一条陡峭不平的上坡道，而下坡之路却长满青苔，沿着绿色的道路洒满了诱惑的鲜花；但是我想只要我鼓足勇气，勇敢地踏上崎岖的上坡道，那么身为万物之友的爱神将会极为满意地微笑；反过来说，一旦我踏上铺满天鹅绒的下坡，就会使得身为人神公敌的恶魔的眉角露出欣喜之情。我急忙转过身匆忙地往回跑；半个小时后我又回到了珀莱先生的家。在他的书房里我找到了他，简短的会谈、简单的解释便已足够，我的方式表明我已下定决心，也许他从心底里是赞同我的决定的。二十分钟的谈话后我又回到自己的房间，我就这样剥夺了自己的谋生手段，判决自己离开现在的家，简单地通知了他我会在一个星期之内找到地方搬走。
en: From all this resulted the conclusion that I must leave Pelet’s, and that instantly.‘But,’ said Prudence, ‘you know not where to go nor how to live.’ And then the dream of true love came over me.Frances Henri seemed to stand at my side, her slender waist to invite my arm, her hand to court my hand.I felt it was made to nestle in mine; I could not relinquish my right to it, nor could I withdraw my eyes for ever from hers, where I saw so much happiness, such a correspondence of heart with heart; over whose expression I had such influence; where I could kindle bliss, infuse awe, stir deep delight, rouse sparkling spirit, and sometimes waken pleasurable dread.My hopes to win and possess, my resolutions to work and rise rose in array against me; and here I was about to plunge into the gulf of absolute destitution; ‘and all this,’ suggested an inward voice, ‘because you fear an evil which may never happen!’ ‘It will happen; you know it will,’ answered that stubborn monitor Conscience.‘Do what you feel is right.Obey me, and even in the sloughs of want I will plant for you firm footing.’ And then, as I walked fast along the road there rose upon me a strange, inly-felt idea of some Great Being, unseen, but all-present, who in His beneficence desired only my welfare, and now watched the struggle of good and evil in my heart, and waited to see whether I should obey His voice, heard in the whispers of my conscience, or lend an ear to the sophisms by which His enemy and mine, the Spirit of Evil, sought to lead me astray.Rough and steep was the path indicated by divine suggestion, mossy and declining the green way along which temptation strewed flowers; but whereas, methought, the Deity of Love, the Friend of all that exists, would smile well pleased were I to gird up my loins and address myself to the rude ascent, so, on the other hand, each inclination to the velvet declivity seemed to kindle a gleam of triumph on the brow of the man- hating, God-defying demon.Sharp and short I turned round, fast I retraced my steps; in half an hour I was again at M. Pelet’s. I sought him in his study; brief parley, concise explanation sufficed; my manner proved that I was resolved; he, perhaps, at heart approved my decision.After twenty minutes’ conversation I re-entered my own room, self-deprived of the means of living, self-sentenced to leave my present home, with the short notice of a week in which to provide another.

zh: 第二十一章
en: CHAPTER XXI

zh: 我刚关上门就看见桌子上摆了两封信。我先想到的是我某个学生的朋友寄过来的邀请信。我过去偶尔收到过这类邀请信，对于我这种没有朋友的人，根本不会有更为重要的信件。自我来到布鲁塞尔，邮差的到来从来就不关我的事。我毫不在意地将手放在信上，冷淡而缓慢地看着它们，准备撕信封。忽然我的眼睛和手都停住了，我明白是什么让我激动了，那就像是我本以为只是白纸一张，结果却看到了一副鲜艳的图画。一个信封上是英国邮戳，另一张上是一位女子清晰娟秀的笔迹。我先打开了后一封。
en: Directly as I closed the door I saw laid on the table two letters.My thought was that they were notes of invitation from the friends of some of my pupils.I had received such marks of attention occasionally, and with me, who had no friends, correspondence of more interest was out of the question.The postman’s arrival had never yet been an event of interest to me since I came to Brussels.I laid my hand carelessly on the documents, and coldly and slowly glancing at them, I prepared to break the seals.My eye was arrested and my hand too; I saw what excited me, as if I had found a vivid picture where I expected only to discover a blank page.On one cover was an English postmark; on the other a lady’s clear, fine autograph.The last I opened first.

zh: “先生，在您拜访我的第二天早晨我便发现您所做的事情了。您也许确定我每天都会给瓷器除尘，因为除了您之外，这周没有人来过我的房间，而且这种带有仙女图像的硬币在布鲁塞尔并不流通，我毫无疑问就断定是谁将这二十法郎放在壁炉台上的。我想起当我弯腰去桌子下帮您找手套的时候曾经听见您弄那个花瓶，我还想您怎么会把手套掉到那么小的杯子里呢。先生，既然这钱不是我的，我不能留着它。我没有将它们装到这个信封里寄给您，因为可能会丢——而且那也太重了——我会暂时收着，等到下次见到您再还给您。您一定要毫不客气地拿走它们，首先因为我确定先生您能够理解任何人都想还清他的债务——正所谓“无债一身轻”；其次我之所以能够真心诚意地将钱还给您是因为我已经找到一份工作。事实上，这也是我写信给您的真正原因，因为我很乐意给您报喜，这些日子里我唯能跟我的老师说一些事情。
en: ’Monsieur,—I found out what you had done the very morning after your visit to me. You might be sure I should dust the china every day; and as no one but you had been in my room for a week, and as fairy-money is not current in Brussels, I could not doubt who left the twenty francs on the chimney-piece.I thought I heard you stir the vase when I was stooping to look for your glove under the table, and I wondered you should imagine it had got into such a little cup. Now, monsieur, the money is not mine, and I shall not keep it.I will not send it in this note, because it might be lost—besides, it is heavy—but I will restore it to you the first time I see you.And you must make no difficulties about taking it: because, in the first place, I am sure, monsieur, you can understand that one likes to pay one’s debts—that it is satisfactory to owe no man anything; and, in the second place, I can now very well afford to be honest, as I am provided with a situation.This last circumstance is, indeed, the reason of my writing to you, for it is pleasant to communicate good news and in these days I have only my master to whom I can tell anything.

zh: “先生，一周前一个叫沃顿太太的英国夫人派人叫我过去。她的大女儿要结婚，有一位富亲戚送给她一方面纱和一件镶着昂贵古花边的衣服，她们说那件衣服几乎像珍宝一样珍贵，但是因为年代久远而有一些损坏，她们请我去修一下。我只好在她家里修。此外她们还给了我一些刺绣活，我花了快一个星期才把一切弄好。在我工作的时候，沃顿小姐经常来房间里和我坐在一起，沃顿夫人也是一样。她们让我说英语，问我怎么学的，能讲那么好。然后她们问我还知道什么，读过什么书，不久她们似乎对我有了好奇心，认为我一定是个有学识的女工。一天下午沃顿太太带来一个巴黎夫人，想测试我的法语水平。可能很大程度上由于这对好脾气的母女人逢喜事，乐于行善，我想还部分地因为她们天性向善，所以她们认为我表达过想做一些比缝补花边更重要的事的愿望很理所当然。她们当天便带我坐马车到德太太家，德太太是布鲁塞尔第一所英语学校的女校长。好像她正好在找一个法国女士用法语教授地理、历史、语法和作文。沃顿太太很热情地推荐了我；由于她的两个小女儿在这所学校读书，她又是该校赞助人，这两点帮助我谋得了那个职位。最后确定我每天上六个小时的课（所幸的是没有要求我住在学校；要我离开家我会很难过的），沃顿太太每年付我一千两百法郎。
en: ‘A week ago, monsieur, I was sent for by a Mrs. Wharton, an English lady.Her eldest daughter was going to be married, and some rich relation having made her a present of a veil and dress in costly old lace, as precious, they said, almost as jewels, but a little damaged by time, I was commissioned to put them in repair.I had to do it at the house.They gave me, besides some embroidery to complete, and nearly a week elapsed before I had finished everything.While I worked, Miss Wharton often came into the room and sat with me, and so did Mrs. Wharton.They made me talk English; asked how I had learned to speak it so well.Then they inquired what I knew besides—what books I had read; soon they seemed to make a sort of wonder of me, considering me no doubt as a learned grisette.One afternoon Mrs. Wharton brought in a Parisian lady to test the accuracy of my knowledge of French.The result of it was that, owing probably in a great degree to the mother’s and daughter’s good- humour about the marriage, which inclined them to do beneficent deeds, and partly, I think, because they are naturally benevolent people, they decided that the wish I had expressed to do something more than mend lace was a very legitimate one, and the same day they took me in their carriage to Mrs. D—’s, who is the directress of the first English school at Brussels.It seems she happened to be in want of a French lady to give lessons in geography, history, grammar, and composition, in the French language.Mrs. Wharton recommended me very warmly; and as two of her younger daughters are pupils in the house, her patronage availed to get me the place.It was settled that I am to attend six hours daily (for, happily, it was not required that I should live in the house; I should have been sorry to leave my lodgings), and for this Mrs. D— will give me twelve hundred francs per annum.

zh: “所以先生您看，我现在富起来了——几乎比我以前所希望的还富有。对此我很感激，尤其是我的视力开始由于长期做精细女工而受到损害，而且夜里经常熬夜到很晚，也弄得我非常厌倦，都没有时间读书学习。我开始担心这样迟早会生病，甚至无力支付日常开销。这种担心如今已经在很大程度上不存在了；说实在的，先生，我很感激上帝为我减轻了负担，我觉得很有必要向乐他人所乐的好心人诉说我心中的喜悦之情。于是我忍不住提笔给您写信。我和自己争辩，写这封信令我很开心，先生您读起来尽管可能会觉得很无聊，但也不至于痛苦。我拙词劣句地赘述了这么多，还请先生见谅，并请相信您忠实的学生。
en: ‘You see, therefore, monsieur, that I am now rich—richer almost than I ever hoped to be.I feel thankful for it, especially as my sight was beginning to be injured by constant working at fine lace; and I was getting, too, very weary of sitting up late at nights, and yet not being able to find time for reading or study.I began to fear that I should fall ill, and be unable to pay my way. This fear is now in a great measure removed; and in truth, monsieur, I am very grateful to God for the relief, and I feel it necessary, almost, to speak of my happiness to some one who is kind-hearted enough to derive joy from seeing others joyful.I could not, therefore, resist the temptation of writing to you. I argued with myself it is very pleasant for me to write, and it will not be exactly painful, though it may be tiresome, to monsieur to read.Do not be too angry with my circumlocution and inelegancies of expression, and believe me your attached pupil,

zh: 弗·埃·亨利。”
en: F. E. Henri.’

zh: 读完这封信，我对里面的内容沉思了一会儿——心里究竟是伤感还是喜悦留到以后再说——跟着又拿起了第二封。那个笔迹我并不熟识——字体很小又很工整，既不像男人的字也不像女人的字。封条上是个盾形纹徽，我只能确定这不是西科姆家族的标志，这样我就知道这封信不会来自我几乎已经遗忘，当然也几乎遗忘我的贵族亲戚。那它到底是谁寄的呢？我打开信封，拆开叠着的信纸，信的内容如下：
en: Having read this letter, I mused on its contents for a few moments—whether with sentiments pleasurable or otherwise I will hereafter note—and then took up the other.It was directed in a hand to me unknown—small, and rather neat, neither masculine nor exactly feminine.The seal bore a coat of arms, concerning which I could only decipher that it was not that of the Seacombe family; consequently the epistle could be from none of my almost forgotten, and certainly quite forgetting, patrician relations.From whom, then, was it?I removed the envelope; the note folded within ran as follows:—

zh: “我肯定你在那块法兰德斯的沃土上混得不错，你极有可能在富得流油的土地上过着奢侈的生活，就像一个坐在埃及人肉锅边上的黑头发、黄褐色皮肤、长鼻子的以色列人，或者就像利未那卑劣的儿子坐在神殿的大铜锅旁，时不时放进一个圣钩，从肉汤中捞出最肥的膀子和肉最多的前肋。因为你从没有给英国的任何人写过信，所以我知道这些。你真是条忘恩负义的狗啊！全赖我的鼎力推荐，你方能得到今天的位置，过着此般安逸的日子，而你却没有一句感激之言，甚至没听你说过一句谢谢来回赠我。但是我还是要去看你的，你那混乱的贵族头脑很难想象我是多么气愤，我已经将这种怨恨收到我的旅行箱里，准备带到布鲁塞尔去，一见你面就拿出来让你瞧瞧。
en: ‘I have no doubt in the world that you are doing well in that greasy Flanders; living probably on the fat of the unctuous land; sitting like a black-haired, tawny-skinned, long-nosed Israelite by the flesh-pots of Egypt; or like a rascally son of Levi near the brass cauldrons of the sanctuary, and every now and then plunging in a consecrated hook, and drawing out of the sea of broth the fattest heave-shoulders and the fleshiest of wave-breasts.I know this, because you never write to any one in England.Thankless dog that you are!I, by the sovereign efficacy of my recommendation, got you the place where you are now living in clover, and yet not a word of gratitude, or even acknowledgment, have you ever offered in return.But I am coming to see you, and small conception can you, with your addled aristocratic brains, form of the sort of moral kicking I have ready packed in my carpet bag, destined to be presented to you immediately on my arrival.

zh: “同时我还知道你所有的事情，并且刚从布朗先生的上封信里得到消息，据说你即将和一位矮小肥胖的比利时女校长——叫佐诺比小姐还是什么的——喜结连理。我去你那儿的时候一定要见一见她！我可以向你保证——如果她合我的胃口，或者从经济的角度我觉得她很合适的话，我会向你猛扑过去，就算扳开你的牙齿也要成功地抢走她。但是我不喜欢矮胖型的，布朗说她就是又矮又胖——这正好适合你这种又瘦又长饿死鬼般的家伙。
en: ’Meantime I know all about your affairs, and have just got information, by Brown’s last letter, that you are said to be on the point of forming an advantageous match with a pursy little Belgian schoolmistress—a Mdlle.
