zh: 我不知道弗朗西斯是否对我的长篇大论给予了应有的注意。她没有如往常一样十分尊敬地立即回答我，而只是叹了口气，然后说道：
en: I am not sure whether Frances had accorded due attention to my harangue.Instead of answering me with her usual respectful promptitude, she only sighed, and said,—

zh: “先生您是多么的富有啊！”然后在我的怀里不安地动了动。“年薪三千法郎！”她低声说道，“而我只有一千二百法郎！”她说得更快了。“但是目前应该这样了，先生，您刚不是说让我放弃我的工作吗？啊不！我要紧紧地抓牢它。”她的小手把我的手抓得更紧了，“想想我嫁给您，靠您养活，先生！我可做不到；而且那样的话，我的日子会是多么无聊啊！您会从早到晚出门，在紧闭又吵闹的教室里上课；而我只能在家里，游手好闲，孤单寂寞。我会很快就变得压抑而沉闷，那您不久就会厌烦我了。”
en: ‘How rich you are, monsieur!’ and then she stirred uneasy in my arms.‘Three thousand francs!’ she murmured, ‘while I get only twelve hundred!’ She went on faster.‘However, it must be so for the present; and, monsieur, were you not saying something about my giving up my place?Oh no!I shall hold it fast,’ and her little fingers emphatically tightened on mine.‘Think of my marrying you to be kept by you, monsieur!I could not do it; and how dull my days would be!You would be away teaching in close, noisy schoolrooms from morning till evening, and I should be lingering at home, unemployed and solitary.I should get depressed and sullen, and you would soon tire of me.’

zh: “弗朗西斯，你可以读书，可以学习呀——你不是很喜欢干这两件事嘛。”
en: ‘Frances, you could read and study—two things you like so well.’

zh: “先生，我做不到。我的确喜欢沉思冥想的生活，但是我更热爱积极向上的生活。无论如何我要做些事，和您一起做事。我已经注意到，先生，那些只是彼此的玩伴的夫妻不会像那些一起工作或者一起吃苦的夫妻那样互相爱慕，互相尊重。”
en: ‘Monsieur, I could not. I like a contemplative life, but I like an active life better.I must act in some way, and act with you. I have taken notice, monsieur, that people who are only in each other’s company for amusement never really like each other so well, or esteem each other so highly, as those who work together, and perhaps suffer together.’

zh: “你说得很对，”我最后说道，”你应该走自己的路，因为那是最好的一条路。现在我欣然答应了你，作为奖赏你应该主动给我一个吻吧。”
en: ‘You speak God’s truth,’ said I at last; ‘and you shall have your own way, for it is the best way.Now, as a reward for such ready consent, give me a voluntary kiss.’

zh: 她犹豫了一会，这对于她这样一个接吻的新生来说是很自然的，她十分害羞地用嘴唇轻触了我的额头。我接受了这份小礼物，作为一笔债，并马上偿还了她，而且带着丰厚的利息。
en: After some hesitation, natural to a novice in the art of kissing, she brought her lips into very shy and gentle contact with my forehead.I took the small gift as a loan, and repaid it promptly, and with generous interest.

zh: 我不知道自从我第一次见到弗朗西斯以来，她是不是真的改变了很多；但是当我现在看着她时，我感觉她确实为我一人改变了。我所记得的她的早先特征——悲伤的眼神，苍白的面颊，沮丧寡欢的面容——都已荡然无存，如今我看到的是一张充满魅力的面孔：浅笑，酒窝，玫瑰般的气色软化了她的轮廓，使她光艳照人。我习惯在内心酝酿一个讨人喜欢的想法，认为我对她的强烈爱慕是我本性中的某种特殊的洞察力。她不漂亮，也没有钱，甚至毫无才艺，但是她是我生命中的珍宝。那样的话我肯定是眼光独到了。今晚我终于睁开眼睛，看到自己犯下的错误了；我开始怀疑只是因为我品位独特，而不是慧眼识珠，才能够欣赏那种精神情操胜过肉体的魅力。对我而言弗朗西斯也是有肉体魅力的。她身上没有什么残缺，眼睛、牙齿、肤色、以及体型都没有显著的缺陷——那些缺陷，会让即便是最为拥护女性“智力美”的男人退避三舍(因为女人会爱上一个丑八怪，只要他有才华）。如果她是个“没牙齿的老太婆，近视眼，又是个麻子或者驼背”，那我对她的感情也许仍然会很和善，但是决不会为她神魂颠倒。我对可怜的畸形的小西尔薇有同情心，但是我永远不会对她有爱情。确实，一开始吸引我的是弗朗西斯的精神，这也一直是我最喜爱的一点；但是我同样喜欢她外优雅的外表。当我凝视她那清澈的棕色双瞳，光滑细腻的皮肤，整齐洁白的牙齿，凹凸有致的身材，便会有一种纯感官的享受——那种享受我至今都无法舍弃。这样看来，我也是个好色之徒，一个适度而挑剔的好色之徒。
en: I know not whether Frances was really much altered since the time I first saw her; but as I looked at her now, I felt that she was singularly changed for me.The sad eye, the pale cheek, the dejected and joyless countenance I remembered as her early attributes were quite gone, and now I saw a face dressed in graces; smile, dimple, and rosy tint rounded its contours and brightened its hues.I had been accustomed to nurse a flattering idea that my strong attachment to her proved some particular perspicacity in my nature.She was not handsome, she was not rich, she was not even accomplished, yet was she my life’s treasure.I must, then, be a man of peculiar discernment.To-night my eyes opened on the mistake I had made; I began to suspect that it was only my tastes which were unique, not my power of discovering and appreciating the superiority of moral worth over physical charms.For me Frances had physical charms.In her there was no deformity to get over, none of those prominent defects of eyes, teeth, complexion, shape, which hold at bay the admiration of the boldest male champions of intellect (for women can love a downright ugly man if he be but talented).Had she been either ‘edentee, myope, rugueuse, ou bossue,’ my feelings towards her might still have been kindly, but they could never have been impassioned.I had affection for the poor little misshapen Sylvie, but for her I could never have had love.It is true Frances’ mental points had been the first to interest me, and they still retained the strongest hold on my preference; but I liked the graces of her person too.I derived a pleasure, purely material, from contemplating the clearness of her brown eyes, the fairness of her fine skin, the purity of her well-set teeth, the proportion of her delicate form; and that pleasure I could ill have dispensed with.It appeared, then, that I too was a sensualist, in my temperate and fastidious way.

zh: 现在，读者们，在上两页里我一直为你们奉献新鲜的花蜜，但是你不能完全靠着如此甘甜的食物生活；那就先尝一点胆汁吧——只尝一滴，就当换换口味。
en: Now, reader, during the last two pages I have been giving you honey fresh from flowers, but you must not live entirely on food so luscious; taste, then, a little gall—just a drop, by way of change.

zh: 我回到住处的时候，已经有点晚了。因为暂时忘了人们还要操心吃喝之类令人讨厌的事情，我空着肚子上床了。我一整天都很激动，一直忙碌着，从那天早上八点一直没有吃东西；此外，在那之前的两个星期，我的身心都没有得到休息。过去的几个小时我一直处于甜蜜的狂热状态，至今未能平静；直到半夜很久之后这种烦人的狂喜仍然干扰着我急需的睡眠。最终，我睡着了，但是没有睡很久；当我醒来时天还很黑，我就像约伯一样，被面前晃过的幽灵惊醒，我像他一样也是“不寒而栗”。我可以把这个比喻继续下去，因为事实上，尽管我什么都没看到，但的确“有一个东西正神秘地朝我走来，我听到它的一点响声。在万籁无声之时我听到一个声音，”说着，“活着就是死去。”
en: At a somewhat late hour I returned to my lodgings.Having temporarily forgotten that man had any such coarse cares as those of eating and drinking, I went to bed fasting.I had been excited and in action all day, and had tasted no food since eight that morning; besides, for a fortnight past I had known no rest either of body or mind.The last few hours had been a sweet delirium; it would not subside now, and till long after midnight broke with troubled ecstasy the rest I so much needed.At last I dozed, but not for long; it was yet quite dark when I awoke, and my waking was like that of Job when a spirit passed before his face, and, like him, ‘the hair of my flesh stood up.’ I might continue the parallel, for in truth, though I saw nothing, yet ‘a thing was secretly brought unto me, and mine ear received a little thereof.There was silence, and I heard a voice,’ saying, ‘In the midst of life we are in death.’

zh: 那种声音以及随之而来的令人不寒而栗的痛苦感，很多人会认为是超自然的；但是我立即意识到那是一种心理反应。人终有一死，此刻踌躇和抱怨的，正是我的凡人本性——我的神经振动着，发出一种不合调的声音，令我烦躁不安，因为我的灵魂最近一直一往无前地朝着一个目标冲击，使得原本就相对虚弱的身体过度紧张。一种巨大的黑暗恐惧笼罩着我。我感觉我的房间闯进一个我以前认识，但是觉得永远都见不到的人。我暂时变成了臆想症的猎物。
en: That sound, and the sensation of chill anguish accompanying it, many would have regarded as supernatural; but I recognized it at once as the effect of reaction.Man is ever clogged with his mortality, and it was my mortal nature which now faltered and plained—my nerves which jarred and gave a false sound, because the soul, of late rushing headlong to an aim, had overstrained the body’s comparative weakness.A horror of great darkness fell upon me. I felt my chamber invaded by one I had known formerly, but had thought for ever departed.I was temporarily a prey to hypochondria.

zh: 她曾是我少年期之前的的一个相识——不，我的客人。我曾在一年的时间里招待了她的吃住，在那段时间我和她偷偷地在一起。她与我一起睡觉，一起吃饭，和我一起出门散步，带我看森林里的偏僻角落，还有山上的山洞，在那我们坐在一起，她揭掉那让人阴郁的面纱，戴在我的头上，遮住天空和太阳，草地和绿树；她一把将我整个抱入她冰冷的乳房，用骨瘦如柴的手臂搂着我。在这样的时候她会给我讲那么奇妙的故事！会给我唱那么动听的歌！她会向我描述她的国家——坟墓——并且一次次地向我许诺，不久后就会带我去那里；她将我带往一条阴沉的黑河边上，指给我看对岸大大小小的坟堆、纪念碑和墓碑，它们伫立在比月光还要惨白的寒光中。“那是公墓！”她指着那暗淡的土堆低语，又补充说，“那里有为你准备的府邸。”
en: She had been my acquaintance—nay, my guest, once before in boyhood.I had entertained her at bed and board for a year; for that space of time I had her to myself in secret.She lay with me, she ate with me, she walked out with me, showing me nooks in woods, hollows in hills, where we could sit together, and where she could drop her drear veil over me and so hide sky and sun, grass and green tree; taking me entirely to her death-cold bosom, and holding me with arms of bone.What tales she would tell me at such hours!What songs she would recite in my ears!How she would discourse to me of her own country—the grave—and again and again promise to conduct me there ere long; and, drawing me to the very brink of a black, sullen river, show me, on the other side, shores unequal with mound, monument, and tablet, standing up in a glimmer more hoary than moonlight.‘Necropolis!’ she would whisper, pointing to the pale piles, and add, ‘It contains a mansion prepared for you.’

zh: 我少年时无父无母，孤苦伶仃，更没有兄弟姐妹的疼爱；所以当我步入青春期时，这位女巫发现我迷失在朦胧的精神流浪之中，带着诸多的情感与稀疏的目标、热情的抱负与黯淡的前景、强烈的欲望以及渺茫的希望，她便在远方举起幻影之灯，引诱我走向她那拱形的恐怖之家，也就不那么令人大惊小怪了。难怪当时她的魔咒那么有力量；但是现在我的道路逐渐拓宽，我的前景逐渐明朗，我的情感得以栖息，我的欲望厌倦了长期的飞行收起翅膀刚刚着陆在丰收的果实上，充满温暖，十分惬意地躺着那里接受一只柔软手的爱抚——为什么臆想症现在又来引诱我呢？
en: But my boyhood was lonely, parentless, uncheered by brother or sister; and there was no marvel that, just as I rose to youth, a sorceress, finding me lost in vague mental wanderings, with many affections and few objects, glowing aspirations and gloomy prospects, strong desires and slender hopes, should lift up her illusive lamp to me in the distance, and lure me to her vaulted home of horrors.No wonder her spells then had power; but now, when my course was widening, my prospect brightening, when my affections had found a rest, when my desires, folding wings, weary with long flight, had just alighted on the very lap of Fruition, and nestled there, warm, content, under the caress of a soft hand—why did hypochondria accost me now?

zh: 我回绝了她的诱惑，就好像所有人都会冷落一个可怕、令人畏惧的姘妇一样，她们唆使丈夫从打心底怨恨他年轻的新娘。一连八天，她夜复一夜地缠绕着我。此后我的精神才开始慢慢地恢复正常，我的食欲也回来了，两个星期之后我康复了。我如往常一样整日奔走，对他人从未提及我的感受；我庆幸那个邪灵已离我而去，我又可以去找弗朗西斯，坐在她的身边，摆脱那个可怕恶魔的缠绕了。
en: I repulsed her as one would a dreaded and ghastly concubine coming to embitter a husband’s heart towards his young bride.In vain.She kept her sway over me for that night and the next day, and eight succeeding days.Afterwards my spirits began slowly to recover their tone; my appetite returned, and in a fortnight I was well.I had gone about as usual all the time, and had said nothing to anybody of what I felt; but I was glad when the evil spirit departed from me, and I could again seek Frances, and sit at her side, freed from the dreadful tyranny of my demon.

zh: 第二十四章
en: CHAPTER XXIV

zh: 十一月的一个晴朗而严寒的星期天，我和弗朗西斯散了很久的步。我们沿着林阴大道在城中漫步，后来因为弗朗西斯有点累，我们便坐在路边树下的椅子上休息，这些椅子间隔排列着，为走累的路人而设。弗朗西斯为我讲述起瑞士的事情。这个话题让她很兴奋；我正在想她的眼睛像她的舌头一样富于表现力之时，她突然停住说道：
en: One fine, frosty Sunday in November Frances and I took a long walk.We made the tour of the city by the boulevards, and afterwards, Frances being a little tired, we sat down on one of those wayside seats placed under the trees at intervals for the accommodation of the weary, Frances was telling me about Switzerland.The subject animated her; and I was just thinking that her eyes spoke full as eloquently as her tongue, when she stopped and remarked,—

zh: “先生，那边有位绅士认识您。”
en: ‘Monsieur, there is a gentleman who knows you.’

zh: 我抬头看去。三个打扮时髦的男人正从我们身边经过——都是英国人，我从他们的神态，步态以及相貌看出来的。我一眼就认出三人中最高的那位是亨斯登先生；他正在举帽向弗朗西斯问好。随后他就对我扮了个鬼脸，又接着向前走去。
en: I looked up. Three fashionably dressed men were just then passing—Englishmen, I knew, by their air and gait as well as by their features.In the tallest of the trio I at once recognized Mr. Hunsden; he was in the act of lifting his hat to Frances.Afterwards he made a grimace at me, and passed on.

zh: “他是谁呀？”
en: ‘Who is he?’

zh: “一个我在英国认识的人。”
en: ‘A person I knew in England.’

zh: “他为什么向我鞠躬呢？他不认识我呀。”
en: ‘Why did he bow to me?He does not know me.’

zh: “不，他确实认识你，他那样就算认识了。”
en: ‘Yes, he does know you, in his way.’

zh: “怎么会呢，先生？”（她还是叫我‘先生’；我没办法说服她用别的更为亲切的词来称呼我。）
en: ‘How, monsieur?’ (She still called me ’monsieur;’ I could not persuade her to adopt any more familiar term.)

zh: “你没有看懂他的眼神吗？”
en: ‘Did you not read the expression of his eyes?’

zh: “他的眼神？没有；他的眼神怎么了？”
en: ‘Of his eyes?No; what did they say?’

zh: “它们在对你说‘您好，威廉明娜·克里姆斯沃思。’对我说‘你终于找到你的另一半了；她就坐在那儿，正是适合你的女人！’”
en: ‘To you they said, “How do you do, Wilhelmina Crimsworth?” To me, “So you have found your counterpart at last; there she sits, the female of your kind!”’

zh: “先生，您不可能从他眼里一下子看出那么多的；他这么快就离开了。”
en: ‘Monsieur, you could not read all that in his eyes; he was so soon gone.’

zh: “我除了那些还看到更多，弗朗西斯。就我看出来他很可能今晚要来拜访我，或者是不久的将来。而且我一点也不怀疑他会坚持让我介绍你们认识。我把他带到你家去好不好？”
en: ‘I read that and more, Frances.I read that he will probably call on me this evening, or on some future occasion shortly.And I have no doubt he will insist on being introduced to you.Shall I bring him to your rooms?’

zh: “如果您愿意的话，先生；我不会反对。我想我确实也想近一点地看看他；他看起来很特别。”
en: ‘If you please, monsieur; I have no objection.I think, indeed, I should rather like to see him nearer; he looks so original.’

zh: 正如我所料，亨斯登先生那晚就来了。他所说的第一件事就是：
en: As I had anticipated, Mr. Hunsden came that evening.The first thing he said was,—

zh: “你没必要开始自吹自擂，教师先生。我知道你被那所学院聘用了，知道那一切；布朗都告诉我了。”然后他便提到自己刚从德国回来一两天；接着他突然问我，他在林荫道上看到和我一起在的人是不是珀莱·勒泰夫人。我正准备竭力否认，但再想了想后又止住了，装作承认的样子，问他觉得她如何。
en: ‘You need not begin boasting, monsieur le professeur.I know about your appointment to College, and all that; Brown has told me.’ Then he intimated that he had returned from Germany but a day or two since; afterwards he abruptly demanded whether that was Madame Pelet-Reuter with whom he had seen me on the boulevards.I was going to utter a rather emphatic negative, but on second thoughts I checked myself, and, seeming to assent, asked what he thought of her.

zh: “关于她，我马上就会提到；但是首先我有一句话要奉劝你。我觉得你是个流氓。你不应该跟别人的妻子散步。我本以为你还算明智，不会稀里糊涂地卷入这种混帐事。”
en: ‘As to her, I’ll come to that directly; but first I’ve a word for you.I see you are a scoundrel.You’ve no business to be promenading about with another man’s wife.I thought you had sounder sense than to get mixed up in foreign hodgepodge of this sort.’

zh: “但是那个女人？”
en: ‘But the lady?’

zh: “显然她太优秀了，你配不上她。她很像你，但是要比你好；但并不算是一个美女。不过当她站起来时（我那时回头看到你们一起走开），我觉得她的身材和姿态还是不错的。这些外国人倒懂得什么是优雅。她跟珀莱到底怎么回事？她嫁给他还没到三个月呢；珀莱肯定是个傻瓜！”
en: ‘She’s too good for you evidently.She is like you, but something better than you; no beauty, though.Yet when she rose (for I looked back to see you both walk away) I thought her figure and carriage good.These foreigners understand grace.What the devil has she done with Pelet?She has not been married to him three months; he must be a spoon!’

zh: 我不想让他再误会下去。我可不想那样。
en: I would not let the mistake go too far.I did not like it much.

zh: “珀莱？怎么你的脑子里一直想着珀莱夫妇呢！你总是谈论他们。我真希望你能娶了佐蕾德小姐。”
en: ‘Pelet?How your head runs on M. and Madame Pelet!You are always talking about them.I wish to the gods you had wed Mdlle. Zoraïde yourself.’

zh: “那个年轻的女士不是佐蕾德小姐吗？”
en: ‘Was that young gentlewoman not Mdlle. Zoraïde?’

zh: “不是的，也不是佐蕾德夫人。”
en: ‘No, nor Madame Zoraïde either.’

zh: “那你为什么要说谎？”
en: ‘Why did you tell a lie then?’

zh: “我没有说谎；但是你一直都急冲冲的。她是我的一个学生——一位瑞士姑娘。”
en: ‘I told no lie; but you are in such a hurry.She is a pupil of mine—a Swiss girl.’

zh: “那你当然准备跟她结婚了？不要否认。”
en: ‘And, of course, you are going to be married to her?Don’t deny that.’

zh: “结婚！我想我会的——只要命运再给我们俩十个礼拜。她就是我的野生小草莓，亨斯登，它的甜蜜让我对你那温室的葡萄毫不在乎。”
en: ‘Married!I think I shall—if Fate spares us both ten weeks longer.That is my little wild strawberry, Hunsden, whose sweetness made me careless of your hot-house grapes.’

zh: “闭嘴！不要再吹牛了，不要再装腔作势了；我是不会听的。她是干什么的？她属于哪个阶级？”
en: ‘Stop!No boasting, no heroics; I won’t hear them.What is she?To what caste does she belong?’

zh: 我笑了笑。亨斯登无意中强调了阶级这个词，事实上，他虽然是一名共和党人，贵族的死敌，但他仍像诺曼族人以及征服英国时被授予封号的人的国家里的所有人一样，为自己古老的某某郡的血脉、世系以及体面、世代受人尊敬的家庭地位感到骄傲。就像斯坦利人不会想到跟科布登人结亲一样，亨斯登也不会考虑娶一个比自己阶级地位低的女人做妻子。我很享受自己给他带来的惊讶；我很享受自己的实践战胜他的理论所带来的欢欣；我靠在桌上，抑制住心中的喜悦，慢吞吞地、简明地说道：
en: I smiled.Hunsden unconsciously laid stress on the word caste, and, in fact, republican, lord-hater as he was, Hunsden was as proud of his old —shire blood, of his descent and family standing, respectable and respected through long generations back, as any peer in the realm of his Norman race and Conquest-dated title.Hunsden would as little have thought of taking a wife from a caste inferior to his own as a Stanley would think of mating with a Cobden.I enjoyed the surprise I should give; I enjoyed the triumph of my practice over his theory; and leaning over the table, and uttering the words slowly but with repressed glee, I said concisely,—

zh: “她是修花边的。”
en: ‘She is a lace-mender.’

zh: 亨斯登仔细地看着我。他没有说他很惊讶，但是他确实很惊讶。他对于什么是良好的出身有自己的见解。我看得出来他怀疑我会草率行事；但是他没有激辩，也没有规劝，只是回答道：
en: Hunsden examined me. He did not say he was surprised, but surprised he was.He had his own notions of good breeding.I saw he suspected I was going to take some very rash step; but repressing declamation or remonstrance, he only answered,—

zh: “好吧，你最清楚你自己在做什么。一位修花边的女工也许可以像一位贵族小姐一样成为好妻子；不过，显然你已经完全考虑清楚了，既然她没受过教育，没有财产，没有地位，她一定有着你所认为极有可能给你带来幸福的天然的品质。她有很多亲戚吗？”
en: ‘Well, you are the best judge of your own affairs.A lace-mender may make a good wife as well as a lady; but, of course, you have taken care to ascertain thoroughly that since she has not education, fortune, or station, she is well furnished with such natural qualities as you think most likely to conduce to your happiness.Has she many relations’ ’

zh: “在布鲁塞尔一个都没有。”
en: ‘None in Brussels.’

zh: “那还好些。在这种情况下亲戚往往容易坏事。我只能这样想，一大群穷亲戚会成为你一辈子的负担。”
en: ‘That is better.Relations are often the real evil in such cases.I cannot but think that a train of inferior connections would have been a bore to you to your life’s end.’

zh: 在沉默不语地坐了一阵后，亨斯登站了起来，轻声地向我说了声晚安。他用礼貌又体贴的方式向我伸出手来（以前他从来没有这样过），这个举动使我相信他认为我已经做了一件极为愚蠢的事；并且认为既然我自甘毁灭，自暴自弃，那他就不需要讽刺挖苦或者冷嘲热讽，并且除了放纵与忍耐外也确实别无他法。
en: After sitting in silence a little while longer, Hunsden rose, and was quietly bidding me good-evening.The polite, considerate manner in which he offered me his hand (a thing he had never done before) convinced me that he thought I had made a terrible fool of myself; and that, ruined and thrown away as I was, it was no time for sarcasm or cynicism, or indeed for anything but indulgence and forbearance.

zh: “晚安，威廉，”他用极为柔和的声音说道，同时他的脸上露出极为仁慈的同情神色；“晚安了，小伙子。我祝你和你未来的妻子前程似锦，并且希望她能够满足你那苛求的心灵。”
en: ‘Good-night, William,’ he said, in a really soft voice, while his face looked benevolently compassionate; ‘goodnight, lad. I wish you and your future wife much prosperity, and I hope she will satisfy your fastidious soul.’

zh: 看着他那宽宏大量的怜悯神色，我好不容易控制住自己才没笑出来。而我故作凝重地说：“我还以为你会很想见见亨利小姐呢？”
en: I had much ado to refrain from laughing as I beheld the magnanimous pity of his mien.Maintaining, however, a grave air, I said, ‘I thought you would have liked to have seen Mdlle. Henri?’

zh: “哦，那是她的名字！是的，如果方便的话我很想见见她；但是——”他迟疑着。
en: ‘Oh, that is the name!Yes, if it would be convenient, I should like to see her; but—’ He hesitated.

zh: “怎么了？”
en: ‘Well?’

zh: “我不能贸然闯入她家。”
en: ‘I should on no account wish to intrude.’

zh: “那我带你去吧，”我说道。我们就出发了。亨斯登无疑把我当做一个轻率而鲁莽的人，居然带他去那可怜的没有装潢的小房间里见我可怜的小女工爱人；但是他准备表现得像一位真正的绅士，而事实上，他已经领会表演这种性格的精髓了，虽然表演有些粗糙，但他很乐意把它当成精神防水衣穿着。我们沿着大街走着，他说话温和，甚至可以说是彬彬有礼。他一生中从未对我这么客气过。我们来到那栋房子，走了进去，爬上楼梯；到门廊时，亨斯登转身还要往引向更高一层的、更为狭窄的楼梯上爬。我明白，他以为弗朗西斯住在阁楼里。
en: ‘Come, then,’ said I. We set out.Hunsden no doubt regarded me as a rash, imprudent man, thus to show my poor little grisette sweet-heart, in her poor little unfurnished grenier; but he prepared to act the real gentleman, having, in fact, the kernel of that character under the harsh husk it pleased him to wear by way of mental mackintosh.He talked affably, and even gently, as we went along the street.He had never been so civil to me in his life.We reached the house, entered, ascended the stair; on gaining the lobby, Hunsden turned to mount a narrower stair which led to a higher story.I saw his mind was bent on the attics.

zh: “这里，亨斯登先生，”我边敲弗朗西斯的门边轻轻地说。他转过身来。因为他的恭敬有礼，这小小错误竟使他有些仓皇失措。他的目光又移回到那绿色的踏脚垫上，但是他什么都没有说。
en: ‘Here, Mr. Hunsden,’ said I quietly, tapping at Frances’ door.He turned.In his genuine politeness he was a little disconcerted at having made the mistake.His eye reverted to the green mat, but he said nothing.

zh: 我们走了进去，弗朗西斯从桌边站起来接待我们。她穿着一身孝服，看起来很像一个修道院的修女，但又显得十分高雅。那身简单而庄重的打扮并没有让她显得更加漂亮，却让她显得端庄了许多。那白色的衣领和袖口将庄重的黑色羊毛袍衬托得十分完美；衣服上没有装饰品。弗朗西斯行了一个稳重而优雅的屈膝礼，就像她一直以来那样，当别人先与她说话时，她看起来更像一位值得尊敬的女人，而不是一位值得爱慕的女人。我介绍了亨斯登先生，她用法语说她十分高兴认识他。她那纯正而动听的口音，低沉而甜美又很圆润的嗓音立即产生了效果。亨斯登也用法语应答。我以前没听他说过法语；但他说得很好。我退到窗边的座位坐了下来。亨斯登先生应女主人的邀请坐在壁炉旁的椅子上；从我的位置一眼就可以看见他们两个和整个房间。房间里干净明亮，看上去就像一个擦亮的壁橱；一个插满鲜花的玻璃杯摆在桌子中央，壁炉台上的每一只陶瓷杯里都插着一支新鲜的玫瑰，使得房间里有一种节日的气氛。弗朗西斯表情严肃，而亨斯登先生有些拘谨，但是两人都很礼貌；他们用法语流利地交谈着。他们认真而礼貌地讨论着一些日常话题。我想我从来没有见过像他们两个这样举止得体的模范；因为亨斯登（幸亏他受外语的限制）不得不小心措辞，以防讲出任何古怪的句子。最后他们谈到英国，弗朗西斯开始问东问西。弗朗西斯逐渐地变得活泼起来，就像一个暗淡的夜空随着日出而逐渐变亮一样。起初似乎是她的前额舒展开来，不久她的眼睛开始发光，神情亦渐趋放松，表情变得丰富起来。她暗淡的脸色变得红润而明晰。对我来说她现在美丽动人；之前她只是显得娴淑高雅。
en: We walked in, and Frances rose from her seat near the table to receive us. Her mourning attire gave her a recluse, rather conventual, but withal very distinguished look.Its grave simplicity added nothing to beauty, but much to dignity.The finish of the white collar and manchettes sufficed for a relief to the merino gown of solemn black; ornament was forsworn.Frances curtsied with sedate grace, looking, as she always did look, when one first accosted her, more a woman to respect than to love.I introduced Mr. Hunsden, and she expressed her happiness at making his acquaintance in French.The pure and polished accent, the low yet sweet and rather full voice, produced their effect immediately.Hunsden spoke French in reply.I had not heard him speak that language before; he managed it very well.I retired to the window seat.Mr. Hunsden, at his hostess’s invitation, occupied a chair near the hearth; from my position I could see them both, and the room too, at a glance.The room was so clean and bright it looked like a little polished cabinet; a glass filled with flowers in the centre of the table, a fresh rose in each china cup on the mantelpiece, gave it an air of fÃªte.Frances was serious and Mr. Hunsden subdued, but both mutually polite; they got on at the French swimmingly.Ordinary topics were discussed with great state and decorum.I thought I had never seen two such models of propriety; for Hunsden (thanks to the constraint of the foreign tongue) was obliged to shape his phrases, and measure his sentences, with a care that forbade any eccentricity.At last England was mentioned, and Frances proceeded to ask questions.Animated by degrees she began to change, just as a grave night-sky changes at the approach of sunrise.First it seemed as if her forehead cleared, then her eyes glittered, her features relaxed, and became quite mobile.Her subdued complexion grew warm and transparent.To me she now looked pretty; before, she had only looked ladylike.

zh: 她对这位刚刚来自那个岛国的英国人有很多话要说，她带着一种求知的激情敦促着他回答问题，这种热情很快便融化了亨斯登的拘谨严肃，就像火暖和了一条被冻僵的毒蛇。我打了这样一个比喻并不算夸大其词，因为他生动的表现使我想起一条从冬眠中苏醒的毒蛇，他挺直了他高大的身躯，抬起他之前稍微低着的头，将头发从他宽阔的撒克逊式的额头拢到脑后，将他那几乎野蛮的讽刺嘴脸展露无遗；弗朗西斯急切的语调和热情的目光不但使这种傲慢在他心中燃烧，也从他的眼神中显现了出来。亨斯登就是亨斯登，正如弗朗西斯就是弗朗西斯；现在，他只愿用自己的母语跟她说话。
en: She had many things to say to the Englishman just fresh from his island country, and she urged him with an enthusiasm of curiosity which ere long thawed Hunsden’s reserve as fire thaws a congealed viper.I use this not very flattering comparison because he vividly reminded me of a snake waking from torpor, as he erected his tall form, reared his head, before a little declined, and putting back his hair from his broad Saxon forehead, showed unshaded the gleam of almost savage satire which his interlocutor’s tone of eagerness and look of ardour had sufficed at once to kindle in his soul and elicit from his eyes.He was himself as Frances was herself, and in none but his own language would he now address her.

zh: “你懂英语吗？”这是他的第一个开场问题。
en: ‘You understand English?’ was the prefatory question.

zh: “懂一点点。”
en: ‘A little.’

zh: “哦，那你以后会懂很多。首先我认为你并不比我的某些其他熟人懂得多（他用大拇指了指我），否则当谈到那个叫英格兰的肮脏小国时你不会那么狂热——我看得出来你比较狂热。我从你的神情中看出来，从你的话语中听出来你有恐英症。小姐，为什么只要是有点理性的人都应该对英国这个名字这么有热情呢？五分钟前我以为你是位修女，所以对你极为尊敬；现在我发现你是个瑞士女巫，很保守，也有很强的宗教观念！”
en: ‘Well, then, you shall have plenty of it.And first, I see you’ve not much more sense than some others of my acquaintance (indicating me with his thumb), or else you’d never turn rabid about that dirty little country called England—for rabid I see you are.I read Anglo-phobia in your looks, and hear it in your words.Why, mademoiselle, is it possible that anybody with a grain of rationality should feel enthusiasm about a mere name, and that name England?I thought you were a lady-abbess five minutes ago, and respected you accordingly; and now I see you are a sort of Swiss sibyl, with high Tory and high Church principles!’

zh: “英国是您的祖国吗？”弗朗西斯问道。
en: ‘England is your country?’ asked Frances.

zh: “是的。”
en: ‘Yes.’

zh: “你不喜欢英国？”
en: ‘And you don’t like it?’

zh: “不是不喜欢，是很不喜欢！那是一个腐败贪污盛行的小国，是可恶的权贵与国王的小国，充满了令人厌恶的傲慢——就像某某郡的人所说的那样——到处都是无助的穷人；这国家已经被不正之风所侵蚀，被偏见歧视所蛀蚀！”
en: ‘I’d be sorry to like it!A little, corrupt, venal, lord-and-king-cursed nation, full of mucky pride—as they say in —shire—and helpless pauperism; rotten with abuses, worm-eaten with prejudices!’

zh: “这种情况几乎在所有国家都存在。到处都有陋习和偏见，我本以为英国会比其他国家少一点。”
en: ‘You might say so of almost every state.There are abuses and prejudices everywhere, and I thought fewer in England than in other countries.’

zh: “去英国看一看吧。到伯明翰去，到曼彻斯特去，到伦敦的圣贾尔斯区去，亲身感受一下我们的制度是怎样运行的吧。仔细看看我们威风凛凛的贵族们的脚印；看看他们是怎样践踏人民的心灵，如何在血泊中行走的吧。去将你的头探进英国的村舍；看看呆滞地蜷缩在黑乎乎的壁炉边的饥民，看看无遮无盖赤裸地躺在床上的病人，看看无耻行径是如何邪恶地挑逗愚昧无知的，尽管骄奢淫逸是她最喜欢的情夫，高贵的客厅对她而言比寒酸的茅草屋珍贵多了。”
en: ‘Come to England and see.Come to Birmingham and Manchester, come to St. Giles’s in London, and get a practical notion of how our system works.Examine the footprints of our august aristocracy; see how they walk in blood, crushing hearts as they go. Just put your head in at English cottage doors; get a glimpse of Famine crouched torpid on black hearthstones, of Disease lying bare on beds without coverlets, of Infamy wantoning viciously with Ignorance, though indeed Luxury is her favourite paramour, and princely halls are dearer to her than thatched hovels.

zh: “我想的不是英国的悲惨与邪恶；我想的是它好的方面——是它作为一个国家孕育出来的你的品德中好的一面。”
en: ‘I was not thinking of the wretchedness and vice in England; I was thinking of the good side—of what is elevated in your character as a nation.’

zh: “根本就没有好的方面，起码你无法体会；因为你不能充分意识到工业的成果，企业的成就或者科学的发现。你学历有限，身份低微，所以你无法理解这些东西；至于历史与理想化的联想，小姐，我并不想要侮辱你，我认为你提过那些骗人的东西。”
en: ‘There is no good side—none, at least, of which you can have any knowledge; for you cannot appreciate the efforts of industry, the achievements of enterprise, or the discoveries of science.Narrowness of education and obscurity of position quite incapacitate you from understanding those points; and as to historical and poetical associations, I will not insult you mademoiselle, by supposing that you alluded to such humbug.’

zh: “但是我只提过一部分。”
en: ‘But I did partly.’

zh: 亨斯登笑了笑——他十足蔑视地笑了。
en: Hunsden laughed—his laugh of unmitigated scorn.

zh: “我确实提过，亨斯登先生。您也是那种觉得联想毫无乐趣的人吗？”
en: ‘I did, Mr. Hunsden.Are you of the number of those to whom such associations give no pleasure?’

zh: “小姐，联想是什么呀？我从没见过。它有多长，多宽，多重，多贵——啊，什么价钱？拿到市场上怎么卖的？”
en: ‘Mademoiselle, what is an association?I never saw one. What is its length, breadth, weight, value—ay, value?What price will it bring in the market?’

zh: “对任何爱您的人而言，因为产生了联想，您的肖像会是无价之宝。”
en: ‘Your portrait, to any one who loved you, would, for the sake of association, be without price.’

zh: 那位神秘莫测的亨斯登听到这句话，也感觉某个地方有些尖锐，因为他脸红了——这是他被出其不意刺中痛处时的正常表现。一种烦恼一时之间让他的眼神暗淡了下来，我相信他的对手给了他致命一击之后，在这短暂间歇中，他在想，他也希望有人能爱他，因为他也愿意被人爱——他希望对于爱他的人他能毫无保留地以爱来报答。
en: That inscrutable Hunsden heard this remark, and felt it rather acutely, too, somewhere, for he coloured—a thing not unusual with him when hit unawares on a tender point.A sort of trouble momentarily darkened his eye, and I believe he filled up the transient pause succeeding his antagonist’s home-thrust by a wish that some one did love him as he would like to be loved—some one whose love he could unreservedly return.

zh: 这位女士趁热打铁。
en: The lady pursued her temporary advantage.

zh: “如果您的世界是个没有联想的世界，亨斯登先生，我就不再对您憎恨英国感到奇怪了。我并不是很清楚地知道天堂是什么，天使是什么，但是我能够想象出天堂是最辉煌的地方，天使是最为高尚的生命，假如有其中一位天使——假如虔诚的阿布德尔”（她想到了弥尔顿）——“突然被剥夺了联想的能力，我想他会很快冲出‘永恒门’，离开天堂，到地狱去寻找他的丢失的东西——是的，就在那地狱中，他因为受到蔑视的反驳又扭头回去了。
en: ‘If your world is a world without associations, Mr. Hunsden, I no longer wonder that you hate England so. I don’t dearly know what Paradise is, and what angels are, yet taking it to be the most glorious region I can conceive, and angels the most elevated existences, if one of them—if Abdiel the faithful himself’ (she was thinking of Milton)—‘were suddenly stripped of the faculty of association, I think he would soon rush forth from “the ever-during gates,” leave heaven, and seek what he had lost in hell—yes, in the very hell from which he turned “with retorted scorn.”’

zh: 弗朗西斯在说这段话的时候语调和她的措辞一样引人注目，当“地狱”这个词带着一种令人吃惊的强调语气从她的嘴里蹦出来时，亨斯登竟然降低身份投给了她一丝赞赏的目光。他喜欢刚强的性格，不管是男人还是女人；他喜欢一切敢于扫除传统限制的东西。以前他从未听到女人用那种强硬的语调说出“地狱”这个词，这声音出自一个女人之口，让他很开心；他十分乐意弗朗西斯再用那样的语气说话，但这不是她的风格。那种古怪的感情流露方式不会给她带来快乐，当碰到特殊情况——一般是痛苦情况下——这种潜藏着的燃烧的激情才会喷涌而出，而且也只表现在她的声音里，或在她的脸上稍纵即逝。曾经有一两回在我们的亲密谈话中，她曾以强健有力的语言向我说过她的大胆想法；但是像这样的时刻一过，我就不能回忆起她当时的那种表现——因为那种表现是自己出现又自己消失的。她对亨斯登的鼓励报之一笑，又回到争论的话题上，说道：
en: Frances’ tone in saying this was as marked as her language, and it was when the word ‘hell’ twanged off from her lips, with a somewhat startling emphasis, that Hunsden deigned to bestow one slight glance of admiration.He liked something strong, whether in man or woman; he liked whatever dared to clear conventional limits.He had never before heard a lady say ‘hell’ with that uncompromising sort of accent, and the sound pleased him from a lady’s lips; he would fain have had Frances to strike the string again, but it was not in her way. The display of eccentric vigour never gave her pleasure, and it only sounded in her voice or flashed in her countenance when extraordinary circumstances—and those generally painful—forced it out of the depths where it burned latent.To me, once or twice, she had, in intimate conversation, uttered venturous thoughts in nervous language; but when the hour of such manifestation was past, I could not recall it—it came of itself, and of itself departed.Hunsden’s excitations she put by soon with a smile, and recurring to the theme of disputation, said,—

zh: “既然英国一无是处，为什么大陆国家都那么尊敬它？”
en: ‘Since England is nothing, why do the Continental nations respect her so?’

zh: “我原以为连小孩都不会问这样的问题，”亨斯登回答说，他每次回答都不忘谴责提问题的人是多么地愚蠢。“如果你是我的学生——我猜你曾经是离此不到百里的那个地方某个可悲的老师的学生——我肯定要罚你站在角落边忏悔自己的无知。小姐，你怎么就不明白，我们是用黄金买来了法国人的礼貌，德国人的和善以及瑞士人的卑下？”他残忍地冷嘲热讽道。
en: ‘I should have thought no child would have asked that question,’ replied Hunsden, who never at any time gave information without reproving for stupidity those who asked it of him. ‘If you had been my pupil, as I suppose you once had the misfortune to be that of a deplorable character not a hundred miles off, I would have put you in the corner for such a confession of ignorance.Why, mademoiselle, can’t you see that it is our gold which buys us French politeness, German good will, and Swiss servility?’ and he sneered diabolically.

zh: “瑞士人！”弗朗西斯听到‘卑下’这个词，立即说道。“你说我的同胞们都是十分卑下？”然后她站了起来。我忍不住低声笑了起来：她的眼睛里充满了怒火，态度也很蔑视。“你是在当着我的面侮辱瑞士么，先生？你以为我没有联想力吗？你以为我只会对阿尔卑斯山山村的邪恶与堕落不能释怀，而不考虑我的同胞们的宽宏大量，我们用鲜血换来的自由以及我们山河的天然壮丽吗？”你错了——你大错特错。”
en: ‘Swiss!’ said Frances, catching the word ‘servility.’ ‘Do you call my countrymen servile?’ And she started up. I could not suppress a low laugh: there was ire in her glance and defiance in her attitude.‘Do you abuse Switzerland to me, Mr. Hunsden?Do you think I have no associations?Do you calculate that I am prepared to dwell only on what vice and degradation may be found in Alpine villages, and to leave quite out of my heart the social greatness of my countrymen, and our blood-earned freedom, and the natural glories of our mountains?You’re mistaken—you’re mistaken.’

zh: “宽宏大量？随便你叫它什么吧，你的同胞都是精明的家伙。他们把你所说的抽象想法当做可出售的商品；他们为了成为外国国王的奴仆，在这之前已经出卖了他们的宽宏大量以及用鲜血换来的自由。”
en: ‘Social greatness?Call it what you will, your countrymen are sensible fellows.They make a marketable article of what to you is an abstract idea; they have ere this sold their social greatness and also their blood-earned freedom to be the servants of foreign kings.’

zh: “你从没有去过瑞士吧？”
en: ‘You never were in Switzerland?’

zh: “不，我去过那里两次。”
en: ‘Yes; I have been there twice.’

zh: “你对它一无所知。”
en: ‘You know nothing of it.’

zh: “我很了解。”
en: ‘I do.’

zh: “你说瑞士人都财迷心窍，就像鹦鹉说‘可怜的鹦鹉’一样，或者这儿的比利时人说英国人十分懦弱，法国人说英国人背信弃义一样。你的看法未免太不公平了。”
en: ‘And you say the Swiss are mercenary, as a parrot says “Poor Poll,” or as the Belgians here say the English are not brave, or as the French accuse them of being perfidious.There is no justice in your dictums.’

zh: “可那是事实。”
en: ‘There is truth.’

zh: “我告诉你吧，亨斯登先生，我是个很不切实际的女人，但你比我更不切实际，因为你不承认实际存在的东西。你想毁灭个人爱国主义和民族的伟大，就像一个无神论者要通过否定上帝和他本身灵魂的存在来毁灭它们一样。”
en: ‘I tell you, Mr. Hunsden, you are a more unpractical man than I am an unpractical woman, for you don’t acknowledge what really exists.You want to annihilate individual patriotism and national greatness as an atheist would annihilate God and his own soul, by denying their existence.’

zh: “你到底在想些什么？你扯远了。我想我们刚在谈关于瑞士人财迷心窍的天性。”
en: ‘Where are you flying to?You are of at a tangent.I thought we were talking about the mercenary nature of the Swiss.’

zh: “是的；就算你明天向我证明瑞士人财迷心窍（当然你没办法证明），我仍然爱瑞士。”
en: ‘We were; and if you proved to me that the Swiss are mercenary to-morrow (which you cannot do), I should love Switzerland still.’

zh: “那你就疯了，就像三月的兔子一样疯狂，竟然对装满数万亿船泥土、木头和冰雪爱得如此无法自拔。”
en: ‘You would be mad, then—mad as a March hare—to indulge in a passion for trillions of shiploads of soil, timber, snow, and ice.’

zh: “我还是没有你疯，你什么都不爱。”
en: ‘Not so mad as you who love nothing.’

zh: “我疯得有道理，你没有。“
en: ‘There’s a method in my madness; there’s none in yours.’

zh: “你的疯法就是把万物的精华都挤掉，把糟粕当做肥料，把它变成你称之为有用的东西。”
en: ‘Your method is to squeeze the sap out of creation and make manure of the refuse, by way of turning it to what you call use.’

zh: “你根本不会思考，”亨斯登说，“你这人完全没有逻辑可言。”
en: ‘You cannot reason at all,’ said Hunsden; ‘there is no logic in you.’

zh: “没有逻辑总比没有感情好，”弗朗西斯反驳道，此时她正在壁橱与桌子之间来回走着——我想她心里尽管有些不愿意，但还勉强在行为上撑着待客之道，因为她正在摆桌布，往桌上摆盘子和刀叉。
en: ‘Better to be without logic than without feeling,’ retorted Frances, who was now passing backwards and forwards from her cupboard to the table, intent, if not on hospitable thoughts, at least on hospitable deeds, for she was laying the cloth, and putting plates, knives, and forks thereon.

zh: “小姐，你刚才的话是在攻击我吗？你是说我没有感情？”
en: ‘Is that a hit at me, mademoiselle?Do you suppose I am without feeling?’

zh: “我认为你总是干涉自己以及别人的感觉，武断地认为各种感情都是不合理的，然后强压它们，因为你觉得它们都是不合逻辑。”
en: ‘I suppose you are always interfering with your own feelings and those of other people, and dogmatizing about the irrationality of this, that, and the other sentiment, and then ordering it to be suppressed because you imagine it to be inconsistent with logic.’

zh: “我做的是对的。”
en: ‘I do right.’

zh: 弗朗西斯走出去了一会儿，去了一间小小的类似于食品储藏室的房间。不久她就又回来了。
en: Frances had stepped out of sight into a sort of little pantry.She soon reappeared.

zh: “你做的是对的？哼，才不！如果你这样想就错得太离谱了。请行行好，让我到火炉边去，亨斯登先生；我要煮点东西。”（她将一个焙盘放在火上，然后搅动着盘里的东西。）“对！好像践踏上帝给予人们的一切美好的感情，尤其像爱国主义这样的感情在更大范围内传播人们的自私心理也是对的。”（她拨动着炉火，将菜端到炉火前。）
en: ‘You do right?Indeed, no!You are much mistaken if you think so.Just be so good as to let me get to the fire, Mr. Hunsden; I have something to cook.’ (An interval occupied in settling a casserole on the fire; then, while she stirred its contents.)‘Right! as if it were right to crush any pleasureable sentiment that God has given to man, especially any sentiment that, like patriotism, spreads man’s selfishness in wider circles’ (fire stirred, dish put down before it).

zh: “你出生于瑞士吗？”
en: ‘Were you born in Switzerland?’

zh: “我想是的，否则我为什么会称它为我的祖国呢？”
en: ‘I should think so, or else why should I call it my country?’

zh: “那你那英国人特有的相貌和体型从何而来呢？”
en: ‘And where did you get your English features and figure?’

zh: “我也是英国人——我的血管里流着一半英国人的血；我有权拥有两倍的爱国力量，因为我与两个高贵，自由而且幸运的国家血脉相连。”
en: ‘I am English too—half the blood in my veins is English; thus I have a right to a double power of patriotism, possessing an interest in two noble, free, and fortunate countries.’

zh: “你母亲是英国人？”
en: ‘You had an English mother?’

zh: “是的，是的，而我觉得你有一位来自月球或者乌托邦的母亲，因为你对欧洲的任何一个国家都毫无兴趣。”
en: ‘Yes, yes; and you, I suppose, had a mother from the moon or from Utopia, since not a nation in Europe has a claim on your interest?’

zh: “相反，我是一个广义上的爱国主义者，如果你能正确地理解我的话。我的祖国是这整个世界。”
en: ‘On the contrary, I’m a universal patriot, if you could understand me rightly.My country is the world.’

zh: “散播得如此广泛的同情心肯定很肤浅。您能到桌边来吗，先生？”（她在对我说话，我看起来此刻正借助着月光聚精会神地读书），“先生，可以用晚餐了。”
en: ‘Sympathies so widely diffused must be very shallow.Will you have the goodness to come to table—Monsieur’ (to me, who appeared to be now absorbed in reading by moonlight), ‘monsieur, supper is served.’

zh: 她对我说话时的语气与刚刚和亨斯登先生辩论时的语气全然不同——没有那么无礼，却更为低沉与温柔。
en: This was said in quite a different voice to that in which she had been bandying phrases with Mr. Hunsden—not so short, graver and softer.

zh: “弗朗西斯，你怎么准备了晚餐？我们没打算留在这里吃饭的。”
en: ‘Frances, what do you mean by preparing supper?We had no intention of staying.’

zh: “啊，先生，但是你们已经留在这儿了，晚饭都准备好了；你们别无选择只有吃饭了。”
en: ‘Ah, monsieur, but you have stayed, and supper is prepared; you have only the alternative of eating it.’

zh: 晚餐当然是外国风格的。两小盘可口诱人的肉，做得很精致并且摆放讲究；还有一盘沙拉和一盘法国奶酪。交战双方在吃饭期间只得暂时休战，但是一用完晚餐他们又开战了。这次争论的新题目是关于宗教偏狭思潮，亨斯登先生坚持声称宗教偏狭思潮在瑞士普遍存在，尽管弗朗西斯断言瑞士人爱好自由。这次弗朗西斯没有占上风，并不只是因为她不擅长争论，而主要是因为她自己对于这个问题的真正想法碰巧与亨斯登先生的想法很相近，她纯粹是为了站在反对的立场上而反驳他的看法。最终她放弃了，承认她和他想的一样，但她又让他注意她不认为自己打了败仗。
en: The meal was a foreign one, of course.It consisted in two small but tasty dishes of meat prepared with skill and served with nicety; a salad and fromage franÃ§ais completed it.The business of eating interposed a brief truce between the belligerents, but no sooner was supper disposed of than they were at it again.The fresh subject of dispute ran on the spirit of religious intolerance, which Mr. Hunsden affirmed to exist strongly in Switzerland, notwithstanding the professed attachment of the Swiss to freedom.Here Frances had greatly the worst of it, not only because she was unskilled to argue, but because her own real opinions on the point in question happened to coincide pretty nearly with Mr. Hunsden’s, and she only contradicted him out of opposition.At last she gave in, confessing that she thought as he thought, but bidding him take notice that she did not consider herself beaten.

zh: “那这样的话，法国人在滑铁卢也没有战败啦，”亨斯登说。
en: ‘No more did the French at Waterloo,’ said Hunsden.

zh: “这两件事之间没有可比性，”弗朗西斯反驳道；“我打的是假战争。”
en: ‘There is no comparison between the cases,’ rejoined Frances; ‘mine was a sham fight.’

zh: “不管是真是假，反正你说了算。”
en: ‘Sham or real, it’s up with you.’

zh: “不是的，虽然我既没有逻辑思维，也没有华丽的辞藻，但是当我的观点确实与你的不一样时我就会坚持己见，直到我无话可说为止；你会被我无言的决心所难倒。你提到滑铁卢！据拿破仑说，你们的威灵顿本来会在滑铁卢战败；但尽管违反了战争定律，他还是坚持了下来，他公然蔑视军事战略，铤而走险，获得了胜利。我也会像他那样做。”
en: ‘No; though I have neither logic nor wealth of words, yet in a case where my opinion really differed from yours, I would adhere to it when I had not another word to say in its defence; you should be baffled by dumb determination.You speak of Waterloo!Your Wellington ought to have been conquered there, according to Napoleon; but he persevered in spite of the laws of war, and was victorious in defiance of military tactics.I would do as he did.’

zh: “我猜你会这样做；你的身上很可能也有同样的倔强。”
en: ‘I’ll be bound for it you would; probably you have some of the same sort of stubborn stuff in you.’

zh: “要是没有，我会很遗憾的。他和特尔是兄弟，要是哪位瑞士人，不管是男是女，灵魂里没有我们民族英雄威廉的忍耐力，我都会表示蔑视。”
en: ‘I should be sorry if I had not. He and Tell were brothers, and I’d scorn the Swiss, man or woman, who had none of the much-enduring nature of our heroic William in his soul.’

zh: “要是特尔像威灵顿一样，那他就是ass了。”
en: ‘If Tell was like Wellington, he was an ass.’

zh: “ass意思不是驴子吗？”弗朗西斯转过身来问我。
en: ‘Does not ass mean baudet?’ asked Frances, turning to me.

zh: “不是的，不是的，”我回答道，“它表示顽强的精神。我看到他们之间又在酝酿一场新的争论，便继续说道，“现在该走了吧。”
en: ‘No, no,’ replied I, ‘it means an esprit fort.And now,’ I continued, as I saw that fresh occasion of strife was brewing between these two, ‘it is high time to go.’

zh: 亨斯登站了起来。“再见了，”他对弗朗西斯说。“我明天就要动身回那个辉煌壮丽的英国了，也许下次再来布鲁塞尔就是十二个月后或者更长时间之后了。不管我什么时候来我都会把你找出来的，你看着吧，我会不择手段把你激得比龙还凶猛。今晚你干得不错，但是下次你得使出你的看家本领来挑战我。我想这段时间你注定会成为威廉·克里姆斯沃思夫人的。可怜的年轻太太！但是你的思想有闪光点，珍惜它，好好善待我们的教师先生吧。”
en: Hunsden rose.‘Good-bye,’ said he to Frances.‘I shall be off for this glorious England to-morrow, and it maybe twelve months or more before I come to Brussels again.Whenever I do come I’ll seek you out, and you shall see if I don’t find means to make you fiercer than a dragon.You’ve done pretty well this evening, but next interview you shall challenge me outright.Meantime you’re doomed to become Mrs. William Crimsworth, I suppose.Poor young lady!But you have a spark of spirit; cherish it, and give the professor the full benefit thereof.’

zh: “亨斯登先生你结婚了吗？”弗朗西斯突然问道。
en: ‘Are you married, Mr. Hunsden?’ asked Frances suddenly.

zh: “还没呢。我本以为你可能从我的长相上猜出我是个独身多年的新婚男人呢。”
en: ‘No.I should have thought you might have guessed I was a Benedict by my look.’

zh: “好的，不管你什么时候结婚，请不要娶一个瑞士的妻子；因为如果你开始亵渎瑞士或者咒骂它的行政区——最重要的是，如果你同时提到ass这个词和特尔的话，（我知道ass是驴子的意思，虽然先生乐于把它译为顽强的精神）——你的山村夫人某天晚上就会把她的英国新郎掐死，就像你们的莎士比亚所写的奥赛罗掐死苔丝德蒙娜一样。”
en: ‘Well, whenever you marry, don’t take a wife out of Switzerland; for if you begin blaspheming Helvetia and cursing the cantons—above all, if you mention the word ass in the same breath with the name Tell (for ass is baudet, I know, though monsieur is pleased to translate it esprit fort)—your mountain maid will some night smother her Breton-bretonnant, even as your own Shakespeare’s Othello smothered Desdemona.’

zh: “我听到你的警告了，”亨斯登说，“你也得注意啊，伙计”（他对我点了点头）。“我还想听到对摩尔人和他那温和的妻子的一段滑稽模仿，按照刚刚描述的计划，角色需要调换过来——而你得戴着我的睡帽出现。再见了，小姐！”他鞠躬吻了吻她的手，绝对地像查尔斯·格兰迪森爵士亲吻哈里特·拜伦的手一样；他还加了一句，“能死在这样的手指下将会是很有魅力的。”
en: ‘I am warned,’ said Hunsden; ‘and so are you, lad’ (nodding to me).‘I hope yet to hear of a travesty of the Moor and his gentle lady, in which the parts shall be reversed according to the plan just sketched—you, however, being in my nightcap.Farewell, mademoiselle!’ He bowed on her hand, absolutely like Sir Charles Grandison on that of Harriet Byron; adding, ‘Death from such fingers would not be without charms.’

zh: “上帝呀！”弗朗西斯张大眼睛，耸起她很弯的眉毛，低声说道，“你在恭维我！我可不期望这样。”她笑着，半忿怒，半开心，还向他行了一个外国式的屈膝礼，他们就这样分开了。
en: ‘Mon Dieu!’ murmured Frances, opening her large eyes and lifting her distinctly arched brows; ‘c’est qu‘il fait des compliments!je ne m’y suis pas attendu.’ She smiled, half in ire, half in mirth, curtsied with foreign grace, and so they parted.

zh: 我们一走到街上亨斯登就抓住我的衣领。
en: No sooner had we got into the street than Hunsden collared me.

zh: “那就是你修补花边的女工？”他说，“你认为你主动提出要娶她是干了一件高尚的善事？你作为西科姆家族的后代，竟然通过与做工的姑娘恋爱来证明你藐视社会地位。我怜悯你这种人，知道是你的感情将你误导，也知道与地位低下的人恋爱只是在伤害自己。”
en: ‘And that is your lace-mender?’ said he; ‘and you reckon you have done a fine, magnanimous thing in offering to marry her?You, a scion of Seacombe, have proved your disdain of social distinctions by taking up with an ouvriÃ¨re!And I pitied the fellow, thinking his feelings had misled him, and that he had hurt himself by contracting a low match!’

zh: “放开我的领子，亨斯登。”
en: ‘Just let go my collar, Hunsden.’

zh: 他不但没放手，还抓着我来回摇摆；我扭住他的腰。天色暗了，街上孤零零地，没有路灯。我们就这样互相拉扯着；后来两人都滚到人行道上，我们艰难地站了起来，最后彼此都冷静下来，继续往前走着。
en: On the contrary, he swayed me to and fro; I grappled him round the waist.It was dark, the street lonely and lampless.We had then a tug for it; and after we had both rolled on the pavement, and with difficulty picked ourselves up, we agreed to walk on more soberly.

zh: “是的，那就是我的修补花边的女工，”我说，“她会终生都是我的——这是上帝的意愿。”
en: ‘Yes, that’s my lace-mender,’ said I; ‘and she is to be mine for life—God willing.’

zh: “上帝没有这样的意愿——你不能想当然。你有什么资格配娶这么好的老婆？她对你又很尊敬，总是叫你‘先生’，跟你说话时声调都变了，好像你的地位很崇高似的！如果她有幸被我选中而不是你，我想她也不会对我表现得更尊重。”
en: ‘God is not willing—you can’t suppose it. What business have you to be suited so well with a partner?And she treats you with a sort of respect, too, and says “monsieur,” and modulates her tone in addressing you, actually as if you were something superior!She could not evince more deference to such a one as I, were she favoured by fortune to the supreme extent of being my choice instead of yours.’

zh: “亨斯登，你就是个目中无人的人。但你只是看到了我幸福的扉页；你不知道接下来的故事；你无法想象出里面的情节是多么地有趣，甜密而又令人兴奋。”
en: ‘Hunsden, you’re a puppy.But you’ve only seen the title-page of my happiness; you don’t know the tale that follows; you cannot conceive the interest and sweet variety and thrilling excitement of the narrative.’

zh: 亨斯登说话声音十分低沉，因为我们已经走进了一条比较繁忙的街道——他想让我保持安静，威胁说如果我再自吹自擂让他生气的话，他就要做出令人不快的事情。我笑了起来，一直笑到肚子疼。不一会儿我们就到了他住的宾馆；在进去前，他说道：
en: Hunsden—speaking low and deep, for we had now entered a busier street—desired me to hold my peace, threatening to do something dreadful if I stimulated his wrath further by boasting.I laughed till my sides ached.We soon reached his hotel; before he entered it, he said,—

zh: “不要狂妄自大。你的缝补工配你是有余的，但是配我还不够格。无论是长相还是品质她都达不到我理想中的女人的标准。达不到；我所想象的女人比你那位有着苍白的脸色又容易激动的小瑞士人强很多倍。（顺便说一下，她很像那种疯疯癫癫的活泼的巴黎女人，而不像健壮的‘少女’”）。你的亨利小姐与我理想的女人相比，相貌上不算出众，思想上缺乏个性。确实只有你能够容忍这种小黄毛丫头；但是如果我要结婚的话我一定要找一个更体面更端庄的女人，更别提身材也要比你那位倔强而又命运不济的小丫头更高雅而且有韵味。”
en: ‘Don’t be vainglorious. Your lace-mender is too good for you, but not good enough for me. Neither physically nor morally does she come up to my ideal of a woman.No; I dream of something far beyond that pale-faced, excitable little Helvetian (by-the-bye, she has infinitely more of the nervous, mobile Parisienne in her than of the robust “jungfrau”).Your Mdlle. Henri is in person chétive, in mind sans caractère, compared with the queen of my visions.You, indeed, may put up with that minors chiffonne; but when I marry I must have straighter and more harmonious features, to say nothing of a nobler and better-developed shape than that perverse, ill-thriven child can boast.’

zh: “如果你愿意的话就去贿赂六翼天使让她为你从天上取一块木炭，”我说，“用它为鲁宾斯所画的最高挑、最丰腴、最柔软无骨、最有血色的女人点燃生命；就把阿尔卑斯山下的小精灵留给我，我也不会羡慕你的。”
en: ‘Bribe a seraph to fetch you a coal of fire from heaven, if you will,’ said I, ‘and with it kindle life in the tallest, fattest, most boneless, fullest-blooded of Rubens’s painted women; leave me only my Alpine peri, and I’ll not envy you.’

zh: 我们同时转过身背对着对方。彼此都没有说“上帝保佑你”，而第二天我们之间就翻云倒海了。
en: With a simultaneous movement each turned his back on the other.Neither said ‘God bless you;’ yet on the morrow the sea was to roll between us.

zh: 第二十五章
en: CHAPTER XXV

zh: 又过了两个月，弗朗西斯为她姑妈的服丧期满了。一月的一个早晨——那是新年假期的第一天——我只在范登赫顿先生的陪同下乘坐着出租马车去了内日河畔的圣母大街；我独自下车，上了楼，看见弗朗西斯显然在等我，她那单薄的穿着与那寒冷又有霜冻的明朗天气很不相符。直到今天为止，除了黑色或者暗淡色外，我还从未见她穿过其他颜色的衣服。而现在，她一袭白衣，站在窗边，那白衣的质地最为柔软。她的衣饰确实非常朴素，但显得华贵而喜庆，因为它如此清新、宽松而飘逸。一块面纱盖住了她的头，一直垂到膝盖以下；一顶用粉色花朵编成的小花冠将面纱牢系在她那浓密的希腊式大辫子上，因此面纱柔顺地垂在脸两侧。有点奇怪的是，她在哭，或者之前在哭；我问她有没有准备好是，她说：“好了，先生”，好像在强忍着啜泣；当我拿起放在桌上的披肩裹在她身上时，不仅她的泪水一滴滴不由自主地顺着脸颊往下流，她自己也像一根芦苇似的靠着我颤抖着。我说，我看见她情绪这么低落很是伤心，问她能否告诉我伤心的原因，她只是说：“我就是控制不住，”然后主动，但又有些慌乱地将手放入我的手中，陪我走出房间，摇晃着匆匆跑下楼，就像是一个急于完成一件可怕的事情的人。我将她抱入出租马车。范登赫顿先生接住了她，让她坐在自己身旁。我们一起乘马车到了新教教堂，完成了英国国教祈祷书所记录的宗教仪式，走出教堂时，我们就是夫妻了。范登赫顿先生将新娘交给了我。
en: In two months more Frances had fulfilled the time of mourning for her aunt.One January morning—the first of the New Year holidays—I went in a fiacre, accompanied only by M. Vandenhuten, to the Rue Notre Dame aux Neiges; and having alighted alone and walked upstairs, I found Frances, apparently waiting for me, dressed in a style scarcely appropriate to that cold, bright, frosty day. Never till now had I seen her attired in any other than black or sad-coloured stuff, and there she stood by the window, clad all in white, and white of a most diaphanous texture.Her array was very simple, to be sure, but it looked imposing and festal because it was so clear, full, and floating.A veil shadowed her head and hung below her knee; a little wreath of pink flowers fastened it to her thickly tressed Grecian plait, and thence it fell softly on each side of her face.Singular to state, she was or had been crying; when I asked her if she were ready, she said, ‘Yes monsieur,’ with something very like a checked sob; and when I took a shawl, which lay on the table, and folded it round her, not only did tear after tear course unbidden down her cheek but she shook to my ministration like a reed.I said I was sorry to see her in such low spirits, and requested to be allowed an insight into the origin thereof She only said, ‘It was impossible to help it,’ and then voluntarily, though hurriedly putting her hand into mine, accompanied me out of the room, and ran downstairs with a quick, uncertain step, like one who was eager to get some formidable piece of business over.I put her into the fiacre.M. Vandenhuten received her, and seated her beside himself.We drove all together to the Protestant chapel, went through a certain service in the Common Prayer Book, and she and I came out married.M. Vandenhuten had given the bride away.

zh: 我们没有新婚旅行。因为我们本就朴素，地位又低下，默默无闻的。这与世隔绝之境倒也惬意，便不再强求那额外的麻烦。我们马上就搬进了我在近郊租的一间小房子，那边离我们俩工作的学校都很近。
en: We took no bridal trip.Our modesty, screened by the peaceful obscurity of our station and the pleasant isolation of our circumstances, did not exact that additional precaution.We repaired at once to a small house I had taken in the faubourg nearest to that part of the city where the scene of our avocations lay.

zh: 结婚仪式结束后三四个小时，弗朗西斯便脱下雪白的新娘礼服，穿上一条漂亮的、质地更暖和的淡紫色长袍，系上一条可爱的黑色丝绸围裙，又披上一条镶着淡紫色丝带的蕾丝披肩，在这间并不宽敞但布置得井然有序的客厅里，跪在地毯上将我从桌上拿起来递给她的书摆到五斗橱里。屋外雪下得很急；下午成了暴风雪，天气变得很冷；灰蒙蒙的天气好像充斥着雪片，街上的积雪已经深及脚踝了。我们的炉火烧得很旺，我们的新家看起来非常干净明亮，一派新气象，家具都已经摆好了，只剩下一些玻璃器皿，瓷器和书籍等需要整理。弗朗西斯一直到吃茶点时才忙完，之后我特意亲自教她怎么用地道的英国方式来煮茶，看见我往茶壶里放那么多茶叶，她吃了一惊，但冷静下来以后，她还给我张罗了一道地道的英式餐，既不缺糖果又不缺茶壶，既有火光又有舒适。
en: Three or four hours after the wedding ceremony, Frances, divested of her bridal snow, and attired in a pretty lilac gown of warmer materials, a piquant black silk apron, and a lace collar with some finishing decoration of lilac ribbon, was kneeling on the carpet of a neatly furnished though not spacious parlour, arranging on the shelves of a chiffonier some books which I handed to her from the table.It was snowing fast out of doors; the afternoon had turned out wild and cold; the leaden sky seemed full of drifts, and the street was already ankle-deep in the white downfall.Our fire burned bright, our new habitation looked brilliantly clean and fresh, the furniture was all arranged, and there were but some articles of glass, china, books, etc., to put in order.Frances found in this business occupation till tea-time, and then, after I had distinctly instructed her how to make a cup of tea in rational English style, and after she had got over the dismay occasioned by seeing such an extravagant amount of material put into the pot, she administered to me a proper British repast, at which there wanted neither candies nor urn, firelight nor comfort.

zh: 一个星期的假期转瞬即逝，我们又投入了工作中。我和妻子从一开始就都很用心地工作，我们知道自己是劳苦大众，注定要竭尽全力赚面包钱，而教师这个职业又是最辛苦的工作。我们总是一天到晚忙于工作。我们总是早上八点分别，直到下午五点才再见面。但是劳累了一天之后，我们的休息是多么甜蜜呀！追忆起那一幕幕的往事时，我感觉在那个小客厅里度过的一个个夜晚，就像一长串红宝石盘绕在往昔那昏暗的眉头上。那一长串红宝石颗颗都像打磨过的宝石一样，颗颗都灿烂夺目，如燃烧的火焰。
en: Our week’s holiday glided by, and we readdressed ourselves to labour.Both my wife and I began in good earnest with the notion that we were working people, destined to earn our bread by exertion, and that of the most assiduous kind.Our days were thoroughly occupied.We used to part every morning at eight o’clock, and not meet again till five p.m.; but into what sweet rest did the turmoil of each busy day decline!Looking down the vista of memory, I see the evenings passed in that little parlour like a long string of rubies circling the dusk brow of the past.Unvaried were they as each cut gem, and like each gem brilliant and burning.

zh: 一年半悄然而过。某天早上（那天是节日，我们不用上课）弗朗西斯突然奇怪地对我说：“我的工作不够。”每当她长时间思考一个问题，最终得到结论时就是这样的。她想用我的判断作为试金石来看看自己的想法是否正确。
en: A year and a half passed.One morning (it was a fête, and we had the day to ourselves) Frances said to me, with a suddenness peculiar to her when she had been thinking long on a subject, and at last, having come to a conclusion, wished to test its soundness by the touchstone of my judgment, ‘I don’t work enough.’

zh: “怎么了？”我从咖啡杯上抬头问道。我刚刚正一边从容不迫地搅拌着咖啡，一边愉快地想着提过的郊游计划，也就是要在那个美好的夏日（当时已是六月）带着弗朗西斯散步到乡下一间农舍去，并在那里用餐；“你说什么？”我立马从她那严肃的神情里看出她有一件至关重要的事要跟我谈。
en: ‘What now?’ demanded I, looking up from my coffee, which I had been deliberately stirring while enjoying, in anticipation, a walk I proposed to take with Frances that fine summer day (it was June) to a certain farmhouse in the country, where we were to dine; ‘what now?’ and I saw at once, in the serious ardour of her face, a project of vital importance.

zh: “我不满意。”她回答说。“您现在每年赚八千法郎”（这是真的，我工作勤奋，又很守时，学生进步的声誉以及工作的公众影响，迄今为止都在帮助我前进），“而我每年还是那可怜的一千两百法郎。我可以做得更好，我想做得更好。”
en: ‘I am not satisfied,’ returned she. ‘You are now earning eight thousand francs a year’ (it was true; my efforts, punctuality, the fame of my pupils’ progress, the publicity of my station, had so far helped me on), ‘while I am still at my miserable twelve hundred francs.I can do better, and I will.’

zh: “你和我工作一样久，一样努力，弗朗西斯。”
en: ‘You work as long and as diligently as I do, Frances.’

zh: “是的，先生；但是我工作的方式不对，这一点我很清楚。”
en: ‘Yes, monsieur; but I am not working in the right way, and I am convinced of it.’

zh: “你想改变——你脑海里现在已经有了改进的计划。你去戴上帽子，我们一边散步，你一边告诉我你的想法。”
en: ‘You wish to change—you have a plan for progress in your mind.Go and put on your bonnet; and, while we take our walk, you shall tell me of it.’

zh: “是的，先生。”
en: ‘Yes, monsieur.’

zh: 她就像一个有教养的孩子一样乖顺地去了。她就是温顺与刚强的奇怪的混合体。我坐在那儿想着她，考虑着她的计划会是什么样子，这时她又回来了。
en: She went—as docile as a well-trained child.She was a curious mixture of tractability and firmness.I sat thinking about her, and wondering what her plan could be, when she re-entered.

zh: “先生，我给明妮（我们的保姆）放了假，让她也出去走走，因为天气这么好；麻烦您锁门，带上钥匙，好吗？”
en: ‘Monsieur, I have given Minnie (our bonne) leave to go out too, as it is so very fine; so will you be kind enough to lock the door, and take the key with you?’

zh: “亲我吧，克里姆斯沃思夫人，”我的回答并不恰当；但她穿着清爽的夏装，戴上小太阳帽，看上去十分迷人，而且她和我说话的态度还像往常一样真挚温和，尊重有礼，一看到她我就会心花怒放，必须要一个吻来满足我内心的渴望。
en: ‘Kiss me, Mrs. Crimsworth,’ was my not very apposite reply; but she looked so engaging in her light summer dress and little cottage bonnet, and her manner in speaking to me was then, as always, so unaffectedly and suavely respectful, that my heart expanded at the sight of her, and a kiss seemed necessary to content its importunity.

zh: “好了，先生。”
en: ‘There, monsieur.’

zh: “你怎么总是叫我‘先生’呢？叫‘威廉’。”
en: ‘Why do you always call me “monsieur” ?Say  “William.” ’

zh: “我发不出你的W音，而且‘先生’这个称呼专属于你啊，我最喜欢它。”
en: ‘I cannot pronounce your W. Besides, “monsieur” belongs to you; I like it best.’

zh: 明妮戴上干净的帽子，披上漂亮的披肩离开后，我们也出发了，留下一栋孤独而安静的房子——如果不是钟表的滴答声，房子起码是安静的。我们很快便走出了布鲁塞尔；迎接我们的是田野以及乡间小径，远离了车声隆隆的大马路。不久我们就到了一片幽静处，很有乡土风情，树木郁郁葱葱，与世隔绝，看上去像是英国某个充满田园风光的省份的一处景点；山楂树下有一个长满小草和生苔的斜坡，形成了一个座位，十分诱人，让人不忍拒绝。我们坐了下来，赏玩了脚下的英式的野花后，我又提起了早餐时俩人所谈到的话题。
en: Minnie having departed in clean cap and smart shawl, we too set out, leaving the house solitary and silent—silent, at least, but for the ticking of the clock. We were soon clear of Brussels; the fields received us, and then the lanes, remote from carriage-resounding chausées.Ere long we came upon a nook, so rural, green, and secluded it might have been a spot in some pastoral English province; a bank of short and mossy grass, under a hawthorn, offered a seat too tempting to be declined.We took it, and when we had admired and examined some English-looking wild flowers growing at our feet, I recalled Frances’ attention and my own to the topic touched on at breakfast.

zh: “她的计划是什么呢？”如果她想在事业上提升自己的话，下一步自然就由我们，或者至少她自己去攀登了。她提议创办一所学校。我们靠着自己的收入一直过得不错，只要勤俭节约，创办学校的启动资金还是有的。而且此时我们已经有了广阔的人际关系，从有利于事业的角度讲，也有资格办学校了；因为虽然我们所来往的交际圈子还是像之前一样窄，但是现在我们作为教师，在学校以及学生家庭那里已经广为人知。弗朗西斯详尽阐述完她的计划，最后几句话还透露出她对未来的希望。她确信，只要我们身体健康，诸事顺利，我们迟早会办成一所独立的学校，也许不用等到年老力衰时就能乐见其成。那时我们都可以休息了；到那时还有什么能够阻止我们一起到英国生活呢？英国仍然是她的理想圣地。
en: ‘What was her plan?’ A natural one—the next step to be mounted by us, or at least by her, if she wanted to rise in her profession.She proposed to begin a school.We already had the means for commencing on a careful scale, having lived greatly within our income.We possessed, too, by this time, an extensive and eligible connection, in the sense advantageous to our business; for though our circle of visiting acquaintance continued as limited as ever, we were now widely known in schools and families as teachers.When Frances had developed her plan, she intimated, in some closing sentences, her hopes for the future.If we only had good health and tolerable success, we might, she was sure, in time realize an independence, and that perhaps before we were too old to enjoy it. Then both she and I would rest; and what was to hinder us from going to live in England?England was still her Promised Land.

zh: 我没有在她的前行道路上设置障碍，没有提出反对意见。我知道她不是个能够无所作为就活着的人，就算比较懒散也不行。她必须要完成一些任务，而且是重要的任务。她需要有工作做，而且是令人激动、引人入胜而且有益的工作。她的身上蕴含着强大的才能，它们需要充足的营养，并得到自由的发挥。我不会让它们挨饿或者束缚它们；不会的，我很乐意为它们提供支持，为它们拓宽施展才能的空间。
en: I put no obstacle in her way, raised no objection.I knew she was not one who could live quiescent and inactive, or even comparatively inactive.Duties she must have to fulfil, and important duties;work to do, and exciting, absorbing, profitable work.Strong faculties stirred in her frame, and they demanded full nourishment, free exercise.Mine was not the hand ever to starve or cramp them; no, I delighted in offering them sustenance, and in clearing them wider space for action.

zh: “你已经构想出一个计划，弗朗西斯，”我说，“一个很好的计划；着手去实施吧。我绝对赞同，只要你需要我的帮助，我随时随地都会帮助你的。“
en: ‘You have conceived a plan, Frances,’ said I, ‘and a good plan; execute it. You have my free consent, and wherever and whenever my assistance is wanted, ask and you shall have.’

zh: 弗朗西斯的眼眶中几乎充满了感激的泪水，不过只是一两滴泪珠，瞬间便擦掉了。她也抓住我的手，双手紧紧地握了很久，但她只是说：“谢谢您，先生。”
en: Frances’ eyes thanked me almost with tears, just a sparkle or two, soon brushed away.She possessed herself of my hand too, and held it for some time very close clasped in both her own, but she said no more than ‘Thank you, monsieur.’

zh: 我们过了极其美好的一天，回家很晚，一轮夏日满月照亮了我们回家的路。
en: We passed a divine day, and came home late, lighted by a full summer moon.

zh: 如今十年时光已经带着满是灰尘的翅膀不断地扑闪着从我身边掠过——这是繁忙的十年，奋斗的十年，毫不松懈的十年；这十年来，我和妻子施尽全力推行着我们的计划，就像一连串欧洲各国首都的发展计划一样，我们几乎不知道休息，也从不纵情享乐；在我们肩并肩，手挽手的前进过程中，都从未抱怨、后悔或者踌躇过。希望确实激励着我们；健康支持着我们；想法与行动的一致克服了很多困难，最终成功不时对我们的勤劳给予鼓励性的回报。我们的学校成为布鲁塞尔最受欢迎的学校之一，随着我们逐步提高学费，改善教育体制，我们挑选学生也更加苛刻，甚至后来还有来自比利时最有名望的家族的孩子们。我们在英国也有了很好的渠道，首先是由亨斯登先生主动提出推荐而开辟的，他来过一次，臭骂我竟如此顺利地调整了学费，回去之后不久就送来了某某郡的三位女继承人——他的几位表妹；就像他说的，“让克里姆斯沃思夫人打磨一下。”
en: Ten years rushed now upon me with dusty, vibrating, unresting wings—years of bustle, action, unslacked endeavour; years in which I and my wife, having launched ourselves in the full career of progress, as progress whirls on in European capitals, scarcely knew repose, were strangers to amusement, never thought of indulgence, and yet, as our course ran side by side, as we marched hand in hand, we neither murmured, repented, nor faltered.Hope indeed cheered us; health kept us up; harmony of thought and deed smoothed many difficulties, and finally success bestowed every now and then encouraging reward on diligence.Our school became one of the most popular in Brussels, and as by degrees we raised our terms and elevated our system of education, our choice of pupils grew more select, and at length included the children of the best families in Belgium.We had too an excellent connection in England, first opened by the unsolicited recommendation of Mr. Hunsden, who having been over, and having abused me for my prosperity in set terms, went back, and soon after sent a leash of young —shire heiresses—his cousins; as he said, ‘to be polished off by Mrs. Crimsworth.’

zh: 至于那位克里姆斯沃思夫人，在某个方面讲她已经变成另一个女人，尽管从另一个方面讲她还没有变。她在不同情况下简直迥然不同，我似乎有着两个妻子。她的天生才干在我和她结婚时便已展现，现在仍然朝气蓬勃，讨人喜爱；而其他方面的才能也在迅速成长，抽枝发芽，大大地改变了她原有的外在性格。之前的倔强好动积极上进，已被严肃的外表以及诗人般的感情和热情所掩盖；但是这些花儿依然生长在那里，在后来成长的有着更为坚强本性的树阴之中保持着当初的纯洁和雨露。也许在这世界上只有我知道它们的存在这个秘密，但是对于我，它们随时都散发着精美的芬芳，展现出光芒四射的高雅之美。
en: As to this same Mrs. Crimsworth, in one sense she was become another woman, though in another she remained unchanged.So different was she under different circumstances, I seemed to possess two wives.The faculties of her nature already disclosed when I married her, remained fresh and fair; but other faculties shot up strong, branched out broad, and quite altered the external character of the plant.Firmness activity, and enterprise covered with grave foliage poetic feeling and fervour; but these flowers were still there, preserved pure and dewy under the umbrage of later growth and hardier nature.Perhaps I only in the world knew the secret of their existence, but to me they were ever ready to yield an exquisite fragrance and present a beauty as chaste as radiant.

zh: 在白天，我的家和学校都是由这位女校长夫人主管，她庄严而优雅，那宽大的额头上挂着很多思虑，严肃的神情中带有适当的尊严。一吃完早饭我便和这位夫人道别。我要去我的学校，她要去她的教室。我一天就回来一个小时，总是看见她在教室里一心一意地忙碌着——沉默寡言，孜孜不倦，极为细心。当她没有课时，也会监督着，用眼神和手势指导他人；那时她显得警惕而又细心。上课时，她的表情更为活泼，似乎在教书中找到了某种快乐。她对学生说话时语言简洁而不做作，从不会用陈词滥调。她不依常规说话，而是有一套自己的措辞，她说话时经常会出现一些强健有力而又发人深省的句子；讲述历史或者地理里她最爱的章节时，她便会滔滔不绝地认真讲。她的学生们，至少那些年长或者比较聪明的学生们，清楚地认识到她语言中体现的出众的思维。他们也感觉到了她的高尚品德，这给其中有些人留下深刻印象。这位老师并没有溺爱这些学生，但是弗朗西斯的一些学生们后来还是学会真心真意地爱上了她，所有学生都很尊敬她。她对她们的态度总的来说是严肃的，有时当她们取得进步或者认真听讲让她很高兴时，她的态度会和蔼一些，但她总是很谨慎地表现出优雅与体贴。有时当需要责备或者处罚学生时，她总是竭力忍耐；但是如果有人利用她的忍耐不知悔改——这情况时有发生，她就会像闪电一样突然变得严厉起来，让这样的学生知道他们犯的错误有多严重。有时她的眼睛和举止中会透露出一丝对学生的温和之情，但是那很少见，只有当某位学生生病了，或者想家了，或者面对某个没有妈妈的小孩，或者某个比其他同学都要穷的孩子，因为衣着简朴，用具简陋，而受到那些穿金戴银的年轻女伯爵或者衣着光鲜的小姐们的嘲笑时。遇到这些羽翼未丰的小鸟，女校长便会张开最仁慈的翅膀保护她们。晚上她会到她们的床边给她们掖一下被子，让她们睡得暖和；冬天她会照顾她们，让她们总能舒服地坐在火炉边；她把她们轮流叫到客厅里，给她们一些小蛋糕或者水果，让她们坐在火炉旁边的脚凳上，一起享受一晚家庭的温暖，甚至可以说家庭自由，她温和地跟她们说话，安慰她们，鼓励她们，珍视她们，到了睡觉时间就会温柔地亲吻她们，让她们回去睡觉。对于一位英国准男爵的的女儿茱莉亚和乔治亚娜，以及一位比利时伯爵的女继承人马蒂尔德·某某小姐，以及其他各种贵族小姐，女校长会像对待其他人一样关怀她们，像对待其他人一样渴望她们的进步；但是在她脑海中绝没有偏爱她们，对她们区分对待的想法。她非常喜爱其中一位贵族女孩，那是位年轻的爱尔兰女男爵，凯瑟琳小姐；但是那是因为她为人热心，又很聪明，慷慨大方，富有天分，与头衔和地位毫无关系。
en: In the daytime my house and establishment were conducted by madame the directress, a stately and elegant woman, bearing much anxious thought on her large brow, much calculated dignity in her serious mien.Immediately after breakfast I used to part with this lady.I went to my college, she to her schoolroom.Returning for an hour in the course of the day, I found her always in class, intently occupied—silence, industry, observance attending on her presence.When not actually teaching, she was overlooking and guiding by eye and gesture; she then appeared vigilant and solicitous.When communicating instruction, her aspect was more animated; she seemed to feel a certain enjoyment in the occupation.The language in which she addressed her pupils, though simple and unpretending, was never trite or dry. She did not speak from routine formulas—she made her own phrases as she went on, and very nervous and impressive phrases they frequently were; often, when elucidating favourite points of history or geography, she would wax genuinely eloquent in her earnestness.Her pupils, or at least the elder and more intelligent amongst them, recognized well the language of a superior mind.They felt too, and some of them received the impression of elevated sentiments.There was little fondling between mistress and girls, but some of Frances’ pupils in time learnt to love her sincerely, all of them beheld her with respect.Her general demeanour towards them was serious, sometimes benignant when they pleased her with their progress and attention, always scrupulously refined and considerate.In cases where reproof or punishment was called for she was usually forbearing enough; but if any took advantage of that forbearance, which sometimes happened, a sharp, sudden, and lightning-like severity taught the culprit the extent of the mistake committed.Sometimes a gleam of tenderness softened her eyes and manner, but this was rare—only when a pupil was sick, or when it pined after home, or in the case of some little motherless child, or of one much poorer than its companions, whose scanty wardrobe and mean appointments brought on it the contempt of the jewelled young countesses and silk-dad misses.Over such feeble fledglings the directress spread a wing of kindliest protection.It was to their bedsides she came at night to tuck them warmly in; it was after them she looked in winter to see that they always had a comfortable seat by the stove; it was they who by turns were summoned to the salon to receive some little dole of cake or fruit—to sit on a footstool at the fireside—to enjoy home comforts, and almost home liberty, for an evening together—to be spoken to gently and softly, comforted, encouraged, cherished, and, when bedtime came, dismissed with a kiss of true tenderness.As to Julia and Georgiana G-, daughters of an English baronet, as to Mdlle. Mathilde de-, heiress of a Belgian count, and sundry other children of patrician race, the directress was careful of them as of the others, anxious for their progress as for that of the rest; but it never seemed to enter her head to distinguish them by a mark of preference.One girl of noble blood she loved dearly—a young Irish baroness—Lady Catherine; but it was for her enthusiastic heart and clever head, for her generosity and her genius—the title and rank went for nothing.

zh: 我下午也在学校里度过，我妻子要求我每天去她学校一个小时，这一点她从不让步。她说我那段时间必须跟她的学生在一起，以便了解她们的性格，熟悉那栋房子里发生的一切，她感兴趣的我也要感兴趣，在她需要我的意见时我要能够在一些棘手的问题上提出自己的看法；她一直这样做着，绝不允许我对学生们的兴趣减少，在没有得到我的认定和同意之前，她从不会做任何重大的改变。当我讲课时（文学课），她喜欢坐在我旁边，双手叠放在膝盖上，比在场的其他人都要聚精会神。课堂上她很少和我说话；就是说话时也明显地带着恭敬的神色。她很乐意，也很高兴仍让我在一切事情上做主。
en: My afternoons were spent also in college, with the exception of an hour that my wife daily exacted of me for her establishment, and with which she would not dispense.She said that I must spend that time amongst her pupils to learn their characters, to be au courant with everything that was passing in the house, to become interested in what interested her, to be able to give her my opinion on knotty points when she required it; and this she did constantly, never allowing my interest in the pupils to fall asleep, and never making any change of importance without my cognizance and consent.She delighted to sit by me when I gave my lessons (lessons in literature), her hands folded on her knee, the most fixedly attentive of any present.She rarely addressed me in class; when she did, it was with an air of marked deference.It was her pleasure, her joy, to make me still the master in all things.

zh: 下午六点钟，我一天的工作结束了。之后我会回到家里，因为家就是我的天堂。每次那个时候，当我走进我们的私人起居室时，女校长夫人就从我的眼前消失，我的小缝补花边女工弗朗西斯·亨利又奇迹般地回到我的怀中。如果她的老师没有像她自己那样持续赴约，如果当她温柔地说“晚上好，先生”时，她的老师没有立即报以真诚的一吻，那她就会很失望。
en: At six o‘clock p.m. my daily labours ceased.I then came home, for my home was my heaven.Ever at that hour, as I entered our private sitting-room, the lady directress vanished from before my eyes, and Frances Henri, my own little lace-mender, was magically restored to my arms.Much disappointed she would have been if her master had not been as constant to the tryst as herself, and if his truthful kiss had not been prompt to answer her soft, ‘Bon soir, monsieur.’

zh: 她总是对我说法语，因为她这固执我已经多次惩罚她。我觉得我对她的惩罚手段很不慎重，因为这不但没有改正她的缺点，却似乎还使她变本加厉。夜晚是属于我们自己的；此时的放松对于恢复我们的体力，应付第二天的工作很有必要。有时我们整个晚上都在谈话，我年轻的日内瓦女士现在因为已经完全适应了她的英国老师，因为她爱他爱得太深所以都没有对他心存畏惧了，她对他有着无限的信任，所以她和他已经是无所不谈，就好像和自己的心灵交流一样自由。那时，她就会像和同伴在一起的小鸟一样幸福，她会向我展示她那优良天性里的活泼、愉悦和奇特之处。她也会展示她暗藏的逗趣与调皮的品质，有时她会称呼包括我在内的英国人为“古怪的英国佬”和“反复无常的岛民”来激怒我、嘲笑我、刺伤我的自尊心，她说这些话时带着一种狂野而又诙谐的邪恶，活生生地像一个无害的小恶魔。但是这很少发生，而且这种精灵般捣蛋行径也总是很短暂。她总是用法语攻击我，因为她的舌头能够将她母语的精髓、要点和精致表现到极致，有时在论战中我词穷时，会以一贯的果断对她展开反攻，伸手去抓这个戏弄我的小精灵。可这毫无用处！我一抓到她的手或者胳膊，这个小精灵就不见了；那挑衅似的微笑在她深情的褐色眼睛中消失了，取而代之的是出现在眼睑下温和而尊敬的光芒。我抓住的只是一个让人苦恼的小仙女，怀中抱的是一个柔顺、乞求宽恕的人间小女人。那时我就会让她拿出一本书，读一个小时的英语给我听，以做惩罚。我常常通过这种方式让她读华兹华斯的诗，因为他很快就会让她安静下来。她很难理解华兹华斯那深奥、平静而审慎的思想。他的语言对她来说也不容易懂。她只得问问题，寻求解释，就像一个小孩，像个生手一样，不得不承认我是她的长者和老师。她的天分使她立即就能洞察并且掌握那些思想更激烈又更富有想象力的作家的作品涵义。拜伦使她激动，司各特令她爱慕，只有华兹华斯让她既十分迷惑又很惊叹，并且不敢对他妄加评述。
en: Talk French to me she would, and many a punishment she has had for her wilfulness.I fear the choice of chastisement must have been injudicious, for instead of correcting the fault, it seemed to encourage its renewal.Our evenings were our own; that recreation was necessary to refresh our strength for the due discharge of our duties.Sometimes we spent them all in conversation, and my young Genevese, now that she was thoroughly accustomed to her English professor, now that she loved him too absolutely to fear him much, reposed in him a confidence so unlimited that topics of conversation could no more be wanting with him than subjects for communion with her own heart.In those moments, happy as a bird with its mate, she would show me what she had of vivacity, of mirth, of originality in her well-dowered nature.She would show, too, some stores of raillery, of malice, and would vex, tease, pique me sometimes about what she called my bizarreries anglaises, my caprices insulaires, with a wild and witty wickedness that made a perfect white demon of her while it lasted.This was rare, however, and the elfish freak was always short.Sometimes when driven a little hard in the war of words—for her tongue did ample justice to the pith, the point, the delicacy of her native French, in which language she always attacked me—I used to turn upon her with my old decision, and arrest bodily the sprite that teased me.Vain idea!no sooner had I grasped hand or arm than the elf was gone; the provocative smile quenched in the expressive brown eyes, and a ray of gentle homage shone under the lids in its place.I had seized a mere vexing fairy, and found a submissive and supplicating little mortal woman in my arms.Then I made her get a look and read English to me for an hour by way of penance.I frequently dosed her with Wordsworth in this way, and Wordsworth steadied her soon.She had a difficulty in comprehending his deep, serene, and sober mind.His language, too, was not facile to her.She had to ask questions, to sue for explanations, to be like a child and a novice, and to acknowledge me as her senior and director.Her instinct instantly penetrated and possessed the meaning of more ardent and imaginative writers.Byron excited her; Scott she loved; Wordsworth only she puzzled at, wondered over, and hesitated to pronounce an opinion upon.

zh: 但是不管她给我读书还是陪我说话，不管她用法语嘲笑我还是用英语哀求我；不管她用小聪明打趣我还是顺从地询问我；不管她饶有兴趣地向我诉说，还是聚精会神地倾听着我说话；不管她嘲笑我还是赞许我，九点的时候她就丢下我——抛弃我。她会从我的手臂中挣脱开，离开我身边，提着灯消失不见。她的任务就在楼上。有时我会跟踪并观察她。她先打开宿舍的门（学生宿舍），从两排长长的白色床边悄悄走过，查看所有睡觉的学生。如果有人还是醒的，尤其是有人在伤心的话，她就会跟她们说话，安慰她们，站在那儿几分钟以确定所有的人都安然无事，之后便调调公寓里那个整夜都亮着的照明灯，然后无声无息地离开宿舍并随手关上宿舍门。然后她又溜回我们自己的房间。房间里有个小房间。她摸进里面。那里面也有一张床，一张很小的床；她一靠近那个小沙发床表情就变了（那晚我跟踪她，观察着她）。表情由严肃变成温和与诚挚；她一手遮住另一只手上提着的灯；身子弯向枕边熟睡的婴儿。那小孩睡得又十分香甜（至少那晚是那样，我相信平时也是那样）；没有眼泪打湿他黑色的眼睫毛；没有发热染红他圆圆的脸颊；没有噩梦打搅他如花蕾般的面容。弗朗西斯注视着他，她没有笑，但是内心里充斥着深切的欢喜，她的脸上泛起了红晕。一种快乐又强烈的感情在仍一动不动的全身上下翻动着。我的确看见她的心脏起伏，嘴唇微张，呼吸有些加快。孩子笑了，最终母亲也笑了，轻声地自言自语道，“上帝保佑我的小儿子！”她又弯了弯腰靠他更近些，用最温柔的吻吻着他的额头，用她的手盖住他的小手，最终站起身离去。我在她之前回到了客厅。两分钟之后她进来了，一边放下已经灭了的灯一边轻轻地说：
en: But whether she read to me or talked with me; whether she teased me in French or entreated me in English; whether she jested with wit or inquired with deference, narrated with interest or listened with attention; whether she smiled at me or on me, always at nine o‘clock I was left—abandoned.She would extricate herself from my arms, quit my side, take her lamp, and be gone.Her mission was upstairs.I have followed her sometimes and watched her.First she opened the door of the dortior (the pupils’ chamber), noiselessly she glided up the long room between the two rows of white beds, surveyed all the sleepers.If any were wakeful, especially if any were sad spoke to them and soothed them, stood some minutes to ascertain that all was safe and tranquil, trimmed the watchlight which burned in the apartment all night, then withdrew closing the door behind her without sound.Thence she glided to our own chamber.It had a little cabinet within.This she sought.There, too, appeared a bed but one, and that a very small one; her face (the night I followed and observed her) changed as she approached this tiny couch.From grave it warmed to earnest; she shaded with one hand the lamp she held in the other; she bent above the pillow and hung over a child asleep.Its slumber (that evening, at least, and usually, I believe) was sound and calm; no tear wet its dark eyelashes; no fever heated its round cheek; no ill dream discomposed its budding features.Frances gazed; she did not smile, and yet the deepest delight filled, flushed her face.Feeling, pleasurable, powerful, worked in her whole frame, which still was motionless.I saw, indeed, her heart heave, her lips were a little apart, her breathing grew somewhat hurried.The child smiled; then at last the mother smiled too, and said in low soliloquy, ‘God bless my little son!’ She stooped closer over him, breathed the softest of kisses on his brow, covered his minute hand with hers, and at last started up and came away.I regained the parlour before her.Entering it two minutes later, she said quietly as she put down her extinguished lamp,—

zh: “维克托睡得好着呢。睡的时候还笑。他的笑容跟您的一样，先生。”
en: ‘Victor rests well.He smiled in his sleep.He has your smile, monsieur.’

zh: 这里的维克托当然是她的亲生儿子，是在我们婚后第三年出生的。给他取这个洗礼名是为了表示对范登赫顿先生的敬意，范登赫顿先生一直都是我们值得信赖和尊敬的朋友。
en: The said Victor was, of course, her own boy, born in the third year of our marriage.His Christian name had been given him in honour of M. Vandenhuten, who continued always our trusty and well-beloved friend.

zh: 那时弗朗西斯是我亲爱的好妻子，因为我是她正直而忠实的好丈夫。假如她嫁给了一个苛刻无情，嫉妒好胜又淡漠随便的男人——一个放荡之人，一个挥金如土之人，一个酒鬼或者一个专制的人，她会怎么样——那就是另一种情况了，并且这是我曾经向她提出过的一个问题。她想了片刻后回答道：
en: Frances was, then, a good and dear wife to me, because I was to her a good, just, and faithful husband.What she would have been had she married a harsh, envious, careless man—a profligate, a prodigal, a drunkard, or a tyrant—is another question, and one which I once propounded to her.Her answer, given after some reflection, was,—

zh: “我会试图忍受那个魔鬼一段时间，或者帮助他改正缺点；如果我发现那确实无法忍受并且无可救药后，我会悄悄地突然离开那个折磨我的人。”
en: ‘I should have tried to endure the evil or cure it for a while; and when I found it intolerable and incurable, I should have left my torturer suddenly and silently.’

zh: “如果法律或者强权又强迫你回到他的身边呢？”
en: ‘And if law or might had forced you back again?’

zh: “什么！回到一个酒鬼，一个放荡之人，一个自私的挥金如土的人，一个不正直的傻瓜身边？”
en: ‘What! to a drunkard, a profligate, a selfish spendthrift, an unjust fool?’

zh: “是啊。”
en: ‘Yes.’

zh: “那我会再回到他身边，再次弄清楚他的罪恶是否能得救，我的痛苦是否能平复，如果不能的话，我会再次离开他。”
en: ‘I would have gone back, again assured myself whether or not his vice and my misery were capable of remedy, and if not, have left him again.’

zh: “假如再次逼迫你回到他身边，强迫你忍受呢？”
en: ‘And if again forced to return and compelled to abide?’

zh: “我不知道，”她匆匆地回答说，“你为什么问我这个呢，先生？”
en: ‘I don’t know,’ she said hastily.‘Why do you ask me, monsieur?’

zh: 我想要一个答案，因为我看见她眼睛里有一种奇怪的幽灵，我想唤醒那个幽灵的声音。
en: I would have an answer, because I saw a strange kind of spirit in her eye, whose voice I determined to waken.

zh: “先生，如果一个妻子与她所嫁的人本性不和，那他们的婚姻肯定就是一种奴隶制。所有正直的思想家都会反对奴隶制，虽然反抗的代价可能是痛苦折磨，但是要敢于直面折磨。尽管通往自由的唯一之路是穿过死亡之门，但是那些门是必须要穿过的，因为自由是不可或缺的。那么，先生，我会用尽全力去反抗；当我心力交瘁时，我就会找到避难之所。死亡肯定可以使我逃脱不正义的法律和这种法律所带来的恶果。”
en: ‘Monsieur, if a wife’s nature loathes that of the man she is wedded to, marriage must he slavery.Against slavery all right thinkers revolt, and though torture be the price of resistance, torture must be dared.Though the only road to freedom lie through the gates of death, those gates must be passed, for freedom is indispensable.Then, monsieur, I would resist as far as my strength permitted; when that strength failed I should be sure of a refuge.Death would certainly screen me both from bad laws and their consequences.

zh: “自愿去死吗，弗朗西斯？”
en: ‘Voluntary death, Frances?’

zh: “不是的，先生。我要有勇气撑过命运安排给我的每份痛苦，力争为正义和自由斗争到底。“
en: ‘No, monsieur.I’d have courage to live out every throe of anguish fate assigned me, and principle to contend for justice and liberty to the last.’

zh: “我看你是做不成一位耐心的老太太的。现在假使命运只安排你做一位老处女，那你怎么办？你会喜欢那种独身生活吗？”
en: ‘I see you would have made no patient Grizzle.And now, supposing fate had merely assigned you the lot of an old maid, what then?How would you have liked celibacy?’

zh: “当然不喜欢了。老处女的生活肯定是空虚单调的，她的心灵因受压抑而空虚。如果我是一位老处女，我会终生努力去填充那种空虚，减少痛楚。我很有可能会失败，像其他单身女人一样劳累而失望地死去，受人鄙视，没有价值。但我不是一位老处女，”她很快地补上一句,“尽管要不是因为我的老师，我可能也是了。除了克里姆斯沃思老师外我不会钟意任何男人——没有任何绅士，不论是法国人，英国人还是比利时人，会认为我可爱美丽；如果他们对我表示认可的话，我想我也会不屑一顾的，现在我已经当了八年的克里姆斯沃思老师的妻子，他在我的眼里是什么样子的呢？他正直吗，值得人爱吗——”她停住了；她的声音突然停止，眼睛突然充满泪水。我们正肩并肩地站着。她突然抱住了我，热情而真诚地将我紧紧抱在她的胸前。她全身的能量都在那睁大的深色的眼睛中燃烧，映红了她那充满生气的脸颊。她的表情和动作就像是得到了神的指示；一个闪闪发光，一个充满力量。半个小时之后，当她冷静下来，我问她那狂野的激情去哪儿了，那激情刚刚使她顷刻间变了一个人，并使她的目光如此勾人魂魄和热切，她的动作如此快速而有力。她低下头，温和而勉强地一笑。
en: ‘Not much, certainly.An old maid’s life must doubtless be void and vapid, her heart strained and empty.Had I been an old maid, I should have spent existence in efforts to fill the void and ease the aching.I should have probably failed, and died weary and disappointed, despised and of no account, like other single women.But I’m not an old maid,’ she added quickly, ‘I should have been, though, but for my master.I should never have suited any man but Professor Crimsworth—no other gentleman, French, English, or Belgian, would have thought me amiable or handsome; and I doubt whether I should have cared for the approbation of many others, if I could have obtained it. Now, I have been Professor Crimsworth’s wife eight years, and what is he in my eyes?Is he honourable, beloved—’ She stopped; her voice was cut off, her eyes suddenly suffused.She and I were standing side by side.She threw her arms round me, and strained me to her heart with passionate earnestness.The energy of her whole being glowed in her dark and then dilated eye, and crimsoned her animated cheek.Her look and movement were like inspiration; in one there was such a flash, in the other such a power.Half an hour afterwards, when she had become calm I asked where all that wild vigour was gone which had transformed her erewhile and made her glance so thrilling and ardent, her action so rapid and strong.She looked down, smiling softly and passively.

zh: “我也不知道它去哪儿了，先生，”她说，“但是我知道只要有需要的话，它就会再回来。”
en: ‘I cannot tell where it is gone, monsieur,’ said she,‘but I know that, whenever it is wanted, it will come back again.’

zh: 现在仔细看看十年后的我们吧，我们已经建立了我们当初所希望的独立学校。我们能这么快获得这样的结局有三个原因。第一，我们为此很努力地工作；第二，我们没碰到什么推迟成功的阻碍；第三，我们一有资金要投资，就有两位高深的顾问，一位在比利时，一位在英国——就是范登赫顿和亨斯登——各自在选择哪种投资方面给我们建议。他们的建议都是明智的，而且能够立即见效，结果都很有收益——至于具体收益多少就不用我说了吧。这种详细情况我只会对范登赫顿先生和亨斯登先生讲述。其他人都不会对此感兴趣的。
en: Behold us now at the close of the ten years, and we have realized an independence.The rapidity with which we attained this end had its origin in three reasons.Firstly, we worked so hard for it; secondly, we had no encumbrances to delay success; thirdly, as soon as we had capital to invest, two well-skilled counsellors, one in Belgium, one in England—namely, Vandenhuten and Hunsden—gave us each a word of advice as to the sort of investment to be chosen.The suggestion made was judicious; and, being promptly acted on, the result proved gainful—I need not say how gainful.I communicated details to Messrs. Vandenhuten and Hunsden.Nobody else can be interested in hearing them.

zh: 账目已经算清，我们的业务联系也已经处理完，我们一致认为，财神不是我们的主人，我们也不愿意一辈子为它打工，因为我们的追求也并不高，我们的生活习惯也很朴素，我们现在有足够的钱活下去，也有足够的钱留给我们的儿子，除此之外手头上还会有些余钱，如果能够通过正义的同情心以及无私的捐助来合理地处理这些钱的话，它们能够用来帮助慈善事业，并给予贫民以安慰。
en: Accounts being wound up, and our professional connection disposed of, we both agreed that, as Mammon was not our master, nor his service that in which we desired to spend our lives, as our desires were temperate, and our habits unostentatious, we had now abundance to live on, abundance to leave our boy, and should besides always have a balance on hand which, properly managed by right sympathy and unselfish activity, might help Philanthropy in her enterprises, and put solace into the hand of Charity.

zh: 如今我们下定决心展翅飞向英国。我们安全地到达了那里。弗朗西斯实现了她毕生的梦想。我们花了一整个夏天和秋天的时间玩遍了整个不列颠岛，随后又在伦敦度过了一个冬天。后来我们认为确实该找个地方定居下来了。我心里思念着我在某某郡的故乡，我们如今就在那个郡里住下来了；此时此刻我就在自己家的书房里写作。那个家位于一个偏僻幽静又多山的地区，离X镇三十里远；那里碧绿的山坡还没有被工厂排放的浓烟玷污，那里的水依然清澈纯净，那里长满蕨类的幽谷有着很多隆起的沼泽地，保持着自然界最为原始的荒凉景象，满地的苔藓，满地的欧洲厥，满地的风铃草，弥散着芦苇与石楠花的芬芳，吹荡着自由清新的微风。我的房子风景如画，并不算宽敞，有着低而长的窗户，前门前面有一个由格架搭成的门廊，上面覆盖着绿叶，在这个夏天的夜晚，看起来就像一个用玫瑰和常春藤搭成的拱门。花园主要是草坪，由山上的草皮铺盖而成，里面生长着像苔藓一样矮而柔软的植物，各自开满了奇特的鲜花，星星般的小花儿点缀在如刺绣般精致的绿叶中。斜坡花园的底下有一扇小门，打开便是一条如草坪般碧绿的小径，又长又阴凉，很幽僻。春天时这条小径的草皮上一般会长出最早的雏菊，小路因此得名——雏菊路，这也是这座房子的一大特色。
