en: To England we now resolved to take wing.We arrived there safely.Frances realized the dream of her lifetime.We spent a whole summer and autumn in travelling from end to end of the British Islands, and afterwards passed a winter in London.Then we thought it high time to fix our residence.My heart yearned towards my native county of —shire; and it is in —shire I now live; it is in the library of my own home I am now writing.That home lies amid a sequestered and rather hilly region, thirty miles removed from X—; a region whose verdure the smoke of mills has not yet sullied, whose waters still rim pure, whose swells of moorland preserve in some ferny glens that lie between them the very primal wildness of nature, her moss, her bracken, her blue-bells, her scents of reed and heather, her free and fresh breezes.My house is a picturesque and not too spacious dwelling, with low and long windows, a trellised and leaf-veiled porch over the front door, just now, on this summer evening, looking like an arch of roses and ivy. The garden is chiefly laid out in lawn, formed of the sod of the hills, with herbage short and soft as moss, full of its own peculiar flowers, tiny and starlike, embedded in the minute embroidery of their fine foliage.At the bottom of the sloping garden there is a wicket, which opens upon a lane as green as the lawn, very long, shady, and little frequented.On the turf of this lane generally appear the first daisies of spring—whence its name, Daisy Lane, serving also as a distinction to the house.

zh: 它（我指的是那条小径）一直延伸至一个长满树木的峡谷；那片树林——主要是橡树和山毛榉——葱葱郁郁，伸展到一栋很古老的房子附近，那是一栋伊丽莎白式建筑，比起雏菊路的房子大得多也古老得多，这里的财产和房子都属于一个我和读者都很熟悉的人。是的，在亨斯登树林里——因为那些林间空地和那栋有很多山形墙与更多烟囱的灰色建筑都在树林里，——那里住着约克·亨斯登，他依然单身，我想是还没有找到他理想的女人，虽然据我所知，在方圆四十英里内少说也有二十多个年轻女士愿意帮助他寻找妻子。
en: It terminates (the lane I mean) in a valley full of wood; which wood—chiefly oak and beech—spreads shadowy about the vicinage of a very old mansion, one of the Flizabethan structures, much larger, as well as more antique than Daisy Lane, the property and residence of an individual familiar both to me and to the reader.Yes, in Hunsden Wood—for so are those glades and that gray building, with many gables and more chimneys, named—abides Yorke Hunsden, still unmarried, never, I suppose, having yet found his ideal, though I know at least a score of young ladies within a circuit of forty miles who would be willing to assist him in the search.

zh: 这些财产是五年前他父亲去世时留给他的。在还清用家产抵押的债务之后，他就放弃了商业。我说他住在那里，但是我认为一年十二个月他不会在这儿住超过五个月。他四处游玩，每年冬天有段时间住在城里。每次他来某某郡时总是会带客人来，这些客人经常都是外国人。有时会带一个德国玄学家，有时是一个法国学者。有次他带了一个面露不满、长相野蛮的意大利人，他既不唱也不玩，弗朗西斯断定他有着“一副十足的阴谋家相”。
en: The estate fell to him by the death of his father, five years since.He has given up trade, after having made by it sufficient to pay off some encumbrances by which the family heritage was burdened.I say he abides here, but I do not think he is resident above five months out of the twelve.He wanders from land to land, and spends some part of each winter in town.He frequently brings visitors with him when he comes to —shire, and these visitors are often foreigners.Sometimes he has a German metaphysician, sometimes a French savant.He had once a dissatisfied and savage-looking Italian, who neither sang nor played, and of whom Frances affirmed that he had ‘tout l’air d’ un conspirateur.’

zh: 亨斯登请来的英国客人都是伯明翰人或者曼彻斯特人，这些人一副严肃的样子，而且，他们彷佛是由同一种思想串在一起似的，谈话内容都是关于自由贸易的。这些外国访客也都是政治家。他们谈话的主题比较宽泛，像欧洲的进步、自由主义思想在大陆的传播；在他们内心的写字板里，俄国、奥地利和罗马教皇的名字都是用红笔标刻的。我曾听见他们中一些人很有激情地谈论——是的，我曾在亨斯登树林古老的、用橡木装饰的餐厅里亲耳听见他们用多国语言进行讨论，当谈及尊重古老北方的独裁专制和更为古老的南方的迷信行为时，他们这些果敢的人有着一些独特的见解；我还听了他们主要用法语和德语说的许多瞎扯的话，关于这些我就不多说了。亨斯登本人容忍了这些满口胡言乱语的理论家；他似乎与实用主义者是同心协力的。
en: What English guests Hunsden invites are all either men of Birmingham or Manchester—hard men, seemingly knit up in one thought, whose talk is of free trade.The foreign visitors, too, are politicians.They take a wider theme—European progress—the spread of liberal sentiments over the Continent; on their mental tablets, the names of Russia, Austria, and the Pope are inscribed in red ink. I have heard some of them talk vigorous sense—yea, I have been present at polyglot discussions in the old, oak-lined dining-room at Hunsden Wood, where a singular insight was given of the sentiments entertained by resolute minds respecting old northern despotisms and older southern superstitions; also, I have heard much twaddle, enounced chiefly in French and Deutsch, but let that pass.Hunsden himself tolerated the drivelling theorists; with the practical men he seemed leagued hand and heart.

zh: 当亨斯登一个人在林子里时（他很少这样做），一般每星期来雏菊路两三次。夏天的晚上，他出于一个善意的动机来我们家门廊下抽烟。他说这样做是为了杀死玫瑰丛里的蜈蚣，他暗示说要不是他善意的烟熏法，我们肯定会发蜈蚣灾。每当下雨天时我们也几乎肯定能见到他。据他所说，是时候践踏我内心的要害而让我发狂，或者是通过侮辱霍弗和特尔把克里姆斯沃思夫人心中的恶龙逗出来。
en: When Hunsden is staying alone at the Wood (which seldom happens) he generally find his way two or three times a week to Daisy Lane.He has a philanthropic motive for coming to smoke his cigar in our porch on summer evenings.He says he does it to kill the earwigs amongst the roses, with which insects, but for his benevolent fumigations, he intimates we should certainly be overrun.On wet days, too, we are almost sure to see him.According to him, it gets on time to work me into lunacy by treading on my mental corns, or to force from Mrs. Crimsworth revelations of the dragon within her by insulting the memory of Hofer and Tell.

zh: 我们也经常去亨斯登树林，我和弗朗西斯都很喜欢去那儿拜访他。如果有其他客人的话，我们就观察他们的性格，这很有趣；他们的对话令我们很激动，也很惊奇。无论是主人还是他挑选的朋友都不会局限于谈论乡土民情，而是谈论大都市，几乎是全世界，自由自在，无所不谈。亨斯登在自己的家中礼貌有加。只要他想，他就会有无穷的法宝来招待客人。他的府邸也很有趣；房间古色古香，走廊像是充满了历史气息，房间的天花板很低，有着一排排长长的亮闪闪的玻璃格子窗，给人一种古代的阴森的、鬼魂经常出没的感觉。他在外旅行时收集了很多古董，都很整齐而雅致地摆放在那镶着板的或者挂着花毯的房间里。我在那里见过一两张画像和一两件雕塑，这都使很多贵族鉴赏家艳羡不已。
en: We also go frequently to Hunsden Wood, and both I and Frances relish a visit there highly.If there are other guests, their characters are an interesting study; their conversation is exciting and strange.The absence of all local narrowness both in the host and his chosen society gives a metropolitan, almost a cosmopolitan, freedom and largeness to the talk.Hunsden himself is a polite man in his own house.He has, when he chooses to employ it, an inexhaustible power of entertaining guests.His very mansion, too, is interesting; the rooms look storied, the passages legendary, the low-ceiled chambers with their long rows of diamond-paned lattices have an old-world, haunted air. In his travels he has collected store of articles of vertu, which are well and tastefully disposed in his panelled or tapestried rooms.I have seen there one or two pictures and one or two pieces of statuary which many an aristocratic connoisseur might have envied.

zh: 当我和弗朗西斯在亨斯登家吃过饭，度过一个晚上时光之后，他经常会步行送我们回家。他的树林很大，一些树木颇有年月，并且十分高耸。林中有着蜿蜒盘旋的小路，时而穿过空地，时而穿过灌木丛，使得返回雏菊路的道路变得有些长。很多次恰逢满月当空，夜色温和宜人，此时夜莺一展歌喉，隐于楷木中的泉水温柔地伴奏，直到从十英里之外某个小村隐约传来子夜教堂钟声时，树林的主人才会离开我们家的门廊。在这期间，他的谈话很随意，比在白天或者在人多的时候要平静很多，也要温和很多。彼时他就会忘记议论政治，会给我们详述他家的过去，讲述他家族的历史，讲述他自己和他自己的情感——这每一件事他都饶有兴趣，因为每一件事都是独一无二的。六月一个月光皎洁的夜晚，我嘲弄他关于他空想的新娘的事情，问他她何时才会将她那异质的美丽嫁接到古老的亨斯登橡树上，他突然回答说：
en: When I and Frances have dined and spent an evening with Hunsden, he often walks home with us.His wood is large, and some of the timber is old and of huge growth.There are winding ways in it which, pursued through glade and brake, make the walk back to Daisy Lane a somewhat long one.Many a time, when we have had the benefit of a full moon, and when the night has been mild and balmy, when, moreover, a certain nightingale has been singing, and a certain stream, bid in alders, has lent the song a soft accompaniment, the remote church-bell of the one hamlet in a district of ten miles has tolled midnight ere the lord of the wood left us at our porch.Free-flowing was his talk at such hours, and far more quiet and gentle than in the daytime and before numbers.He would then forget politics and discussion, and would dwell on the past times of his house, on his family history, on himself and his own feelings—subjects each and all invested with a peculiar zest, for they were each and all unique.One glorious night in June, after I had been taunting him about his ideal bride, and asking him when she would come and graft her foreign beauty on the old Hunsden oak, he answered suddenly,—

zh: “你说她是空想的，但是你看，这是她的影子，没有实物的话就不会有影子。”
en: ‘You call her ideal; but see, here is her shadow, and there cannot be a shadow without a substance.’

zh: 他带我们走出“蜿蜒小道”，来到一片山毛榉簇拥之外的空地，抬头就可望见天空。皓月洒下一片光辉到这片空地上，在月光下，亨斯登拿出一个象牙的小画像。
en: He had led us from the depth of the ‘winding way’ into a glade from whence the beeches withdrew, leaving it open to the sky. An unclouded moon poured her light into this glade and Hunsden held out under her beam an ivory miniature.

zh: 弗朗西斯迫不及待地先看了看；然后交给我——但她的小脸蛋还是靠我很近，想从我的眼神中看出我对这幅画像是怎么看的。我觉得这是一张非常漂亮又很有个性的女性脸蛋，就像他之前说过那样，“相貌端正而匀称”。图像很暗；头发乌黑，既没有遮住额头，也没有盖住双鬓——似乎是随意地向后弄去，好像这种美女不需要，不，应该说是不屑于打扮。那双意大利式的眼睛直视着你，透着自由而执着的眼神，嘴唇坚毅而美丽，下巴亦然。画像的背面镀着金字“露西亚”。
en: Frances, with eagerness, examined it first; then she gave it to me—still, however, pushing her little face close to mine, and seeking in my eyes what I thought of the portrait.I thought it represented a very handsome and very individual-looking female face, with, as he had once said, ‘straight and harmonious features.’ It was dark; the hair, raven-black, swept not only from the brow, but from the temples—seemed thrust away carelessly, as if such beauty dispensed with, nay, despised arrangement.The Italian eye looked straight into you, and an independent, determined eye it was; the mouth was as firm as fine, the chin ditto.On the back of the miniature was gilded ‘Lucia.’

zh: “那是真人画像。”我得出结论。
en: ‘That is a real head,’ was my conclusion.

zh: 亨斯登笑了笑。
en: Hunsden smiled.

zh: “我想也是的。”他回答说。“露西亚的一切都是真实的。”
en: ‘I think so,’ he replied.‘All was real in Lucia.’

zh: “她就是你想娶却娶不了的女人？”
en: ‘And she was somebody you would have liked to marry, but could not?’

zh: “我肯定想娶她，但我没有娶她，说明我娶不了。”
en: ‘I should certainly have liked to marry her, and that I have not done so is a proof that I could not.’

zh: 他要回现在在弗朗西斯手中的小画像，又收了起来。
en: He repossessed himself of the miniature, now again in Frances’ hand, and put it away.

zh: “你觉得怎么样？”他边系大衣的纽扣将它揣起来边问我的妻子。
en: ‘What do you think of it?’ he asked of my wife, as he buttoned his coat over it.

zh: “我确定露西亚曾经戴过锁链又挣脱了它们，”她奇怪的回答道。“我指的并不是婚姻的锁链，”她又加以改正，似乎是担心他会理解错误，补充道，“而是某种社会的枷锁。她脸上的表情说明她一直在努力挣脱无法忍受的束缚，为了获得一种有力而宝贵的能力，而且她的努力成功了，获得了胜利，一旦露西亚的这种能力得到自由，我肯定它会展开双翅，将露西亚带上高空，高于——”。她犹豫了一下。
en: ‘I am sure Lucia once wore chains and broke them,’ was the strange answer.‘I do not mean matrimonial chains,’ she added, correcting herself, as if she feared misinterpretation,‘but social chains of some sort.The face is that of one who has made an effort, and a successful and triumphant effort, to wrest some vigorous and valued faculty from insupportable constraint; and when Lucia’s faculty got free, I am certain it spread wide pinions and carried her higher than—’ She hesitated.

zh: “高于什么东西？”亨斯登问道。
en: ‘Than what?’ demanded Hunsden.

zh: “高于你所追随的‘得体’，让你无法得到。”
en: ‘Than les convenances permitted you to follow.’

zh: “我觉得你开始心怀恶意——说的话不着调。”
en: ‘I think you grow spiteful—impertinent.’

zh: “露西亚已经踏上舞台，”弗朗西斯继续说道，“你从来没有认真考虑要娶她。你欣赏她的独特，她的无畏，她身心的活力；你喜欢她的才能，无论是哪个方面，不管是唱歌，跳舞还是戏剧表演；你爱慕她的美貌，那是你内心所追求的那种；但是我确定你是不会在她的那个阶层里找个妻子的。”
en: ‘Lucia has trodden the stage,’ continued Frances.‘You never seriously thought of marrying her.You admired her originality, her fearlessness, her energy of body and mind; you delighted in her talent, whatever that was, whether song, dance, or dramatic representation; you worshipped her beauty, which was of the sort after your own heart; but I am sure she filled a sphere from whence you would never have thought of taking a wife.’

zh: “说的很好，”亨斯登评价说，“但至于说得对不对就要另当别论了。同时，在露西亚这样一个烛台旁边，你难道不认为你这个小小的精神烛光太暗淡了吗？”
en: ‘Ingenious,’ remarked Hunsden; ‘whether true or not is another question.Meantime, don’t you feel your little lamp of a spirit wax very pale beside such a girandole as Lucia’s?’

zh: “是的。”
en: ‘Yes.’

zh: “你至少很坦率；教师先生很快就会对你所能发出的微弱光满感到不满的。”
en: ‘Candid, at least; and the professor will soon be dissatisfied with the dim light you give?’

zh: “您会这样吗，先生？”
en: ‘Will you, monsieur?’

zh: “我的视力总是太差了，受不了强光，弗朗西斯。”这时我们已经到了小门边。
en: ‘My sight was always too weak to endure a blaze, Frances.’ And we had now reached the wicket.

zh: 我在前几页说过这是个甜蜜的夏夜。确实如此；这些天天气都很好，而今天是最好的。干草刚刚从地里拉回来，它的香味仍然弥漫在空气中。弗朗西斯在一两个小时前向我提议在草坪上品茶。我看到圆桌摆在一颗山毛榉下，上面放着陶瓷茶具。我们正等着亨斯登——喏，我听见他正往这边来；是他的声音，正以权威的口吻大谈特谈某件事；我还听见弗朗西斯的搭话声。她当然是在反驳他。他们在争论关于维克托的事情，亨斯登认定他的妈妈正在把他培养成一个毫无男子汉气概的人。克里姆斯沃斯夫人回敬说：
en: I said, a few pages back, that this is a sweet summer evening.It is; there has been a series of lovely days, and this is the loveliest.The hay is just carried from my fields, its perfume still lingers in the air. Frances proposed to me, an hour or two since, to take tea out on the lawn.I see the round table, loaded with china, placed under a certain beech.Hunsden is expected—nay, I hear he is come; there is his voice, laying down the law on some point with authority; that of Frances replies.She opposes him, of course.They are disputing about Victor, of whom Hunsden affirms that his mother is making a milksop.Mrs. Crimsworth retaliates—

zh: “就算成为一个没有男子汉气概的人也比亨斯登所说的‘好孩子’好上一千倍。”她还说如果亨斯登在这附近定居下来，而不是像一颗彗星，来去神秘，没人知道他从哪里来，到哪里去，什么时候，什么方式，何种原因，她只有把维克托送到至少一百英里之外的学校才能安心，因为凭着亨斯登那反叛的准则和不切实际的信条，二十个小孩也会被他毁掉。
en: ‘Better a thousand times he should be a milksop than what he (Hunsden) calls a “a fine lad.” ’ And, moreover, she says that if Hunsden were to become a fixture in the neighbourhood, and were not a mere comet, coming and going no one knows how, when, where, or why, she should be quite uneasy till she had got Victor away to school at least a hundred miles off, for that with his mutinous maxims and unpractical dogmas he would ruin a score of children.

zh: 在我把这部手稿锁进书桌之前我还有几句关于维克托的话要说；但得简短，因为我已经听见银器撞瓷器的叮当声。
en: I have a word to say of Victor ere I shut this manuscript in my desk; but it must be a brief one, for I hear the tinkle of silver on porcelain.

zh: 维克托不是一个漂亮的小孩，就像我不是一个英俊男人，他的母亲也不是一个标致的女人一般。他脸色苍白，身体瘦小，有着大大的眼睛，像弗朗西斯的眼睛一样黑，像我的眼窝一样深。他的身材很匀称，但是有些瘦小，还算健康。我从没见过一个小孩比他笑得还少，也没有谁像他那样坐着看一本有趣的书，或者听他母亲、亨斯登或者我给他讲冒险、惊险或者神话故事时，眉头还那样紧皱的。尽管比较沉默，他并不是不快乐；虽然表情严肃但也并不孤僻。他很容易受欢乐情绪影响，常常反应过激，几乎有些痴狂了。他是通过很老式的方式，从放在妈妈膝盖上的拼音书开始学习识字的；因为后来他不用靠那种方法鞭策也能读下去时，弗朗西斯认为没有必要给他买象牙字母，也没有尝试那些现在被认为在刺激小孩读书方面是必不可少的方法。从他会读书开始，他便成了小书虫，现在仍然如此。他的玩具很少，他也从没要求要更多。他似乎对已拥有的玩具很偏爱，几乎到了钟情的程度。他的这种情感也延伸到家里养的一两只动物上，他对它们几乎到了深爱的地步。
en: Victor is as little of a pretty child as I am of a handsome man, or his mother of a fine woman.He is pale and spare, with large eyes, as dark as those of Frances, and as deeply set as mine.His shape is symmetrical enough, but slight; his health is good.I never saw a child smile less than he does, nor one who knits such a formidable brow when sitting over a book that interests him, or while listening to tales of adventure, peril, or wonder, narrated by his mother, Hunsden, or myself.But though still, he is not unhappy; though serious, not morose.He has a susceptibility to pleasurable sensations almost too keen, for it amounts to enthusiasm.He learned to read in the old-fashioned way out of a spelling-book at his mother’s knee; and as he got on without driving by that method, she thought it unnecessary to buy him ivory letters, or to try any of the other inducements to learning now deemed indispensable.When he could read, he became a glutton of books, and is so still.His toys have been few, and he has never wanted more.For those he possesses he seems to have contracted a partiality amounting to affection.This feeling, directed towards one or two living animals of the house, strengthens almost to a passion.

zh: 亨斯登先生送给他一个小猛犬，他就依着赠送者的名字叫它约克。它后来长成一只威武的猛犬，但是在小主人的陪伴与爱抚下，它的凶猛大大地弱化了。没有约克陪伴，维克托哪儿都不去，什么都不干。学习功课的时候约克就躺在他的脚边，约克还和他在花园里嬉戏，陪他小径和树林里散步，吃饭时蹲在他的椅边，是由他亲手喂，他早上的第一件事就是找到约克，晚上睡觉前总是最后一个离开它。有一天约克陪着亨斯登先生去X镇，被街上一条患狂犬病的狗咬伤了。亨斯登先生一把它带回家，告知我情况之后，我马上到院子里开枪射死它，当时约克正在那儿卧着舔伤口。它当场死亡。它都没有看见我拿起枪，我站在它的后面。我回到屋里还没有十分钟，耳边便传来痛苦的哭声。我又回到院子里，因为哭声是从那边传来的。维克托跪在他死去的猛犬旁，弯下身子，抱着它如公牛脖子般的粗脖子，沉浸在悲恸之中。他看见了我。
en: Mr. Hunsden gave him a mastiff cub, which he called Yorke, after the donor.It grew to a superb dog, whose fierceness, however, was’ much modified by the companionship and caresses of its young master.He would go nowhere, do nothing without Yorke.Yorke lay at his feet while he learned his lessons, played with him in the garden, walked with him in the lane and wood, sat near his chair at meals, was fed always by his own hand, was the first thing he sought in the morning, the last he left at night.Yorke accompanied Mr. Hunsden one day to X—, and was bitten in the street by a dog in a rabid state.As soon as Hunsden had brought him home, and had informed me of the circumstance, I went into the yard and shot him where he lay licking his wound.He was dead in an instant.He had not seen me level the gun; I stood behind him.I had scarcely been ten minutes in the house, when my ear was struck with sounds of anguish.I repaired to the yard once more, for they proceeded thence.Victor was kneeling beside his dead mastiff, bent over it, embracing its bull-like neck, and lost in a passion of the wildest woe.He saw me.

zh: “啊，爸爸，我永远不会原谅你！永远不会原谅你！”他惊叫道。“你杀死了约克；我从窗子里看见了。我不敢相信你竟然这么残忍。我再也不爱你了！”我花了很大气力并以沉着的语气向他解释这样做很有必要。他仍然用我无法描述的悲痛欲绝的痛苦声音重复着，这声音刺透了我的心：
en: ‘O papa, I’ll never forgive you!I’ll never forgive you!’ was his exclamation.‘You shot Yorke; I saw it from the window.I never believed you could be so cruel.I can love you no more!’ I had much ado to explain to him with a steady voice the stem necessity of the deed.He still, with that inconsolable and bitter accent which I cannot render, but which pierced my heart, repeated,—

zh: “它本可以治好的——你本应该试一试——你可以用热铁烧烧伤口，或者用腐蚀剂敷在伤口上。你却没有给它一点时间；现在太晚了——它死了！”
en: ‘He might have been cured—you should have tried—you should have burnt the wound with a hot iron, or covered it with caustic.You gave no time; and now it is too late—he is dead!’

zh: 他整个身子扑到那毫无知觉的尸体上。我耐心地等了很久，直到他已经哭得筋疲力尽；然后我把他抱到怀里交给他母亲，相信她能给他最好的安慰。她已经从窗户里看到整个情形。她没有出来是因为担心她的情绪会增加我的困难，但是她现在已经做好准备来安抚儿子。她把他抱入自己关爱的怀抱里，让他坐在她柔软的腿上；只是用她的双唇，她的眼睛还有她温柔的环抱安慰了他一段时间；当他的啜泣声慢慢停止，她便告诉他约克在死的时候没有任何痛苦，但是如果让它留下来，自然死去，结局会很可怕；她特别告诉他我并不残忍（因为那个想法似乎给可怜的维克托带来极大的痛苦），就是因为我爱约克和他，我才会那么做的，而且我现在看到他哭得那么厉害，几乎心都碎了。
en: He sank fairly down on the senseless carcass.I waited patiently a long while, till his grief had somewhat exhausted him; and then I lifted him in my arms and carried him to his mother, sure that she would comfort him best.She had witnessed the whole scene from a window.She would not come out for fear of increasing my difficulties by her emotion, but she was ready now to receive him.She took him to her kind heart, and on to her gentle lap; consoled him but with her lips, her eyes, her soft embrace, for some time; and then, when his sobs diminished, told him that Yorke had felt no pain in dying, and that if he had been left to expire naturally, his end would have been most horrible; above all, she told him that I was not cruel (for that idea seemed to give exquisite pain to poor Victor), that it was my affection for Yorke and him which had made me act so, and that I was now almost heartbroken to see him weep thus bitterly.

zh: 如果他的母亲用这么低沉、这么甜蜜的语调向他讲述这些考虑和理由，再加上她那么亲切而温柔的抚摸和那么怜悯同情的神情，如果对维克托还毫无效果的话，那维克托就不配做他父亲真正的儿子。这确实产生了效果。他逐渐平静下来，脸埋在母亲的肩膀上，安静地趴在她的怀里。不一会儿他抬起头，让他的母亲再跟他说一遍约克是毫无痛苦地死去的，他的父亲并不残忍。母亲又重复了一遍这些温和的话语，他再次将他的脸颊贴在母亲的胸前，又平静下来。
en: Victor would have been no true son of his father had these considerations, these reasons, breathed in so low, so sweet a tone, married to caresses so benign, so tender, to looks so inspired with pitying sympathy, produced no effect on Wm.They did produce an effect.He grew calmer, rested his face on her shoulder, and lay still in her arms.Looking up shortly, he asked his mother to tell him over again what she had said about Yorke having suffered no pain, and my not being cruel.The balmy words being repeated, he again pillowed his cheek on her breast, and was again tranquil.

zh: 几个小时之后，他来到我的书房，问我是否能够原谅他，表示想和我和解。我把儿子拉到身边，就这样让他呆了好大一会儿，和他谈了很多，在此期间他向我披露了很多方面的情感和想法，我很赞成。我发现他的身上真得没有很多“好孩子”或者“优秀孩子”的特征，也缺少那种喝些葡萄酒就灵光闪现的才能，或者那种能够能给他人熄灭的心灵火焰和带来激情的天赋；但是我发现在他心房的土壤上健康茁壮地生长着同情、喜爱与忠诚的胚芽。我发现在他的智力花园里茁壮地生长着很多有益身心的准则，如理智、公正、品性坚强，只要保持下去，不要枯萎，势必会结出丰盛的果实。所以我在他那宽阔的前额以及苍白的、还带着泪珠的脸颊上自豪而满意地吻了一下，让他得到了安慰，然后就让他走了。但第二天我还是看见他双手遮住脸，躺在约克的坟上。他伤心了好几个星期，大概一年多时间内，他完全不想听再养只狗的建议。
en: Some hours after, he came to me in my library, asked if I forgave him, and desired to be reconciled.I drew the lad to my side, and there I kept him a good while, and had much talk with him, in the course of which he disclosed many points of feeling and thought I approved of in my son. I found, it is true, few elements of the ‘good fellow’ or the ‘fine fellow’ in him, scant sparkles of the spirit which loves to flash over the wine cup, or which kindles the passions to a destroying fire; but I saw in the soil of his heart healthy and swelling germs of compassion, affection, fidelity.I discovered in the garden of his intellect a rich growth of wholesome principles; reason, justice, moral courage, promised, if not blighted, a fertile bearing.So I bestowed on his large forehead, and on his cheek—still pale with tears—a proud and contented kiss and sent him away comforted.Yet I saw him the next day laid on the mound under which Yorke had been buried, his face covered with his hands.He was melancholy for some weeks, and more than a year elapsed before he would listen to any proposal of having another dog.

zh: 维克托学得很快。很快他就必须到伊顿公学读书，我觉得他在那里的前一两年会很悲惨。离开我，离开母亲，离开这个家会给他的心灵带来极度的痛苦。况且，他不适合替高年级学生跑腿；但是竞争意识，对知识的渴望以及成功的荣耀会逐渐刺激和奖励他的。在这段期间，我自己有着很强烈的抵触情绪来确定一个时间将我的独苗连根拔起，在离我很远的地方重新种植；当我向弗朗西斯提及这件事情时，她强忍着痛苦听着，似乎我在说一次可怕的手术，她的母性本能使她感到不寒而栗，但她的坚韧不拔不允许她畏缩。但是必须得走这一步，而且马上就要走；因为虽然弗朗西斯不想将儿子培养成没有男子汉气概的人，但她要让他习惯于一种新的待人方式，习惯于自制，习惯于志同道合的友情，而这些，除了在学校外，在任何人那里都得不到。她看到了，正如我也看到了，维克托的脾气里有着一种东西——一种像电一般的热情和力量——时而出现，迸发出令人生畏的火花。亨斯登称它为他的精神，说那不应该被强加控制。我说那是惹是生非的亚当潜移默化的影响，并且认为就算不从他身上赶走，至少也要正确地加以控制；不然任何一点肉体或者精神上的痛苦都会毁掉他，而只有这些痛苦才能使他彻底地学会自制。弗朗西斯不知道该怎么称呼儿子性格里的这种特质；但是每当它出现在他咬牙切齿时，出现在他怒火中烧的眼睛时，出现在他对于失望、灾难、突然的悲伤或者自认为的不公表现出激烈的反抗时，她会把他搂入怀中，或者独自带他去树林里走走。然后她会像哲学家一样劝服他，而维克托一向能听进去这种劝导；然后她就会满眼慈爱地看着他，维克托总会被慈爱征服的。但是将来世界也会用劝导和慈爱来面对他的狂暴吗？啊，不会的！因为他黑色眼睛里的怒火，因为他消瘦的眉头上的阴云，因为他轮廓清晰的唇角上绷紧的表情，这个孩子总有一天得到的不会是温言软语而是当头痛击，不是甜蜜一吻，而是拳打脚踢。那时无言的愤怒会使他身体虚弱、灵魂发疯，我相信受点痛苦挫折是应当并且是有益的，这样会使他成为一个更为明智和优秀的人！
en: Victor learns fast.He must soon go to Eton, where, I suspect, his first year or two will be utter wretchedness.To leave me, his mother, and his home, will give his heart an agonized wrench.Then, the fagging will not suit him; but emulation, thirst after knowledge, the glory of success, will stir and reward him in time.Meantime, I feel in myself a strong repugnance to fix the hour which will uproot my sole olive branch and transplant it far from me; and, when I speak to Frances on the subject, I am heard with a kind of patient pain, as though I alluded to some fearful operation, at which her nature shudders, but from which her fortitude will not permit her to recoil.The step must, however, be taken, and it shall be; for, though Frances will not make a milksop of her son, she will accustom him to a style of treatment, a forbearance, a congenial tenderness, he will meet with from none else.She sees, as I also see, a something in Victor’s temper—a kind of electrical ardour and power—which emits, now and then, ominous sparks.Hunsden calls it his spirit, and says it should not be curbed.I call it the leaven of the offending Adam, and consider that it should be, if not whipped out of him, at least soundly disciplined; and that he will be cheap of any amount of either bodily or mental suffering which will ground him radically in the art of self-control.Frances gives this something in her son’s marked character no name; but when it appears in the grinding of his teeth, in the glittering of his eye, in the fierce revolt of feeling against disappointment, mischance, sudden sorrow, or supposed injustice, she folds him to her breast, or takes him to walk with her alone in the wood.Then she reasons with him like any philosopher, and to reason Victor is ever accessible; then she looks at him with eyes of love, and by love Victor can be infallibly subjugated.But will reason or love be the weapons with which in future the world will meet his violence?Oh, no!For that flash in his black eye, for that cloud on his bony brow, for that compression of his statuesque lips, the lad will some day get blows instead of blandishments, kicks instead of kisses.Then for the fit of mute fury which will sicken his body and madden his soul, then for the ordeal of merited and salutary suffering out of which he will come, I trust, a wiser and a better man!

zh: 此时我看到了他。他站在亨斯登旁边，亨斯登正坐在山毛榉树下的草坪上。亨斯登一只手放在孩子的衣领上，也不知道他往孩子的耳朵里灌输着什么原则。维克托此刻看起来非常好，因为他面带微笑饶有兴致地听着，他笑的时候是最像他母亲了。可惜的是这种像阳光冲破乌云的表情太少见了！维克托对亨斯登有着一种偏爱，我觉得这样挺好，但他对他的感情比我对这位仁兄的要更加强烈、更坚决、也更全心全意。弗朗西斯也有一种无以言表的焦虑；每当儿子倚靠在亨斯登的膝盖上，或者靠在他的肩膀上，弗朗西斯就会不安地在附近走来走去，就像一只母鸽要保卫它的孩子不会被在近处盘旋的老鹰叼走一样。她说她很希望亨斯登有自己的孩子，那时他就会更好地知道放纵孩子骄傲的秉性，容忍他们的各种缺点是很危险的。
en: I see him now.He stands by Hunsden, who is seated on the lawn under the beech.Hunsden’s hand rests on the boy’s collar, and he is instilling God knows what principles into his ear. Victor looks well just now, for he listens with a sort of smiling interest, he never looks so like his mother as when he smiles.Pity the sunshine breaks out so rarely!Victor has a preference for Hunsden, full as strong as I deem desirable, being considerably more potent, decided, and undiscriminating than any I ever entertained for that personage myself. Frances, too, regards it with a sort of unexpressed anxiety; while her son leans on Hunsden’s knee, or rests against his shoulder, she roves with restless movement round, like a dove guarding its young from a hovering hawk.She says she wishes Hunsden had children of his own, for then better know the danger of inciting their pride and their foibles.

zh: 弗朗西斯走到我的书房窗边，拨开半遮住窗户的金银花枝，告诉我茶已经准备好了。看到我还在忙，她走进屋里，轻轻地走到我身边，手搭在我的肩膀上。
en: Frances approaches my library window, puts honeysuckle which half covers it, and tells me tea is ready.Seeing that I continue busy, she enters the room, comes near me quietly, and puts her hand on my shoulder.

zh: “先生真是太用功了。”
en: ‘Monsieur est trop appliqué.’

zh: “我马上就写完了。”
en: ‘I shall soon have done.’

zh: 她拉近一张椅子，坐在那儿等我写完。她在我的身边，我心里很高兴，就像闻到了新鲜干草和沁人心脾的花朵的香味，就像感受到落日的余晖，享受到仲夏之夜的宁静。
en: She draws a chair near, and sits down to wait till I have finished.Her presence is as pleasant to my mind as the perfume of the fresh hay and spicy flowers, as the glow of the westering sun, as the repose of the midsummer eve are to my senses.

zh: 但是亨斯登来了。我听见他的脚步声，看着他弯腰将身子伸进了格子窗，用那无情的手将窗旁的金银花树枝拨到一边，吓走了两只蜜蜂和一只蝴蝶。
en: But Hunsden comes.I hear his step, and there he is, bending through the lattice, from which he has thrust away the woodbine with unsparing hand, disturbing two bees and a butterfly.

zh: “克里姆斯沃思！我说克里姆斯沃思！拿掉他手上的笔，夫人，让他抬起头。”
en: ‘Crimsworth!I say, Crimsworth!Take that pen out of his hand, mistress, and make him lift up his head.’

zh: “怎么了，亨斯登？我听你说着呢——”
en: ‘Well, Hunsden?I hear you—’

zh: “我昨天在X镇。你哥哥内德做铁路投机买卖发财了，现在比克里萨斯还要富有。他们称他已经跻身股票交易大厅的十大股票投机商之一。而且我听布朗先生说。范登赫顿夫妇和让·巴普蒂斯特谈到下个月要来看你们。他还提到了珀莱夫妇。他说他们的家庭并不算世界上最和谐的，但是在事业上他们干得是“不能再好了”，他总结说，这种情况对于双方感情上的任何小的磨难都足够称得上是一种慰藉。你为什么不邀请珀莱夫妇来某某郡呢，克里姆斯沃思？我很想见一见你的初恋情人佐蕾德。夫人别嫉妒，他爱那位夫人可是爱到精神错乱呢；我可是有事实根据的。布朗说她现在重达十二英石。教师先生，你看你丢掉了什么。现在，先生、夫人，如果你们再不来用茶的话，我和维克托就要先开始了哦。”
en: ‘I was at X— yesterday.Your brother Ned is getting richer than Cresus by railway speculations.They call him in the Piece Hall a stag of ten.And I have heard from Brown.M. and Madame Vandenhuten and Jean Baptiste talk of coming to see you next month.He mentions the Pelets too.He says their domestic harmony is not the finest in the world, but in business they are doing “on ne peut mieux,” which circumstance, he concludes, will be a sufficient consolation to both for any little crosses in the affections.Why don’t you invite the Pelets to —shire, Crimsworth?I should so like to see your first flame, Zoraïde.Mistress, don’t be jealous, but he loved that lady to distraction; I know it for a fact.Brown says she weighs twelve stones now.You see what you’ve lost, Mr. Professor.Now, monsieur and madame, if you don’t come to tea, Victor and I will begin without you.’

zh: “爸爸，过来呀！”
en: ‘Papa, come!’

zh: 结束
en: The End
